Refusal to produce the dog, cat or other animal upon request of the chief of police or his authorized representative constitutes a violation of this section and each day of such refusal constitutes a separate and individual violation. 
(Ord. No. 654, § 2.)  
Sec. 5-39. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction thereof shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 654, § 2; amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 7, 9-25-12)  
CHAPTER 6 - BUILDINGS. 
 As to plumbing generally, see Ch. 21 of this Code.  
Article I. - In General. 
 For state law as to authority of city to regulate building construction generally, see CRSA § 31-15-601. 
 
Sec. 6-1. - International Building Codes—Adopted. 
There is hereby adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Fire Code (IFC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, prepared by the International Code Council (ICC), 5360 Workman Mill Road, Whittier, California, and containing a total of five hundred and three pages. 
There is hereby adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Building Code (IBC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, prepared by said International Code Council, containing one volume with a total of seven hundred and six pages. 
There is likewise adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Residential Code (IRC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, except for Section 105.2 #1, Section 105.2 #10, and Section 313, prepared by said International Code Council, and containing a total of eight hundred ninety-one pages. 
There is likewise adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Existing Building Code, (IEBC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, prepared by said International Code Council, and containing a total of two hundred ninety-four pages. 
There is likewise adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Mechanical Code (IMC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, prepared by said International Code Council, and containing a total of one hundred forty-five pages. 
There is likewise adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Plumbing Code (IPC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, prepared by said International Code Council, and containing a total of one hundred seventy pages. 
There is likewise adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Energy Conservation Code (IECC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, prepared by said International Code Council, and containing a total of ninety pages. 
There is likewise adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, prepared by said International Code Council, and containing a total of fifty pages. 
There is likewise adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Fuel Gas Code (IFGC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, prepared by said International Code Council, and containing a total of one hundred seventy-seven pages. 
There is likewise adopted as set forth herein, the following local minimum construction standards: 
THE CITY OF CORTEZ SUPPLEMENT TO THE INTERNATIONAL BUILDING AND RESIDENTIAL CODES 
(a)  Due to the unique soils and weather conditions that each structure must perform under, the City of Cortez has adopted the following specific construction standards. The items listed are more stringent than the standards delineated within the currently-adopted construction codes enforced by the City of Cortez. 
(1)  Minimum eight inches by sixteen inches concrete spread footing with two #4 rebar suspended horizontally to allow for three inches of concrete coverage. 
Exception: Minimum concrete spread footing may be less than eight inches by sixteen inches, if the foundation is designed and stamped by a Colorado Licensed Engineer and foundation design is site specific. 
(2)  Minimum eight-inch wide stem wall with two #4 rebar installed horizontally and verticals spaced at forty-eight inches on center minimum for dwellings. When insulated concrete forms are utilized, the width shall be measured from interior to interior of said forms. 
Exception: Minimum stem wall width may be less than eight inches if the foundation stem wall is designed and stamped by a Colorado Licensed Engineer and stem wall design is site specific. 
(3)  Gypsum wall board installed on a ceiling shall be a minimum of five-eights-inch in thickness. 
(4)  Sheathing for roofs shall be a minimum of five-eighths-inch in thickness installed with the required one-eighth-inch air gap. 
(5)  Roofing material installed must be rated to withstand a ninety-mph three-second wind gust/forty mph sustained. 
There are likewise previously-adopted appendix chapters in ordinance form that council has determined are desirable to retain, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, as part of the construction codes for the City of Cortez, Colorado, as follows: 
(a)  Ordinance No. 851, Series 1997—Construction Standards for the Construction of Straw Bale Homes with Load Bearing and Non-Load Bearing Walls; 
(b)  Ordinance No. 862, Series 1998—Construction and Maintenance Standards for Commercial Wireless Antennas and Supporting Towers; 
(c)  Ordinance No. 953, Series 2001—Manufactured Housing Installations in Accordance with State Resolution #37; and 
(d)  NFPA-211 Standards for Chimneys, Fireplaces, Vents, and Solid Fuel-Burning Appliances, 2000 Edition, Copyright 2000, 1st Printing, prepared by the National Fire Protection Association, 11 Tracy Drive, Avon, MA, and containing a total of forty-seven pages. 
(Ord. No. 855, § 2; Ord. No. 962 (part): Ord. No. 1087, § 2 (part).) 
(Ord. No. 1137, § II) 
 For state law as to authority of city to adopt by reference, see CRSA § 31-16-201 et seq. 
 As to the Fire Prevention Code, see §§ 10-1, 10-2 of this Code. As to the Plumbing Code, see §§ 21-1, 21-2.  
Sec. 6-1.1. - Repealed by Ord. No. 634.  
Sec. 6-2. - Currently adopted city construction codes—Copies on file. 
Three true and exact official copies of the above-described 2009 Editions of the IBC, IRC, IEBC, IMC, IPC, IECC, IPMC, IFGC, and IFC are on file in the municipal offices of the city of Cortez, Colorado, duly certified by the mayor and attested by the city clerk, and may be examined, duplicated, or copied by any interested person during the regular business hours of said offices, all such reproduction or copying to be at the expense of the person requesting the same. 
(Ord. No. 855, § 3; Ord. No. 962 (part): Ord. No. 1087, § 3 (part).) 
(Ord. No. 1137, § III)  
Sec. 6-2.1. - Approved and inspected modular homes. 
Notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary, and any modular home erected upon a foundation within the city which bears an inspection tag of "Factory Built" issued by the state of Colorado, shall be deemed to satisfy the minimum requirements of the currently adopted city construction codes of this city and such modular home shall be approved by the city building inspector upon satisfactory evidence that such modular home has been so inspected, the state inspection tag being attached to the same certified as meeting state requirements. Except as herein amended, the currently adopted city construction codes shall remain unchanged. 
(Ord. No. 457, § 1; Ord. No. 962 (part).)  
Sec. 6-3. - Repealed by Ord. No. 539.  
Sec. 6-4. - Repealed by Ord. No. 539.  
Sec. 6-4.1. - Electrical inspections required. 
All structures which have been issued a city building permit must have a final electrical inspection done by the state electrical inspector prior to the issuance of a final certificate of occupancy by the city's building department.  
Sec. 6-5. - Fire limits—Permit required for rebuilding, altering or enlarging. 
Where a building is partially destroyed by fire within the fire limits and the owner desires to rebuild such building, or to alter or enlarge a building already constructed, he shall make application for a permit as in the case of a new building, and the building official shall decide whether or not he may rebuild, alter or enlarge such building with the same material. 
(Code 1968, § 13-2-1.) 
 For state law as to authority of city to regulate building construction within fire limits, see C.R.S. 1973, § 31-12-101(43). 
 As to fire protection generally, see Ch. 10 of this Code.  
Sec. 6-6. - Same—Described. 
The fire limits of the city shall be as are set out on a map which shall be kept in the office of the city clerk. The fire limits shall be as are set by the city council and described on such map. Such map shall be available for public inspection during the normal office hours of the city clerk. 
 For state law as to authority of city to prescribe fire limits, see C.R.S 1973, § 31-15-601(d), (k).  
Sec. 6-6.1. - Unsafe buildings. 
All structures or existing equipment that are or hereafter become unsafe, unsanitary or deficient because of inadequate means of egress facilities, inadequate light and ventilation, or which constitute a fire hazard, or are otherwise dangerous to human life or the public welfare, or which involve illegal or improper occupancy or inadequate maintenance shall be deemed an unsafe condition. Unsafe structures shall be taken down and removed or made safe, as the building official deems necessary and as provided for in appropriate chapters of the currently adopted city construction codes. 
(Ord. No. 488, § 12; Ord. No. 962 (part).)  
Sec. 6-6.2. - Erection of buildings within potential flood areas; duties of building inspector and zoning and planning commission. 
(a)  The city building inspector shall review all building permit applications for new construction or substantial improvements to determine whether proposed building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding. If a proposed building site is in a location that has a flood hazard, any proposed new construction or substantial improvement (including prefabricated and mobile homes) must: 
(1)  Be designed (or modified) and anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement of the structure; 
(2)  Use construction materials and utility equipment that are resistant to flood damage; and 
(3)  Use construction methods and practices that will minimize flood damage. 
(b)  The city zoning and planning commission shall review subdivision proposals and other proposed new developments to assure that: 
(1)  All such proposals are consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; 
(2)  All public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems are located, elevated and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage; and 
(3)  Adequate drainage is provided so as to reduce exposure to flood hazards. 
(c)  The city zoning and planning commission shall require new or replacement water supply systems or sanitary sewage systems to be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters, and require on-site waste disposal systems to be located so as to avoid impairment of them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(Ord. No. 473, §§ 1—3.)  
Sec. 6-6.3. - Repealed November 27, 2001. 
 For state law as to authority of city to adopt by reference, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 31-16-202 to 31-16-204.  
Sec. 6-6.4. - Repealed November 27, 2001.  
Sec. 6-6.5. - Repealed November 27, 2001.  
Sec. 6-6.6. - NFPA-211 Standard adopted. 
(a)  Adoption by reference. There is hereby adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the NFPA-211 Standard for Chimneys, Fireplaces, Vents, and Solid Fuel-Burning Appliances, 2000 Edition, prepared by the National Fire Protection Association, NG-Fire Safety, I Batterymarch Park, PO Box 9101, Quincy, MA 02269-9101, with a total of forty-seven printed pages. 
(b)  Copies on file. Three true and exact official copies of the above NFPA-211 Standard are on file in the municipal offices of the city, duly certified by the mayor and attested by the city clerk, and may be examined, duplicated, or copied by any person interested during the regular business hours of said offices, all such reproduction or copying to be at the expense of the person requesting the same. 
(Ord. No. 879, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 962 (part).)  
Article II. - Numbering of Buildings. 
 For state law as to authority of city to compel the numbering of buildings, see C.R.S. 1973, § 31 15-601(i). 
 
Sec. 6-7. - "House" defined. 
For the purposes of this article, the word "house" shall mean any building used for dwelling or business purposes. 
(Code 1968, § 13-6-1.)  
Sec. 6-8. - System established; street designations and operation of system generally. 
(a)  The intersection of Main and Market Streets shall be the base points for such numbering system. Main Street shall be the base for the numbering of houses on streets running north or south or at a relative curve or angle from Main Street. Market Street shall be the base for the numbering of houses on streets running east or west or at a relative curve or angle from Market Street. 
(b)  All streets running north, south, east, or west or at a relative curve or angle from the base street shall contain the appropriate prefix, North, South, East or West as a part of the official name of such street. 
(c)  The north and east sides of streets shall be even numbers and the numbers on the south or west sides of street shall be odd numbers. 
(d)  There is hereby established a number for each twelve and one-half feet, which number shall be in consecutive odd or even order depending upon the side of the street, beginning with 1 and 2 at the property adjacent to the base street; numbers in the first block from the base street shall be from 1 to 99, in the second block from 100 to 199 and in such manner each block removed from the base street shall begin a new hundred serial. In new subdivisions, the 12.5 foot distance for numbering shall be followed as closely as is reasonably possible, but with modifications that may seem necessary. 
(Code 1968, § 13-6-2; Ord. No. 592, § 1.)  
Sec. 6-9. - Display and regulation of number plates. 
Each house within the limits of the city shall display in a prominent place upon the front side of such house, a number plate and number, which shall be of uniform size, style and type as follows: 
(a)  All numbers shall be upon a reflector type plate. 
(b)  All plates shall be nine inches by three and one-fourth inches in size. 
(c)  All numbers shall be three inches by three inches in size. 
(d)  All plates shall be made of metal with glass face, with black background and white reflector numbers. 
(Code 1968, § 13-6-3.)  
Sec. 6-10. - Building official to furnish information. 
The building official shall upon request furnish information as to the correct number or numbers applicable to any house upon being furnished with the proper lot and block number. 
(Code 1968, § 13-6-4.)  
Sec. 6-11. - Compliance with article required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having control of any house within the city limits to fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1968, § 13-6-5.)  
Sec. 6-11.1. - Street numbering in certain annexed areas and subdivisions. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any language in this article to the contrary, from and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in sections 6-11.1 through 6-11.3, it shall be the duty of the city manager and his staff, and he is likewise empowered and directed, to cause to be examined all official plats of annexed areas and subdivisions now on file or to be hereafter filed with the city of Cortez. 
(b)  Upon such examination it shall be his duty, aided by his staff, to assign numbers to each lot platted on such plat and to cause such number to be engraved on the official plat of the city, whether any such lot is vacant or occupied by a building. 
(c)  Such numbering of said lots shall be in an orderly sequential manner so that each lot bears a logical numbering sequence with all other lots in said subdivision or addition to the end that confusion and duplication of numbers within said subdivision or addition will be avoided. 
(d)  Such plats, after the numbers have been engraved thereon, shall be indexed and preserved in an orderly filing system in the city administration building and it shall be the duty of all persons owning a structure erected upon such lot to display a number plate upon such building as required by section 6-7 of this article. 
(e)  After all numbers have been engraved on said official plats it shall be the duty of the city manager to notify the owner or occupant of the official number assigned to said premises with a demand that such number be attached to any building thereon. 
(f)  If any such lot is vacant and unoccupied, it shall be the duty of the city building inspector to notify the owner of any building to be thereafter erected thereon of such official number and the same shall be printed on any building permit thereafter issued. 
(Ord. No. 592, § 1.)  
Sec. 6-11.2. - Official status of such numbers. 
(a)  The numbers engraved on such lots or parcels of land within said annexed areas and/or subdivisions shall be deemed to be the official house or building number for all purposes including, but not limited to, mail service United States Postal System or any other authorized delivery service serving the inhabitants of such annexed area and/or subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 592, § 1.)  
Sec. 6-11.3. - Conflicts. 
(a)  In the numbering of such lots should it appear that any structure has affixed a house or business number thereon which conflicts with the orderly sequential numbers engraved thereon, it shall be the duty of the owner of such house or business building to remove such conflicting number and to install the proper number upon being notified of such conflict by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 592, § 1.)  
Sec. 6-11.4. - Street renumbering in the city. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any language in this article to the contrary, from and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section, it shall be the duty of the city manager and his staff, and he is likewise empowered and directed to cause to be examined the entire numbering system and street naming system in the city of Cortez and upon such examination it shall be his duty, aided by his staff, to assign or reassign numbers to each business, lot or individual tract. Such numbering shall be in an orderly sequential manner so that each identified area bears a logical numbering sequence with all the others in that area to the end that confusion and duplication and improper spacing of numbers shall be avoided or corrected. 
(b)  Such numbers shall be indexed and preserved in an orderly filing system in the City Administration Building on official plats, and it shall be the duty of all persons owning a structure erected upon such lot to display a number plate on such building as required by Section 6-7 of this article. 
(c)  After all such numbers have been assigned and placed on such official plats, it shall be the duty of the city manager and his staff, to notify the owner/occupant of the official number assigned to such premises with a demand that such number be attached to any building thereon. 
(d)  If any such lot is vacant and unoccupied, it shall be the duty of the city building inspector to notify the owner of any building to be thereafter erected thereon of the official number and the same shall be printed on any building permit thereafter issued. 
(e)  Conflicts. If, in the numbering of such lots, tracts or premises as hereinbefore provided, should it appear that any structure has been affixed to a house or business the number therein which conflicts with the orderly sequential numbers engraved thereon, it shall be the duty of the owner of such lot, tract or premises to remove such conflicting numbers and to install a proper number on the improvements upon being notified of such conflict by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 663.)  
Article III. - Building Department, Building Official and Board of Appeals. 
 
Sec. 6-12. - Building department created. 
There is hereby established in the city the building department which shall be under the jurisdiction of the building official designated by the appointing authority. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 5.)  
Sec. 6-13. - Building official—Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  Generally. The building official is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all the provisions of the currently adopted city construction codes. 
(b)  Appointment of deputies. In accordance with the procedure and with the approval of the chief appointing authority of the municipality, the building official may appoint such number of officers, inspectors, assistants and other employees as shall be authorized from time to time. He may deputize such employees as may be necessary to carry out the functions of the building department. 
(c)  Reports and records. The building official shall submit a report to the proper city official not less than once a year, covering the work of the department during the preceding period. He shall incorporate in such report a summary of his recommendations as to desirable amendments to the currently adopted city construction codes. 
(d)  Account of fees and monies. The building official shall keep a permanent, accurate account of all fees and other monies collected and received under the currently adopted city construction codes, the names of the persons upon whose account the same were paid, the date and amount thereof, together with the location of the building or premises to which they relate. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 6; Ord. No. 962 (part).)  
Sec. 6-14. - Same—Right of entry for inspection—Buildings under construction. 
Whenever in the judgment of the building official or any of his deputies it becomes necessary to make an inspection of a building under construction, the building official or his authorized representative shall have at all times right to enter upon the premises where such building is being constructed and upon presenting his credentials to the owner thereof or such person as is in charge of construction and stating his reasons therefor, he shall then have the right to make such reasonable inspection of such premises to determine whether compliance with the provisions of the currently adopted city construction codes is met. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 7; Ord. No. 962 (part).)  
Sec. 6-15. - Same—Same—Occupied building. 
(a)  Inspection. The building inspector or his authorized representative shall have the right during daylight hours to make an inspection of such occupied building whenever he has reasons to believe that such inspection is reasonably necessary to enforce any of the provisions of the currently adopted city construction codes; provided, however, that in case of an occupied building, the building inspector must first present himself to the owner or occupant as the case may be, and after presenting his credentials shall make a request for an inspection of the premises stating his reasons therefor. If the owner or occupant should refuse entry to the building inspector after he has presented his credentials and stated his reasons for making such inspection and should the building inspector or his representative then believe that such refusal was arbitrary, capricious or unreasonable, the building inspector shall then have a right to file a complaint in the municipal court of the city, charging the owner or occupant or both with unreasonable refusal to permit his inspection. The court shall then set the matter for hearing and the defendant shall have the right to be represented at such hearing by counsel of his choice. If the court should determine that the request for admittance by the building official or his representative was unreasonable, capricious and without any basis and that the request for inspection was an unreasonable request, then the court shall dismiss the matter. On the other hand, if the court should find that the reasons for inspection given by the building official or his authorized representative were not arbitrary, unreasonable or capricious and that the refusal of the defendant to permit such inspection was in fact unreasonable, arbitrary or capricious, then the court may find the defendant guilty and he may be fined in the manner and to the extent as provided in this article. 
(b)  Final inspection to ensure compliance with standards. After the building inspector has completed his inspection he shall then deliver to the owner or occupant a written list of requirements necessary to comply with applicable portions of this Code and the owner or occupant shall have a reasonable time to comply with such requirements. Upon so complying the owner or occupant shall notify the building inspector by certified mail of that fact and the inspector shall then have a right to make a final inspection to determine if such requirements have been met. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 6; Ord. No. 484, § 2; Ord. No. 962 (part).)  
Sec. 6-16. - Same—Same—Unsafe buildings. 
Whenever the building official or his authorized representative has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any condition which makes such building or premises unsafe as defined in section 6-7 of this Code, the building official or his authorized representative shall first present himself to the owner thereof or the occupant and deliver to such owner or occupant, written reasons why the building official believes that such premises are unsafe as defined herein. If the owner or occupant believes that such reasons appear to be reasonable and that a dangerous condition does in fact exist, then he may admit the building official or his representative to the premises to make such inspection to the end that such dangerous condition may be removed. If on the other hand, the owner or occupant believes that such request is arbitrary, capricious or unreasonable and he should refuse such request, then the building official shall have the right to file a complaint in the municipal court of the city charging such owner or occupant or both with such unreasonable refusal and the matter shall be heard by the court as provided in section 6-15, subsection (a) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 6.)  
Sec. 6-17. - Same—Same—Emergencies. 
Whenever in the judgment of the building official or his authorized representative, it appears that there exists in a building a condition which poses an immediate threat to life or property and there is not sufficient time because of such emergency and the threat to human life or property in which to provide notice as in sections 6-14 to 6-16 of this Code, the building official shall make every bona fide effort to locate the owner or occupant thereof and to notify him orally of the dangerous condition. If the owner or occupant then refuses admission to the premises of the building official or his representative, the building official with the aid of the city attorney's office may then apply for and obtain a mandatory injunction from the district court of the county, such injunction to be ex parte and without notice as provided by law, and with such injunctive order the building official or his representative may then enter the premises and take such steps as are necessary to remove the threat of harm to life, limb or property as the case may be; provided, however, that if the threat is so pressing and the time within which to remedy the same is so short as to make it impossible to apply to the district court for such mandatory injunction and should the threat of harm to life, limb or property be so grave and immediate that action must be taken at once, the building official shall have the right in the company of the chief of police of the city and the chief of the fire department to enter such premises with or without consent of the occupant or owner in order to remove such dangerous condition or instrumentality. 
"Authorized representative" shall include the officers named in section 6-11.2, subsection (b). 
No owner or occupant or any other person having charge, care or control of any building or premises shall fail or neglect, after proper demand is made as herein provided, to promptly permit entry therein by the building official or his authorized representative for the purpose of inspection and examination pursuant to this article. Any person violating this section may be found guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be subject to the fines set forth in section 6-26. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 6.)  
Sec. 6-18. - Same—Stop-work orders. 
Whenever any building work is being done contrary to the provisions of the currently adopted city construction codes, the building official may order the work stopped by notice in writing served on any persons engaged in the doing or causing such work to be done, and any such persons shall forthwith stop such work until authorized by the building official to proceed with the work. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 8; Ord. No. 962 (part).)  
Sec. 6-19. - Same—Occupancy violations. 
Whenever any structure is being used contrary to the provisions of the currently adopted city construction codes, the building official may order such use discontinued and the structure, or portion thereof, vacated by notice served on any person causing such use to be continued. Such person shall discontinue the use within ten days after receipt of such notice or make the structure, or portion thereof, comply with the requirements of the currently adopted city construction codes; provided, however, that in the event of an unsafe building, section 6-7 of this Code shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 9; Ord. No. 962 (part).)  
Sec. 6-20. - Same—Liability. 
The building official or any employee charged with the enforcement of the currently adopted city construction codes, acting in good faith and without malice for the city in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself liable personally and he is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or by reason of any act or omission in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against the building official or employee, because of such act or omission performed by him in the enforcement of any provisions of the currently adopted city construction codes, shall be defended by the legal department of the city until final termination of the proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 10; Ord. No. 962 (part).)  
Sec. 6-21. - Same—Cooperation of other officials. 
The building official may request, and shall receive so far as may be necessary in the discharge of his duties, the assistance and cooperation of other officials of the city. 
(Ord. No. 483, § 11.)  
Sec. 6-22. - Board of appeals created. 
There is hereby created a board of appeals which shall be created in accordance with paragraph 6-15, board of adjustment of the Cortez Land Use Code, and all provisions of paragraph 6-15 shall be adhered to. 
All appeals to the board shall be in accordance with paragraph 6-15 of the Cortez Land Use Code. 
(Ord. No. 488, § 13; Ord. No. 963 (part): Ord. No. 1006 (part).)  
Sec. 6-23. - Repealed February 10, 2004.  
Sec. 6-24. - Repealed February 10, 2004.  
Sec. 6-25. - Repealed February 10, 2004.  
Sec. 6-26. - Repealed February 10, 2004.  
CHAPTER 7. - CIVIL DEFENSE AND EMERGENCIES. 
 For state law as to authority of city to establish civil defense organization, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 28-1-2, 28-2-108. As to civil defense generally, see C.R.S. 1973, § 28-2-101 et seq. 
 
Sec. 7-1. - Mayor to establish program; scope of program. 
The mayor of the city is hereby empowered and authorized to promulgate in writing such rules and regulations as may be reasonably necessary for the protection of life and property within the city from dangers or hazards created or increased by the existing state of war or for the coordinating of an efficient program of civilian defense, including, but not by way of limitation: 
(a)  Defense of the city and its inhabitants against air raids or attack, warnings to be given, black-outs and care of persons and property during such emergency. 
(b)  Prevention of sabotage of property within the city and designation of insignia and symbols to be used by authorized civil defense workers or organizations. 
(c)  Control of traffic movements, evacuation of residents, systems of warning and alarm and conduct of persons during practice black-outs. 
(Code 1968, § 1-5-1.)  
Sec. 7-2. - Mayor may delegate authority. 
The mayor is authorized to delegate in writing to such agencies or persons as he may designate or appoint for such purpose the authority granted by this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 1-5-2.)  
Sec. 7-3. - Enforcement of chapter. 
The law enforcement authorities of the city are authorized and directed to enforce the orders, rules and regulations made or issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 1-5-3.)  
Sec. 7-4. - Disclaimer of liability of city, etc. 
Neither the city, nor its agents or representatives who, in good faith, carry out, comply with or attempt to carry out or comply with any order, rule, regulation or command promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be liable for any injury or death to any person or damage to any property as the result of such activity. 
(Code 1968, § 1-5-4.)  
Sec. 7-5. - Effect of section 7-4 on workman's compensation, etc.; chapter and rules promulgated thereunder deemed governmental function. 
(a)  Section 7-4 shall not affect the right of any person to receive benefits or compensation to which he might otherwise be enTitled under the Workman's Compensation Act or other pension law. 
(b)  This chapter and any rules, regulation or order promulgated hereunder shall constitute the exercise by the city of its governmental functions. 
(Code 1968, § 1-5-5.)  
CHAPTER 7A. - DISPOSAL OF PROPERTY.  
Article I. - Property Received as Evidence. 
 
Sec. 7A-1. - Safekeeping by officer pending disposition—Records required. 
When personal property comes into the possession of a police officer of the city either in execution of a search warrant, or pursuant to an arrest of a person with or without warrant, or is received or taken by him as evidence in connection with any public offense, he shall hold it in safe custody until it is received into evidence or, if it is not used as evidence, until it can be disposed of as provided in this chapter. While in the custody of such officer, a proper record shall be maintained reflecting the ownership of the property, if known, and the case or cases for which it was taken or received and is being held. 
(Ord. No. 577, Art. I.)  
Sec. 7A-1.1. - Property turnover. 
Any property turned over to the Cortez police department by any other law enforcement agency shall be subject to all provisions of this Chapter 7, including being subject to destruction or return in accordance with the guidelines set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1090 (part).)  
Sec. 7A-2. - Return of property not needed as evidence—Procedure. 
Property so obtained which is not needed as evidence shall be returned to the owner if he may lawfully possess it. When the police officer or the agency by which he is employed becomes aware that the property is not needed, the district attorney and/or the city attorney shall be so advised, giving a description and details of ownership. When the police chief or his designated agent, by such notice or otherwise, becomes aware that the property is not needed, he shall give written notice to the owner. Upon proof of ownership and of lawfulness of possession satisfactory to the police chief, the police chief shall give the owner written authorization which shall entitle the owner to receive the property from the person having custody of it. When property so obtained is received in evidence, it shall be retained by the clerk of the court last receiving it or shall be returned by him to the custody of the police officer until all direct appeals and retrials are final, at which time the property shall be returned in accordance with this section. 
In the event that the district attorney or city attorney considers it necessary to retain control over the evidence, in anticipation of possible collateral attacks upon the judgment or of use in some potential prosecution, he may decline to authorize return. 
(Ord. No. 577, Art. II; Ord. No. 812, § 1.)  
Sec. 7A-3. - Receipt from owner of returned property. 
Whenever property is returned to the owner, a receipt shall be taken from him listing in detail the property returned. The receipt shall be retained on record (shall be held in accordance with Colorado Revised Statutes, 1973, Sections 24-80-101 through 24-80-112) in the files of the city police department or the court where the case is finally resolved. 
(Ord. No. 577, Art. III.)  
Sec. 7A-4. - Sale of unclaimed property—Disposition of proceeds. 
If the property is not claimed by the owner before the expiration of thirty days from the receipt of notice, or if the owner is unknown and no claim of ownership has been made, the city police department having possession of the property shall sell it at public auction, as provided by law for the sale of personal property on execution, and with the proceeds pay: 
(a)  The necessary expenses incurred in the preservation of such property and its sale; and 
(b)  Any balance to the director of finance under the provisions of Article VIII of the Charter. 
The said property may also be destroyed at the discretion of the police chief or his designated representative. 
(Ord. No. 577, Art. IV; Ord. No. 1090 (part); Ord. No. 1098 (part).)  
Sec. 7A-5. - Property seized from person—Duplicate receipts. 
When money or other property is seized with or without a warrant, the police officer seizing it shall at the time deliver a receipt to the person from whom it is taken and file a duplicate in the office of the city police department. If the custody of the property is transferred to another police agency or the property is placed in evidence, a copy of the receipt shall accompany it until disposition of the property is made in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 577, Art. V.)  
Article II. - Found Property. 
 
Sec. 7A-6. - Storage period. 
When personal property is turned over to the police department by citizens who found the same, the property shall be stored by the city for a period of not less than thirty days or until someone who can establish themselves as the rightful owner claims and removes the property. 
(Ord. No. 674, 1; Ord. No. 1098 (part).)  
Sec. 7A-7. - Return to finder. 
If the property is maintained for a period of thirty days and is unclaimed by any person, then the property may be returned to the finder of the same, who shall acknowledge receipt of the property. The receipt shall contain the warning: 
The City of Cortez or the Police Department make no determination as to the legal ownership of the property, but is returning same to the finder who first brought the property to the City of Cortez. If, in the future, there is any question concerning the true ownership of the property then the City of Cortez has expressed no opinion as to the ownership and the question shall be resolved between the person who claims to be the legal owner and the party who returned the property to the City of Cortez. 
The receipt shall adequately describe the property. 
(Ord. No. 674, § 2; Ord. No. 1098 (part).)  
Sec. 7A-8. - Unclaimed property. 
The property will be disposed of in accordance with Section 7A-4 of this Code in the event that the party turning the property into the city as lost property does not make a claim thereon within thirty days after the date of turning said property in to the city. 
(Ord. No. 674, § 3; Ord. No. 1098 (part).)  
Sec. 7A-9. - Retention of receipts. 
All receipts, both from the city and from the finder who removes the property from the city's possession, according to this article, shall be retained for a period of at least three years. 
(Ord. No. 674, § 4.)  
Article III. - Disposal of Unclaimed Property. 
 
Sec. 7A-10. - Purpose of provisions. 
The purpose of this article is to provide for the administration and disposition of unclaimed property which is in the possession of or under the control of the city. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 1.)  
Sec. 7A-11. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise required by context or use, words and terms shall be defined as follows: 
(a)  "Director" shall mean the director of finance, or designee thereof. 
(b)  "Municipality" means the city of Cortez, Colorado. 
(c)  "Owner" means a person or entity, including a corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity other than this municipality, or a duly authorized legal representative or successor in interest of same, which owns unclaimed property held by the municipality. 
(d)  "Unclaimed property" means any tangible or intangible property, including any income or increment derived therefrom, less any lawful charges, that is held by or under the control of the city and which has not been claimed by its owner for a period of more than five years after it became payable or distributable. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 2.)  
Sec. 7A-12. - Procedure for disposition of property. 
(a)  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of twenty-five dollars or more, the director shall send a written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the owner as shown by the records of the municipal department holding the property. The notice shall include a description of the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the director with a written claim for the return of the property within thirty days of the date of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the municipality and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(b)  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of less than twenty-five dollars or having no last known address of the owner, the director shall cause a notice to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice shall include a description of the property, the owner of the property, the amount or estimated value of the property and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the director with a written claim for the return of the property within sixty days of the date of the publication of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the municipality and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(c)  If the director receives no written claim within the thirty-day claim period, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(d)  If the director receives a written claim within the thirty-day claim period, the director shall evaluate the claim and give written notice to the claimant within ninety days thereof that the claim has been accepted or denied in whole or in part. The director may investigate the validity of a claim and may request further supporting documentation from the claimant prior to disbursing or refusing to disburse the property. 
(e)  In the event that there is more than one claimant for the same property, the director may, in the director's sole discretion, resolve such claims, or may resolve such claims by depositing the disputed property with the registry of the district court in an interpleader action. 
(f)  In the event that all claims filed are denied, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner of such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(g)  Any legal action filed challenging a decision of the director shall be filed pursuant to Rule 106 of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure within thirty days of such decision or shall be forever barred. If any legal action is timely filed, the property shall be disbursed by the director pursuant to the order of the court having jurisdiction over such claim. 
(h)  The director is authorized to establish and administer procedures for the administration and disposition of unclaimed property consistent with this article, including compliance requirements for other municipal officers and employees in the identification and disposition of such property. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 3; Ord. No. 1098 (part).)  
Sec. 7A-13. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Any property which is held by the police department pursuant to the provision of Municipal Ordinance No. 577 or Ordinance No. 674, said ordinances being codified as chapter 7A, sections 7A-1 to 7A-9, shall be exempt from the provisions of this article and shall be disposed of in accordance with Chapter 7A sections 7A-1 to 7A-9. 
(b)  Any property which is held by the city pursuant to the provisions of Municipal Ordinance No. 555, codified as chapter 18A, sections 18A-1 through 18A-7, shall be exempted from the provisions of this article and shall be disposed of in accordance with chapter 18, section 18A-8. 
(Ord. No. 760, § 4.)  
CHAPTER 8. - ELECTRICITY.  
CHAPTER 9. - FINANCE AND TAXATION. 
 For charter provision as to city finances generally, see Char., art. VII. As to taxation generally, see Char., art. VII, §§ 12, 13, 15, 19. 
 For state law authorizing city to control finances of city, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 31-15-301 to 31-15-302. As to city finances generally, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 31-20-201 to 31-20-202. As to power to tax, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 31-15-302, 31-20-101 to 31-20-107. 
 As to the occupation tax for alcoholic beverages, see §§ 4-3 to 4-10 of this Code. As to licenses and business regulations generally, see Ch. 15. As to public improvements generally, see Ch. 22. As to the rates, charges and bills for the use of the water system, see §§ 27-21 to 27-29.  
Article I. - In General. 
 
Sec. 9-1. - Purchase orders—Requisite to validity of accounts. 
No account rendered by any person to or on behalf of the city shall be valid unless a purchase order has been issued upon such form as designated by the director of finance and signed by the city manager or by a purchasing agent designated by such manager. 
(Ord. No. 417, § 1.) 
 For charter provision as to a division of purchase generally, see Char., art. IX.  
Sec. 9-2. - Same—When required. 
The provisions of section 9-1 shall apply to all bills or accounts rendered to or on behalf of the city for materials, equipment, supplies, labor or services. 
(Ord. No. 417, § 2.)  
Sec. 9-3. - Reserved for future legislation.  
Sec. 9-4. - Same—Approval of bills in excess of two thousand dollars. 
All bills or accounts to be incurred by the city in excess of two thousand dollars shall first be approved at a regular meeting of the city council and by the city council of the city of Cortez. All bills or accounts below two thousand dollars must be approved by a department head and the city manager prior to payment. In the event an account or bill must be paid which exceeds the two thousand dollar limit prior to a city council meeting, a city council person must be notified and approve the expenditure prior to payment being made. 
(Ord. No. 1040.)  
Sec. 9-5. - Sales and use tax—Collection—Limitation of Actions. 
(a)  No sales or use tax, or interest thereon or penalties with respect thereto, shall be assessed, nor shall any notice of lien be filed, or distraint warrant issued, or suit for collection be instituted, nor any other action to collect the same be commenced, more than three years after the date on which the tax was or is payable; nor shall any lien continue after such period, except for taxes assessed before the expiration of such period, notice of lien with respect to which has been filed prior to the expiration of such period, in which cases such lien shall continue only for one year after the filing of notice thereof. In the case of a false or fraudulent return with intent to evade tax, the tax, together with interest and penalties thereon, may be assessed, or proceedings for the collection of such taxes may be begun at any time. Before the expiration of such period of limitation, the taxpayer and the director of finance may agree in writing to an extension thereof, and the period so agreed on may be extended by subsequent agreements in writing. 
(b)  In the case of failure to file a return, the sales tax, use tax, or both may be assessed and collected at any time. 
(c)  Other Remedies. Nothing in sections 9-5 and 9-6 shall preclude the city from utilizing any other applicable penalties or remedies for the collection or enforcement of sales or use taxes. 
(Ord. No. 645, Art. 1 § 1.)  
Sec. 9-6. - Same—Standard reporting form and map/location guide. 
(a)  The city shall use the standard municipal sales and use tax reporting form and any subsequent revisions thereto adopted by the executive director of the department of revenue by the first full month commencing one hundred twenty days after the effective date of the regulation adopting or revising such standard form. 
(b)  Map/Location Guide of Municipal Boundaries. The city shall make available to any requesting vendor, a map showing the boundaries of the city. For transactions consummated on or after January 1, 1986, the requesting vendor may rely on such map/location guide and any update thereof available to such vendor in determining whether to collect a sales or use tax or both. No penalty shall be imposed or action for deficiency maintained against such a vendor who in good faith complies with the most recent map/location guide available to it. 
(Ord. No. 645, Art. 1 § 2.)  
Sec. 9-6A. - Collection of delinquent charges, assessments and taxes by the county treasurer. 
(a)  Until paid all fees, rates, penalties, charges or assessments together with interest on delinquencies, and reasonable attorney's fees incurred in the collection of same by the city shall constitute a perpetual lien on and against the property served real or personal and any such lien may be foreclosed in the same manner as provided for by state law for the foreclosure of mechanic's liens or may be collected in any other manner legally permissible including certification to the Montezuma County Treasurer for collection as provided in CRS 31-20-105 Municipalities May Certify Delinquent Charges. 
(b)  There shall be included in any amount certified to the county treasurer any cost of collection charged to the city of Cortez by the county treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1171, 9-25-12)  
Article II. - Retail Sales. 
 For charter provision as to taxation, see Char., art. VII, §§ 12, 13, 15, 19. 
 For state law authorizing city to levy taxes, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 31-12-101(5), 31-20-101 to 31-20-107.  
Division 1. - Generally. 
 
Sec. 9-7. - Words and phrases defined. 
The following words and phrases as used in this chapter shall have the following meaning: 
Agricultural producer. A person regularly engaged in the business of using land for the production of commercial crops or commercial livestock. The term includes farmers, market gardeners, commercial fruit growers, livestock breeders, dairymen, poultrymen, and other persons similarly engaged, but does not include a person who breeds or markets animals, birds, or fish for domestic pets nor a person who cultivates, grows, or harvests plants or plant products exclusively for that person's own consumption or casual sale. 
Aircraft. A device that is used or intended to be used for flight in the air. 
Aircraft part. Any tangible personal property that is intended to be permanently affixed or attached as a component part of an aircraft. 
Aircraft simulator. A flight simulator training device (FSTD) as defined in Part I of Title 14 of the Code of Federal Regulations that is qualified in accordance with Part 60 of Title 14 of the Code of Federal Regulations for use in a Federal Aviation Administration Approved Flight Training Program. 
Aircraft simulator part. Any tangible personal property that is originally designed and intended to be permanently affixed or attached as a component part of an aircraft, and which will also function when it is permanently affixed or attached as a component part of an aircraft simulator. 
Airline company. Any operator who engages in the carriage by aircraft of persons or property as a common carrier for compensation or hire, or the carriage of mail, or any aircraft operator who operates regularly between two or more points and publishes a flight schedule. Airline company shall not include operators whose aircraft are all certified for a gross takeoff weight of twelve thousand five hundred pounds or less and who do not engage in scheduled service or mail carriage service. 
Auction. Any sale where tangible personal property is sold by an auctioneer who is either the agent for the owner of such property or is in fact the owner thereof. 
Automotive vehicle. Any vehicle or device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, or any device used or designed for aviation or flight in the air. Automotive vehicle includes, but is not limited to, motor vehicles, trailers, semi-trailers, or mobile homes. Automotive vehicle shall not include devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
Business. All activities engaged in or caused to be engaged in with the object of gain, benefit, or advantage, direct or indirect. 
Candy. A preparation of sugar, honey, or other natural or artificial sweeteners in combination with chocolate, fruit, nuts, or other ingredients or flavorings in the form of bars, drops, or pieces. Candy does not include any preparation containing flour, products that require refrigeration or marijuana infused products. 
Carrier access services. The services furnished by a local exchange company to its customers who provide telecommunications services which allow them to provide such telecommunications services. 
Charitable Organization. Any entity which: 
(1)  Has been certified as a nonprofit organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, and 
(2)  Is an organization which exclusively, and in a manner consistent with existing laws and for the benefit of an indefinite number of persons or animals, freely and voluntarily ministers to the physical, mental, or spiritual needs of persons or animals, and thereby lessens the burden of government. 
City or town. The municipality of the City of Cortez. 
Coins. Monetized bullion or other forms of money manufactured from gold, silver, platinum, palladium or other such metals now, in the future or heretofore designated as a medium of exchange under the laws of this state, the United States or any foreign nation. 
Coin-operated device. Any device operated by coins or currency or any substitute therefor. 
Collection costs. Shall include, but is not limited to, all costs of audit, assessment, bank fees, hearings, execution, lien filing, distraint, litigation, locksmith fees, auction fees and costs, prosecution and attorney fees. 
Commercial packaging materials. Containers, labels, and/or cases, that become part of the finished product to the purchaser, used by or sold to a person engaged in manufacturing, compounding, wholesaling, jobbing, retailing, packaging, distributing or bottling for sale, profit or use, and is not returnable to said person for reuse. Commercial packaging materials does not include commercial shipping materials. 
Commercial shipping materials. Materials that do not become part of the finished product to the purchaser which are used exclusively in the shipping process. Commercial shipping materials include but are not limited to containers, labels, pallets, banding material and fasteners, shipping cases, shrink wrap, bubble wrap or other forms of binding, padding or protection. 
Community organization. A nonprofit entity organized and operated exclusively for the promotion of social welfare, primarily engaged in promoting the common good and general welfare of the community, so long as: 
(1)  No part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual; 
(2)  No substantial part of the activities of which is carrying on propaganda, or otherwise attempting to influence legislation; and 
(3)  Which does not participate in, or intervene in (including the publishing or distributing of statements), any political campaign on behalf of any candidate for public office. 
Construction equipment. Any equipment, including mobile machinery and mobile equipment, which is used to erect, install, alter, demolish, repair, remodel, or otherwise make improvements to any real property, building, structure or infrastructure. 
Construction materials. Tangible personal property which, when combined with other tangible personal property, loses its identity to become an integral and inseparable part of a structure or project including public and private improvements. Construction materials include, but are not limited to, such things as: Asphalt, bricks, builders' hardware, caulking material, cement, concrete, conduit, electric wiring and connections, fireplace inserts, electrical heating and cooling equipment, flooring, glass, gravel, insulation, lath, lead, lime, lumber, macadam, millwork, mortar, oil, paint, piping, pipe valves and pipe fittings, plaster, plumbing fixtures, putty, reinforcing mesh, road base, roofing, sand, sanitary sewer pipe, sheet metal, site lighting, steel, stone, stucco, tile, trees, shrubs and other landscaping materials, wall board, wall coping, wallpaper, weather stripping, wire netting and screen, water mains and meters, and wood preserver. The above materials, when used for forms, or other items which do not remain as an integral and inseparable part of completed structure or project are not construction materials. 
Consumer. Any person in the city who purchases, uses, stores, distributes or otherwise consumes tangible personal property or taxable services, purchased from sources inside or outside the city. 
Contract auditor. A duly authorized agent designated by the taxing authority and qualified to conduct tax audits on behalf of and pursuant to an agreement with the municipality. 
Contractor. Any person who shall build, construct, reconstruct, alter, expand, modify, or improve any building, dwelling, structure, infrastructure, or other improvement to real property for another party pursuant to an agreement. For purposes of this definition, contractor also includes subcontractor. 
Cover charge. A charge paid to a club or similar entertainment establishment which may, or may not, entitle the patron paying such charge to receive tangible personal property, such as food and/or beverages. 
Data processing equipment. Any equipment or system of equipment used in the storage, manipulation, management, display, reception or transmission of information. 
Digital product. An electronic product including, but not limited to: 
(1)  "Digital images" which means works that include, but are not limited to, the following that are generally recognized in the ordinary and usual sense as "photographs," "logos," "cartoons," or "drawings"; 
(2)  "Digital audio-visual works" which means a series of related images which, when shown in succession, impart an impression of motion, together with accompanying sounds, if any; 
(3)  "Digital audio works" which means works that result from the fixation of a series of musical, spoken, or other sounds, including ringtones. For purposes of the definition of "digital audio works", "ringtones" means digitized sound files that are downloaded onto a device and that may be used to alert the customer with respect to a communication; and 
(4)  "Digital books" which means works that are generally recognized in the ordinary and usual sense as "books". 
Distribution. The act of distributing any article of tangible personal property for use or consumption, which may include, but not be limited to, the distribution of advertising gifts, shoppers guides, catalogs, directories, or other property given as prizes, premiums, or for goodwill or in conjunction with the sales of other commodities or services. 
Dual residency. Those situations including, but not limited to, where a person maintains a residence, place of business or business presence, both within and outside the city. A person shall be deemed to have established a legitimate residence, place of business or business presence outside of the city for purposes of dual residency if the person has a physical structure owned, leased or rented by such person which is designated by street number or road location outside of the city, has within it a telephone or telephones in the name of such person and conducts business operations on a regular basis at such location in a manner that includes the type of business activities for which the business (person), as defined in this Code, is organized. 
Dwelling unit. A building or any portion of a building designed for occupancy as complete, independent living quarters for one or more persons, having direct access from the outside of the building or through a common hall and having living, sleeping, kitchen and sanitary facilities for the exclusive use of the occupants. 
Engaged in business in the city. Performing or providing services or selling, leasing, renting, delivering or installing tangible personal property for storage, use or consumption, within the city. Engaged in business in the city includes, but is not limited to, any one of the following activities by a person: 
(1)  Directly, indirectly, or by a subsidiary maintains a building, store, office, salesroom, warehouse, or other place of business within the taxing jurisdiction; 
(2)  Sends one or more employees, agents or commissioned sales persons into the taxing jurisdiction to solicit business or to install, assemble, repair, service, or assist in the use of its products, or for demonstration or other reasons; 
(3)  Maintains one or more employees, agents or commissioned sales persons on duty at a location within the taxing jurisdiction; 
(4)  Owns, leases, rents or otherwise exercises control over real or personal property within the taxing jurisdiction; or 
(5)  Makes more than one delivery into the taxing jurisdiction within a twelve-month period by any means other than a common carrier. 
Factory built housing. A manufactured home or modular home. 
Farm closeout sale. Full and final disposition of all tangible personal property previously used by a farmer or rancher in farming or ranching operations which are being abandoned. 
Farm equipment. Any farm tractor, as defined in section 42-1-102(33), C.R.S., any implement of husbandry, as defined in section 42-1-102(44), C.R.S., and irrigation equipment having a per unit purchase price of at least one thousand dollars. Farm equipment also includes, regardless of purchase price, attachments and bailing wire, binders twine and surface wrap used primarily and directly in any farm operation. Farm equipment also includes, regardless of purchase price, parts that are used in the repair or maintenance of the farm equipment described in this paragraph, all shipping pallets, crates, or aids paid for by a farm operation, and aircraft designed or adapted to undertake agricultural applications. Farm equipment also includes, regardless of purchase price, dairy equipment. Except for shipping pallets, crates or aids used in the transfer or shipping of agricultural products, farm equipment does not include: 
(1)  Vehicles subject to the registration requirements of section 42-3-103, C.R.S., regardless of the purpose for which such vehicles are used; 
(2)  Machinery, equipment, materials, and supplies used in a manner that is incidental to a farm operation; 
(3)  Maintenance and janitorial equipment and supplies; and 
(4)  Tangible personal property used in any activity other than farming, such as office equipment and supplies and equipment and supplies used in the sale or distribution of farm products, research, or transportation. 
Farm operation. The production of any of the following products for profit, including, but not limited to, a business that hires out to produce or harvest such products: 
(1)  Agricultural, viticultural, fruit, and vegetable products; 
(2)  Livestock; 
(3)  Milk; 
(4)  Honey; and 
(5)  Poultry and eggs. 
Finance director. The finance director of the City of Cortez or such other person designated by the municipality; finance director shall also include such person's designee. 
Garage sales. Sales of tangible personal property, except automotive vehicles, occurring at the residence of the seller, where the property to be sold was originally purchased for use by members of the household where such sale is being conducted. The term includes, but is not limited to, yard sales, estate sales, and block sales. 
Gross sales. The total amount received in money, credit, property or other consideration valued in money for all sales, leases, or rentals of tangible personal property or services. 
Internet access services. Services that provide or enable computer access by multiple users to the Internet, but shall not include that portion of packaged or bundled services providing phone or television cable services when the package or bundle includes the sale of Internet access services. 
Internet subscription service. Software programs, systems, data and applications available online through rental, lease or subscription, that provide information and services including, but not limited to, data linking, data research, data analysis, data filtering or record compiling. 
License. A City of Cortez sales and/or use tax license. 
Linen services. Services involving the provision and cleaning of linens, including but not limited to rags, uniforms, coveralls and diapers. 
Lodging services. The furnishing of any rooms or accommodations by any person, partnership, association, corporation, estate, representative capacity or any other combination of individuals by whatever name known to a person who, for consideration possesses or has the right to use or possess any room, including but not limited to a hotel, inn, bed and breakfast, apartment, lodging house, motor hotel, guesthouse, guest ranch, trailer coach, mobile home, auto camp, trailer court and park, any portion of a dwelling unit or other area which accommodates a guest, or similar establishment, for a period of less than thirty days under any rental agreement, concession, permit, right of access, license to use, or other agreement. 
Machinery. Any apparatus consisting of interrelated parts used to produce an article of tangible personal property. The term includes both the basic unit and any adjunct or attachment necessary for the basic unit to accomplish its intended function. 
Manufactured home. Any preconstructed building unit or combination of preconstructed building units, without motive power, where such unit or units are manufactured in a factory or at a location other than the residential site of the completed home, which is designed and commonly used for occupancy by persons for residential purposes, in either temporary or permanent locations, and which unit or units are not licensed as a vehicle. 
Manufacturing. The operation or performance of an integrated series of operations which places a product, article, substance, commodity, or other tangible personal property in a form, composition or character different from that in which it was acquired whether for sale or for use by a manufacturer. The change in form, composition or character must result in a different product having a distinctive name, character or use from the raw or prepared materials. 
Medical marijuana. Marijuana acquired, possessed, cultivated, manufactured, delivered, transported, supplied, sold, or dispensed to a person who qualifies as a patient with a debilitating medical condition(s) under article XVIII, section 14, of the Colorado Constitution, and which person holds a valid "registry identification card" issued by the State of Colorado pursuant to Colorado Constitution, article XVIII, section 14. 
Mobile machinery and self-propelled construction equipment. Those vehicles, self-propelled or otherwise, which are not designed primarily for the transportation of persons or cargo over the public highways, and those motor vehicles which may have originally been designed for the transportation of persons or cargo over the public highways, and those motor vehicles which may have originally been designed for the transportation of persons or cargo but which have been redesigned or modified by the mounting thereon of special equipment or machinery, and which may be only incidentally operated or moved over the public highways. This definition includes but is not limited to wheeled vehicles commonly used in the construction, maintenance, and repair of roadways, the drilling of wells, and the digging of ditches. 
Modular home. Any structure that consists of multiple sections fabricated, formed or assembled in manufacturing facilities for installation and assembly at the building site, and is constructed to the building codes adopted by the state division of housing, created in section 24-32-706, C.R.S., and is designed to be installed on a permanent foundation. 
Motor fuel. Gasoline, casing head or natural gasoline, benzol, benzene and naphtha, gasohol and any other liquid prepared, advertised, offered for sale, sold for use or used or commercially usable in internal combustion engines for the generation of power for the propulsion of motor vehicles upon the public highways. The term does not include fuel used for the propulsion or drawing of aircraft or railroad cars or railroad locomotives. 
Newspaper. A publication, printed on newsprint, intended for general circulation, and published regularly at short intervals, containing information and editorials on current events and news of general interest. The term newspaper does not include: Magazines, trade publications or journals, credit bulletins, advertising inserts, circulars, directories, maps, racing programs, reprints, newspaper clipping and mailing services or listings, publications that include an updating or revision service, or books or pocket editions of books. 
Online garage sales. Sales of tangible personal property, except automotive vehicles, occurring online, where the property to be sold was originally purchased for use by the seller or members of the seller's household. 
Parent. A parent of a student. 
Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, estate or trust, receiver, trustee, assignee, lessee or any person acting in a fiduciary or representative capacity, whether appointed by court or otherwise, or any group or combination acting as a unit. 
Photovoltaic system. A power system designed to supply usable solar power by means of photovoltaics, a method of converting solar energy into direct current electricity using semiconducting materials that create voltage or electric current in a material upon exposure to light. It consists of an arrangement of several components, including solar panels to absorb and convert sunlight into electricity, a solar inverter to change the electric current from DC to AC, as well as mounting, cabling, metering systems and other electrical accessories to set up a working system. 
Precious metal bullion. Any precious metal, including but not limited to, gold, silver, platinum, palladium, that has been put through a process of refining and is in such a state or condition that its value depends upon its precious metal content and not its form. 
Prepress preparation material. All materials used by those in the printing industry including, but not limited to, airbrush color photos, color keys, dies, engravings, light-sensitive film, light-sensitive paper, masking materials, Mylar, plates, proofing materials, tape, transparencies, and veloxes, which are used by printers in the preparation of customer specific layouts or in plates used to fill customers' printing orders, which are eventually sold to a customer, either in their original purchase form or in an altered form, and for which a sales or use tax is demonstrably collected from the printer's customer, if applicable, either separately from the printed materials or as part of the inclusive price therefor. Materials sold to a printer which are used by the printer for the printer's own purposes, and are not sold, either directly or in an altered form, to a customer, are not included within this definition. 
Preprinted newspaper supplements. Inserts, attachments or supplements circulated in newspapers that: 
(1)  Are primarily devoted to advertising; and 
(2)  The distribution, insertion, or attachment of which is commonly paid for by the advertiser. 
Prescription drugs for animals. A drug which, prior to being dispensed or delivered, is required by the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. section 301, et seq., as amended, to state at a minimum the symbol "Rx Only," and is dispensed in accordance with any order in writing, dated and signed by a licensed veterinarian specifying the animal for which the medicine or drug is offered and directions, if any, to be placed on the label. 
Prescription drugs for humans. A drug which, prior to being dispensed or delivered, is required by the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. section 301, et seq., as amended, to state at a minimum the symbol "Rx Only," and is dispensed in accordance with any written or electronic order dated and signed by a licensed practitioner of the healing arts, or given orally by a practitioner and immediately reduced to writing by the pharmacist, assistant pharmacist, or pharmacy intern, specifying the name and any required information of the patient for whom the medicine, drug or poison is offered and directions, if any, to be placed on the label. 
Price or purchase price. The aggregate value measured in currency paid or delivered or promised to be paid or delivered in consummation of a sale, without any discount from the price on account of the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, and exclusive of any direct tax imposed by the federal government or by this article, and, in the case of all retail sales involving the exchange of property, also exclusive of the fair market value of the property exchanged at the same time and place of the exchange, if: 
(1)  Such exchanged property is to be sold thereafter in the usual course of the retailer's business, or 
(2)  Such exchanged property is a vehicle and is exchanged for another vehicle and both vehicles are subject to licensing, registration, or certification under the laws of this state, including, but not limited to, vehicles operating upon public highways, off-highway recreation vehicles, watercraft, and aircraft. Any money or other consideration paid over and above the value of the exchanged property is subject to tax. 
Price or purchase price includes: 
(1)  The amount of money received or due in cash and credits. 
(2)  Property at fair market value taken in exchange but not for resale in the usual course of the retailer's business. 
(3)  Any consideration valued in money, whereby the manufacturer or someone else reimburses the retailer for part of the purchase price and other media of exchange. 
(4)  The total price charged on credit sales including finance charges which are not separately stated at the time of sale. An amount charged as interest on the unpaid balance of the purchase price is not part of the purchase price unless the amount added to the purchase price is included in the principal amount of a promissory note; except the interest or carrying charge set out separately from the unpaid balance of the purchase price on the face of the note is not part of the purchase price. An amount charged for insurance on the property sold and separately stated at the time of sale is not part of the purchase price. 
(5)  Installation, applying, remodeling or repairing the property, delivery and wheeling-in charges included in the purchase price and not separately stated. 
(6)  Transportation and other charges to effect delivery of tangible personal property to the purchaser. 
(7)  Indirect federal manufacturers' excise taxes, such as taxes on automobiles, tires and floor stock. 
(8)  The gross purchase price of articles sold after manufacturing or after having been made to order, including the gross value of all the materials used, labor and service performed and the profit thereon. 
Price or purchase price shall not include: 
(1)  Any sales or use tax imposed by the State of Colorado or by any political subdivision thereof. 
(2)  The fair market value of property exchanged if such property is to be sold thereafter in the retailers' usual course of business. This is not limited to exchanges in Colorado. Out of state trade-ins are an allowable adjustment to the purchase price. 
(3)  Discounts from the original price if such discount and the corresponding decrease in sales tax due is actually passed on to the purchaser, and the seller is not reimbursed for the discount by the manufacturer or someone else. An anticipated discount to be allowed for payment on or before a given date is not an allowable adjustment to the price in reporting gross sales. 
Private communications services. Telecommunications services furnished to a subscriber, which entitles the subscriber to exclusive or priority use of any communication channel or groups of channels, or to the exclusive or priority use of any interstate inter-communications system for the subscriber's stations. 
Prosthetic devices for animals. Any artificial limb, part, device or appliance for animal use which replaces a body part or aids or replaces a bodily function; is designed, manufactured, altered or adjusted to fit a particular patient; and is prescribed by a licensed veterinarian. Prosthetic devices include, but are not limited to, prescribed auditory, ophthalmic or ocular, cardiac, dental, or orthopedic devices or appliances, and oxygen concentrators with related accessories. 
Prosthetic devices for humans.
