CHAPTER 11. - FIREWORKS. 
 For state law as to authority of city to regulate the use of fireworks, see C.R.S. 1973, § 12-28-107. As to fireworks generally, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 12-28-101 to 12-28-109. As to fire protection generally, see Ch. 10 of this Code. As to applicability of the Fire Prevention Code to fireworks, see § 10-2. 
 
Sec. 11-1. - Definitions. 
Fireworks. Any article, device or substance prepared for the primary purpose of producing a visual or auditory sensation by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, which meets the description of fireworks as set forth in the United States Department of Transportation Hazardous Materials Regulations at title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, parts 173.88 and 173.100. 
Fireworks do not include: 
(a)  Toy caps which do not include more than 0.25 of a grain of explosive compound per cap; 
(b)  Highway flares, railroad fuses, ship distress signals, smoke candles and other emergency signaling devices; 
(c)  Education rockets and toy propellant device-type engines used in such rockets when such rockets are of nonmetallic construction and utilize replaceable engines or model cartridges containing less than two ounces of propellant and when such engines or model cartridges are designed to be ignited by electrical means; 
(d)  Explosive auto alarms as described in title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, part 173.100; 
(e)  Matches, consisting of book matches, strike-anywhere matches, or strike-on box matches as described in title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, part 173.100. 
(Ord. No. 1057 (part).)  
Sec. 11-2. - Lawful display of fireworks. 
The city manager, or his designated representative, may grant nontransferable and non-assignable permits to allow displays of fireworks for general public display. The discharge of such public fireworks displays shall be performed in accordance with the requirements of the National Fire Protection Association as stated in FPA-1123, Code for Outdoor Display of Fireworks. 
No other display of fireworks is legal within the city of Cortez. 
(Ord. No. 1057 (part).)  
Sec. 11-3. - Selling of fireworks. 
The sale of fireworks within the municipality of the city of Cortez shall be strictly prohibited. There shall be no exception to this prohibition of selling fireworks within the Cortez city limits. 
Anyone who violates any portion of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be subject to a fine in the amount of up to five hundred dollars and a jail sentence of up to six months, or both such fine and jail sentence. 
(Ord. No. 1057 (part).)  
Sec. 11-4. - Public display—Permit required. 
The chief of the fire department or his authorized agent shall have the power to grant permits within the city for supervised public displays of fireworks by the city, fair associations and other organizations and groups, and to adopt reasonable rules and regulations for the granting of such permits. Application for a permit shall be made in writing at least fifteen days in advance of the date of display. Every display shall be handled by a competent operator and shall be of such character and so located, discharged and fired as not to be hazardous to property or endanger any person. Before a permit is granted, the operator and the location and handling of the display shall be approved after investigation by the chief of the fire department of Cortez, or his authorized agent. No permit shall be transferable or assignable.  
Sec. 11-5. - Same—Disposal of unfired fireworks. 
Any fireworks that remain unfired after the display is concluded shall be immediately disposed of by the fire department in a method which is safe for the discharge of that or those particular type of fireworks.  
Sec. 11-6. - Same—Insurance requirements. 
Prior to the issuance of any permit for the displaying of fireworks, the applicant shall file with the city a liability insurance policy which shall provide insurance coverage against any and all property damages in an amount established by city council resolution, and further shall provide insurance coverage for bodily injury including death in an amount established by city council by resolution. This policy as so required shall designate the city as a named insured.  
Sec. 11-7. - Repealed by Ord. No. 717.  
Sec. 11-8. - Exemptions. 
This chapter shall not be construed to prohibit: 
(a)  Any person from offering for sale, exposing for sale, selling or having in his possession with intent to offer for sale or sell fireworks to any municipality, fair association, amusement park or other organization or group holding a permit issued as provided in this chapter or to the governing body of any county or district fair organized under the laws of the state; 
(b)  Any person from using or exploding fireworks in accordance with the provisions of any permit issued as provided in this chapter or as a part of a supervised public display at any county or district fair organized under the laws of the state; 
(c)  Any person from offering for sale, exposing for sale, selling or having in his possession with intent to offer for sale or sell any fireworks which are to be shipped directly out of the state; 
(d)  Any person from using, possessing, selling, displaying or launching model rockets. 
(Ord. No. 717, § 2.)  
Sec. 11-9. - Seizure by police. 
The police department shall seize, take and remove, at the expense of the owner, all stocks of fireworks or combustibles offered or exposed for sale, stored or held in violation of this chapter.  
Sec. 11-10. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A as now in effect or as may be amended from time to time or by revocation of the license or permit, if a license or permit has been issued to such person, in addition to penalties prescribed in section 17-16A of this Code. Each day of sale prohibited under this article shall be deemed a separate offense. Penalties under this section may be imposed consecutively. The local authorities in behalf of the secretary of state shall seize, take, remove, or cause to be removed, at the expense of the owner, all stocks of fireworks or combustibles offered or exposed for sale, stored or held in violation of this article. 
(Amended by memo 3519; amended at city request, 3-07.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 10, 9-25-12)  
CHAPTER 12. - GARBAGE, REFUSE AND WEEDS. 
 As to health and sanitation generally, see Ch. 14 of this Code. As to plumbing generally, see Ch. 21. As to sewers generally, see Ch. 23.  
Article I. - In General. 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section. 
Garbage. All offal, waste matter or vegetable matter from a kitchen, market or store and other worthless, offensive or filthy material and every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, liquid or otherwise, that attends to the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables. 
Junk is defined to be any old, used or secondhand materials of any kind including without limitation cloth, rags, clothing, paper, rubbish, bottles, rubber, iron, tires, brass, copper, or other metal furniture, refrigerators, freezers, all other appliances, parts of used motor vehicles, machines, apparatuses, contrivances and parts thereof, any used building materials, boards or other lumber, cement blocks, bricks or brick bats or other secondhand building materials or any discarded, abandoned or inoperable machinery, tractors, trucks or automobiles or any other article or thing commonly known and classified as junk. 
Rubbish. House dirt, ashes, rags, abandoned articles of clothing or similar substances. 
Trash. All bottles, tin cans, refuse, paper, fallen tree limbs and all other forms of discarded refuse. 
Weed. Any unsightly, useless, troublesome or injurious herbaceous plant, including any rank vegetable growth. 
(Ord. No. 493; Ord. No. 838.)  
Sec. 12-3. - Accumulation of weeds, trash, etc., prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner, tenant or person in possession or their agents of any lot, block or parcel of ground within the city to allow or permit weeds to grow or remain when grown, on such lot, block or parcel of ground or along any street adjoining the same and to the middle of the alley behind the same, or to allow or permit any trash, junk, rubbish or garbage upon such private property, to the middle of the alley abutting such property or along or upon any street adjoining the same. 
(Ord. No. 493.)  
Sec. 12-4. - Exceptions. 
This chapter shall not apply to garbage or waste material properly deposited in containers for removal as provided by the regulations of the city sanitation district. Nor shall it apply to any junk, as that term is herein defined, which is properly stored by the property owner in a shed or garage or other building suitable for that purpose and not exposed to public view. 
(Ord. No. 493.)  
Article II. - Removal of Garbage, Refuse and Weeds. 
 
Sec. 12-5. - Abatement—Issuance of notice—Municipal complaint. 
Whenever an informal complaint is made to the police or to any other appropriate city official or member of the city council regarding an alleged violation of this chapter or whenever any police officer or city employee observes an apparent violation of this chapter, written notice shall be served upon the person in possession or the owner of the real property upon which such violation is located. Such notice shall inform such person of the violation and direct that he take action within ten days after receipt of such notice to comply with this section or prosecution will be commenced for the violation in the municipal court. Subsequent filing in the municipal court shall not require ten days notice if the person in possession or owner has received prior notice during the calendar year. Filing in the municipal court does not preclude the city from taking such action as set forth in section 12-6 and subsequent sections of this code to collect any and all costs that it may have for abating the violation. 
The city manager or his designated city employee is authorized to give notice to any property owner, or if the same cannot be found, to any tenant in possession or any agent of the tenant or owner, if known, whose property is being kept or maintained contrary to this chapter, and such notice may be deposited by mail in the city post office, addressed to the record owner or owners, or tenant or agent, as the case may be, and if such owner cannot be found, the notice may be given by posting the property and the notice shall state that if the weeds, rubbish, trash, junk or garbage are not removed from such premises on or before ten days from the date of such notice, the same may be done by the city, and the cost thereof, including the cost of inspection and other incidental costs in connection therewith, will be assessed against such real property. The notice shall also state that the owner's failure to comply will result in misdemeanor charges being filed against the owner in the municipal court and the possible penalties therefor. 
(Ord. No. 493; Ord. No. 788; Ord. No. 1088.)  
Sec. 12-6. - Same—By city upon failure of owner. 
If the weeds, junk, trash, refuse, rubbish or garbage shall not be removed by the property owner, or the tenant, or agent in charge within ten days following notice by the city manager, such removal may be performed by the city and the cost thereof, including inspection and other incidental costs in connection therewith shall be assessed against the lot or lots or tracts of land from or abutting upon which such weeds, rubbish, trash, junk, garbage or refuse are removed, and upon the owners thereof. 
(Ord. No. 493.)  
Sec. 12-7. - Same—Assessment of costs by city. 
The cost of the removal of such weeds, trash, rubbish, refuse, junk or garbage from any lot or lots, tracts of land, or from the alley from behind or from the street and parking area adjoining any such lot or tracts of land within the corporate limits of the city shall be assessed upon the lot or lots or tracts of land from which such weeds as well as rubbish, trash, refuse or junk are removed, as well as upon the owners thereof, and such assessment shall be a lien in the several amounts assessed against each lot or tract of land until paid and shall have priority over all other liens except general taxes and prior special assessments. In case any such assessment is not paid within thirty days after the same has been certified to the director of finance by the city manager, the director of finance shall then be and is hereby authorized to certify to the county treasurer the list of all delinquent assessments, giving the name of the owner as appears of record, the number of the lot and block and the amount of assessment, the same to be properly certified by the director of finance. The county treasurer, upon the receipt of such certified list, is hereby authorized to place the same upon the tax list for the current year and collect a special assessment in the same manner as other taxes are collected, with ten percent penalty thereon; and all the laws of the state for the assessment and collection of the general taxes, including the laws for the sale of property for taxes and the redemption thereof, shall apply to and have full force and effect for the collection of all such assessments. 
(Ord. No. 630, § 2.)  
Sec. 12-8. - Same—Payment of assessment. 
The amount of such assessment may be paid to the director of finance at any time before the tax list is placed in the hands of the county treasurer, but thereafter, only to the county treasurer or his deputy. 
In the event any owner or owners desire to object to such assessment either before or after the same is certified to the county treasurer, he may, within thirty days after the receipt of such assessment notice, file a written objection thereto with the city clerk, who shall thereupon designate the next regular meeting of the city council as the date when such objection may be heard. The objector may appear in person and with counsel, if he so desires, and such hearing shall be duly recorded. The city council shall have the power to either modify, affirm or reverse such assessment after such hearing. Any owner of real estate dissatisfied with the decision of the city council shall have the right to have the decision reviewed by the county district court under Rule 106, subsection (a)(4) of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure; provided, that such petition to review is filed within the time and in the manner provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 630, § 2.)  
Sec. 12-9. - City not obligated to remove weeds, etc. 
Nothing herein contained shall be construed as placing any duty upon the city to remove weeds, trash, junk, rubbish or garbage from private property and the city, acting through its city manager or police department, may, at its option, charge an offender in the municipal court with violation of this chapter under the penalties set out in section 12-10. 
(Ord. No. 493.)  
Sec. 12-9A. - Undesirable plants. 
(a)  Undesirable plants. Russian, spotted and diffuse knapweed and leafy spurge are declared to be undesirable plants to be controlled in accordance with this section. 
(b)  Declaration of nuisance. Leafy spurge, Russian knapweed, and diffuse knapweed, spotted knapweed and diffuse knapweed, and all other plants designated "undesirable plants" by the city are declared to be a public nuisance. Such action may be taken as is available for nuisance abatement under the laws of this state and the city, and as the city council, in their sole discretion deem necessary. 
(c)  Removal of undesirable plants required by property owner. Property owners within the city shall be responsible for the elimination of undesirable plants from their property within thirty days of the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. Such removal shall be accomplished in an ecologically feasible and environmentally safe manner in accordance with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(d)  Enforcement. The city shall have the right to enter upon any premises, lands, or places, whether public or private, during reasonable business hours or upon proper notice, for the purpose of inspecting for the existence of undesirable plants, and shall have the right to propose, implement or enforce the management of undesirable plants upon such lands in accordance with the provisions of Colorado Revised Statutes section 35-5.5-109. 
(e)  Penalty. Violation of this section shall be subject to a penalty of up to ninety days in jail or a fine up to three hundred dollars, or both such fine and imprisonment in addition to any other remedies, provided herein or allowed by ordinance, law, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 754, §§ 1—5)  
Sec. 12-10. - Penalties for violation. 
Any person, whether as owner, tenant or agent in charge of private premises within the city who suffers or permits the growth of weeds, as the term is defined in section 12-1, upon the premises described in section 12-3 or along the streets adjoining such premises and to the middle of the alley in the rear thereof, or who fails to remove any trash, junk, rubbish or garbage from the same, after being notified to remove the same, as herein provided, and who fails, after such notice, to remove the same may be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. Each day that failure to remove the same continues, shall be deemed to be a separate and distinct offense and punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 493; amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 11, 9-25-12)  
CHAPTER 13. - GAS. 
 As to plumbing generally, see ch. 21 of this Code. 
 
Sec. 13-1. - Gas Code adopted. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Fuel Gas Code (IFGC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st; Printing, prepared by said International Code Council, and containing a total of one hundred seventy-seven pages. 
(b)  Three true and exact official copies of the above-described 2009 Edition of the International Fuel Gas Code (IFGC) are on file in the municipal offices of the City of Cortez, Colorado, duly certified by the mayor and attested by the city clerk, and may be examined, duplicated, or copied by any interested person during the regular business hours of said offices, all such reproduction or copying to be at the expense of the person requesting the same. 
(Ord. No. 638, § 2; Ord. No. 738, § 2; Ord. No. 962 (part).) 
(Ord. No. 1137, §§ II, III (part)) 
 Prior history: Code 1968, § 13-3-5. 
 For state law as to authority of city to adopt by reference, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 31-16-202 to 31-16-204.  
Sec. 13-2. - Gas inspector—Appointment. 
The city manager shall appoint a competent person as the gas inspector. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-1.)  
Sec. 13-3. - Same—Powers and duties enumerated. 
The gas inspector and his assistants are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to: 
(a)  Inspect and supervise the installation, construction, reconstruction and repair of all house gas piping, gas appliances, fixtures and apparatus now or hereafter to be placed in or in any manner directly attached to any building or structure within the city. The gas inspector and his assistants shall be subject to the orders and directions of the city council and they are hereby vested with full authority to enter any building or premises at any reasonable time in the discharge of their duties herein imposed. 
(b)  Receive all applications for connection, to pass on and approve or reject plans submitted, to issue permits for all plumbing work, extensions or change in location of fixtures, to sign and issue all notices, to keep a daily record of all applications received, plans approved and all other matters which may pertain thereto and to make a monthly report of such operations to the city council. 
(c)  Inspect as often as necessary all houses in the course of erection, alteration or repair and to inspect any plumbing of any character already in use which he may have reason to believe is out of repair or is imperfect. 
(d)  Give the owner or agent in charge of any building written notice of any defects in his plumbing or fixtures or of changes or repairs necessary and such owner or agent shall immediately, after such notice, make the necessary changes or repairs. If the owner or agent fails to comply with this notice, the gas inspector may order the gas franchise holder to turn off the gas and it shall not thereafter turn the gas on again until the gas inspector has certified that such defects have been repaired or removed. 
(e)  Furnish the gas franchise holder with a copy of each certificate of inspection. Such department shall not turn gas into any new, altered or repaired system of gas until such certificate has been received. 
(f)  Investigate all alleged violations of the provisions of this chapter and to file complaints when necessary. No one except an authorized representative of the gas franchise holder shall at any time turn on any valve or cock or in any way tamper or make any connection with any gas main, meter, meter connection or gas service pipe between the main and the meter. Any user, however, may turn off service in case of an emergency. 
(g)  A gas inspection charge will be established by the city council by resolution. This fee will be collected and retained by the city as compensation for services rendered by such inspector. 
(h)  Decide all controversies which may arise under this chapter, and in so doing, shall be subject to the control and direction of the city council. 
(Code 1968, §§ 13-3-1, 13-3-7.)  
Sec. 13-4. - Installation, construction, etc., license—Required; application; fee; insurance; issuance and renewal. 
Every person, before entering upon the installation, construction, reconstruction or repair of any house piping within the service area of the city natural gas system, shall be required to take out a gas plumbing license, the cost of which shall be determined by the city council by resolution. Before such license is issued, the party applying for such license shall meet the requirements set by the city council as to his knowledge of gas fittings and shall deposit with the city clerk a policy of public liability and property damage insurance, in a sum to be deter-mined by the city council by resolution, executed by a reliable insurance company to protect the franchise holder's householders and building owners against loss of life, injury or damage to property occasioned by the negligence of such contractor and all persons interested, against all costs, expenses, damages and injuries sustained by the negligence of such contractor, his agents, servants and employees, or his failure to comply ethically with the terms of this chapter in doing work made the subject matter hereof and otherwise to be in the form and executed as required by the city council. Upon approval of such insurance by the city council, the clerk shall issue to such contractor a license, which shall remain in force only so long as such contractor's insurance is in force and effect. Such insurance shall be renewed annually on the first day of January of each year as a prerequisite to the issuance of a license for such year. Such license shall be conspicuously displayed at the place of business. Applicants for a gasfitter's license who are duly licensed plumbers under the requirements of section 21-3 of this Code, are not required to pay an additional license fee for a gasfitter's license. However, proof of public liability and property damage insurance, as set forth in this section, shall be required in addition to the $1,000 bond required for plumbers' licenses as set forth in section 21-4 of this Code. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-2; Ord. No. 596, § 2.)  
Sec. 13-5. - Same—Revocation. 
The license pursuant to section 13-4 may at any time be suspended or revoked by the city council upon the recommendation of the city manager for any violation of the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-2.)  
Sec. 13-6. - Plans and specifications required—Submission; information to be specified. 
Before the construction, reconstruction, installation or repair of any gas house piping, suitable plans and specifications of all the work proposed to be done, showing clearly the sizes of pipe, kind of fittings, locations and measurements shall be made out on blanks furnished by the inspector and properly signed by the owner, his agent or other authorized representative and filed at the office of the inspector. All connections and fixtures shall be neatly drawn in the following manner. In case of new work or extension of old work, black ink shall be used. In case of old work, red ink shall be used. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-4.)  
Sec. 13-7. - Same—Approval; issuance of permit; modification; rectification of errors. 
If the plans as required by section 13-6 are approved by the inspector, he shall issue a written permit within two days after the application is filed. No change or modification of approved plans shall be permitted unless such change or modification is authorized by the owner or agent, submitted to and approved by the inspector and placed on file as in the case of original work. No infraction of rules, not specially authorized in writing by the inspector, although it may be shown on plans and has passed inspection, shall be permitted. The inspector always reserves the right to compel the gas fitter to rectify any infraction of the rules, although the work has passed inspection and a final inspection certificate issued, and the plumbers' insurance will be held for such rectification. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-4.)  
Sec. 13-8. - Permits—Issuance only to licensed plumber. 
No permit to install, construct, reconstruct or repair any gas house piping shall be issued, except to a licensed plumber or a person licensed to do such work in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-4.)  
Sec. 13-9. - Same—Property owner's responsibility. 
No property owner shall cause or permit any installation, construction, reconstruction or repair of any gas house piping in the city and its gas service territory before the person doing the work has first obtained a permit from the inspector to do so. The mere fact that such work has been done will be considered sufficient to hold and render such property owner amenable to this rule. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-3.)  
Sec. 13-10. - Certificate of inspection—Issuance upon test. 
When the system of piping and all extensions thereto has been completed and all openings firmly closed, the person installing the piping shall make the test provided above and if the piping is found tight, shall make an application for a test to the gas inspector. Upon such application the inspector or one of his assistants will inspect the piping and shall witness the test. If the piping is found tight and the work done in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, such inspector or assistant shall issue and deliver a certificate of inspection. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-6.)  
Sec. 13-11. - Same—Form. 
The certificate of inspection, as required by the preceding section, shall be substantially in a form to be prescribed by the city council. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-6.)  
Sec. 13-12. - Same—Additional installations. 
Any additional gas piping or outlets installed, after the required certificate has been issued, must be reported for inspection and tested in the same manner as pipe originally installed. 
(Code 1968, § 13-3-6.)  
CHAPTER 14. - HEALTH AND SANITATION. 
 For state law as to authority of city to make regulations and do acts necessary for the promotion of health and suppression of disease, see C.R.S. 1973, § 31-15-401(b). 
 As to animals and fowl generally, see ch. 5 of this Code. As to rabies control among dogs, see §§ 5-35 to 5-44. As to the Uniform Housing Code, see §§ 6-3, 6-4. As to civil defense and emergencies generally, see ch. 7. As to garbage, refuse and weeds generally, see ch. 12. As to plumbing generally, see ch. 21. As to public improvements generally, see ch. 22. As to water generally, see ch. 27.  
Article I. - Administration. 
 
Sec. 14-4. - Repealed September 14, 2004. 
 For charter provision as to creation of a department of health generally, see Char., art. XVIII.  
Sec. 14-5. - Duties of health officers generally. 
It shall be the duty of the health officer or officers to carry out and enforce all existing laws, codes and ordinances having for their object the preservation of life, the prevention of disease and the abatement and removal of nuisances, except as otherwise provided by ordinance or code. He shall attend to complaints of nuisances and orders relating thereto and shall perform such other services as the council may impose by ordinance, or the board of health lawfully requires of him. 
(Code 1968, § 2-4-4.)  
Article II. - Nuisances. 
 
Sec. 14-6. - Public nuisance—Defined. 
In addition to those things which are elsewhere by ordinance of the city declared to be and constitute public nuisances, it is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, or an act in the nature of a public nuisance, for any person, including, but not limited to, landlords and their agents and employees, who knowingly permits or encourages or knowingly and unreasonably fails to prevent tenants from committing the acts proscribed below within the limits of the city or to knowingly participate in, permit, abet or otherwise allow the following to occur on or within any property or structure. For purposes of this section, where an illegal activity references a section contained within the Colorado Revised Statutes (C.R.S.), the illegal activities shall have the same definition as contained within the C.R.S. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993.)  
Sec. 14-7. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter: 
Abatement. The removal, prostration, or destruction of that which causes a nuisance, whether by breaking or pulling it down, or otherwise removing, disintegrating, or effacing it. 
Board of health. Consists of a committee of three council members, with four alternates who shall also be council members, and whose duties are set out in section 14-11(c). 
Health officer. A physician who is retained by the city of Cortez on an "as needed" basis to deal with sanitation and health problems. 
Public health nuisance shall be defined as: 
1.  A situation creating infectious, contagious and pestilent disease, unsanitary toilet facilities, matters relating to sewage, drainage and surface water flow, stagnant water, existence of privy vaults, sinks, cesspools and septic tanks that may not be operating properly by reason of location, defective construction, inadequate maintenance, wear and want of repair, and improper or inadequate installation of private sewage lines from houses, buildings and other structures at the point where the same is connected to the lines of the Cortez sanitation district; 
2.  To deposit any animal or human fecal material, dead animal, or other filthy or offensive, substance upon any public street, alley, highway, park or other public place; 
3.  To corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water of any drinking fountain, spring, stream, pond or lake, to the injury or prejudice of others, or any part of the city water supply system; 
4.  To permit or suffer any slops, swill, garbage, stable droppings, feces, offal, filth, refuse, animal or vegetable matter, which are liable to become putrid or offensive or injurious to health, to remain on any premises. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993; Ord. No. 1027, §§ 2, 3.)  
Sec. 14-8. - Nuisance prohibited. 
From and after the date of the ordinance codified in this section, the owners of all lots or tracts or any addition thereto shall be, and are required to correct and abate and keep corrected and abated all those matters declared a nuisance, or a threat to public health and safety as defined in this chapter. A public nuisance as defined, or any other violation of this chapter which adversely affects the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city is strictly prohibited within the city. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993.)  
Sec. 14-9. - Authority to enter on property. 
The health officials, city manager, his designated representative or any police officer may, where reasonable cause exists with or without a warrant issued by any court or competent jurisdiction, including the municipal court of the city, enter upon any land for examination of the same to ascertain whether any such nuisance exists, and shall be free from any action or liability on account thereof. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993.)  
Sec. 14-10. - Interpretation; effect on other ordinances. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of any zoning ordinance or other ordinances now or hereafter enacted authorizing certain uses or location of property, it is the intention of the city council, and it is hereby so declared that any use, location or activity otherwise authorized by zoning ordinances or any other ordinance shall be subject to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993.)  
Sec. 14-11. - Complaints generally. 
(a)  In the event that it is determined by any individual that a nuisance within the city as described in this chapter may exist, it shall be the duty of such individual to register a complaint with the city manager of the city and the Cortez sanitation district. Upon the registering of such complaint, it shall be the duty of the city manager or his designee to investigate the subject of the complaint and determine whether it shall be necessary to issue a cease and desist order to prevent disease and cause the abatement of the nuisance described in this chapter. The city manager may direct the health officer or officers to determine if such a serious health hazard exists that a twenty-four hour notice to cease and desist order to abate or remove the determined public health nuisance should be issued. If the hazard is not considered to be of such magnitude that the abatement doesn't require a twenty-four hour cease and desist then the city manager, with the advise of the health officer, shall establish in the notice the date which the nuisance must be abated. A notice shall be addressed to the landowners of the property and shall be personally served upon them if possible and if not possible, shall be mailed to them certified mail, return receipt requested and posted upon the premises. In the event that it is determined there are tenants residing on the premises, the city shall post the premises and make reasonable efforts to personally notify the tenants. The cease and desist or abatement order shall clearly state the problem complained of, the reason why the problem must be immediately corrected, the name and address and telephone number of the person issuing the order and a notice that the order constitutes a summons to appear and give testimony before the city manager and city health officer in the event that the condition is not rectified within the time required. The notice shall also state that if the situation is not corrected in the time required the city will undertake the correction at the landowner's expense. The notice shall also advise the landowner that city water service may be terminated if deemed necessary by the city to abate the situation. Normal and customary water charges for termination and reconnection shall apply in such an event. 
(b)  If the condition is not rectified within twenty-four hours, it is the duty of the city manager with the recommendation of the health officer to make a determination whether the nuisance shall be immediately abated. If the city manager and city health officer determine that while there is a health problem that does not require twenty-four hour abatement, they will issue an order with a date certain in which the problem will be abated before the cease and desist order is issued. 
(c)  Once there has been a cease and desist order issued by the city manager, the landowner shall be given the right to appeal the same through the public health board which shall consist of three permanently appointed city council members and with the other four city council members being alternates. The affected landowner shall have twenty days from the cease and desist order to file an appeal to the board of health. The twenty-day time to appeal has no effect on the city manager and the health officer's ability to rectify the offending condition so that the health and safety of the citizens of Cortez is protected. The appeal to the board of health shall review whether the determination of the city manager and the health officer that a health hazard existed was correct and that the actions of the city manager and the health officer were reasonable and necessary. Upon the completion of the appeal the board shall make such finding of fact and law as are necessary to support their decision and the same shall become an immediate order of the board. Any person aggrieved by the action of the board may appeal to the district court under the terms and within the same time limitations of Rule 106(a)(4), Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure. Any such appeal or other civil action shall not stay any proceedings being conducted by the city to mitigate the health problem being acted on. 
(d)  The inquiry of the board shall relate directly to the determination of whether or not a health hazard exists, and the action which shall be taken to ratify the decision of the city manager or health officer, directed to whether such action was reasonable and necessary. Upon the completion of the hearing, the board shall make such findings of fact and law as are necessary to support their decision and the same shall become an immediate order of the board. Any person aggrieved by the action of the board may appeal to the district court under the terms and within the time limitations of Rule 106(a)(4) of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure. Any such appeal or other civil action shall not stay the proceedings or orders of the board unless a bond in an amount to be determined adequate by the court shall be posted and such other stipulations as the court deems reasonable to protect the health, safety and welfare of the population of the city are put in place. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993; Ord. No. 1027, §§ 4—6.)  
Sec. 14-12. - No election of remedies. 
Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, the city may take such other action, including the filing of a civil complaint to protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city and the surrounding area as it deems necessary. The remedies set forth in this chapter are cumulative. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993.)  
Sec. 14-13. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person or persons guilty of violating any of the provisions contained in this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor for each day that a violation continues. 
(b)  Whenever in this chapter or any other ordinance of the city or any section or an order, rule or regulation promulgated under the provisions of this chapter or other ordinance of the city any act is prohibited, made or declared to be unlawful, an offense, nuisance or misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, any person who shall be convicted of the violation of any such provision of this chapter or other ordinance of the city or of such orders, rules or regulations shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. For purposes of this chapter, each day of violation constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993; amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 12, 9-25-12)  
Sec. 14-14. - Authority of the city to correct and abate, assess costs and notify owner. 
The city shall have the power and authority to correct, abate and/or remove any public health nuisance herein described and to assess the whole cost thereof against the lot or lots or tracts of land or personal property upon which said nuisance is located upon the failure or refusal of any landowners to fully comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993.)  
Sec. 14-15. - Collection/lien. 
All costs assessed under this section shall constitute a lien in the several amounts against each offending lot or tract of land or personal property until paid. In the event that such assessment shall not be paid within thirty days after assessment notice to the landowner at his last known address, certified mail, return receipt requested, the city may certify said assessment to the county treasurer or to the officer of the county and in which the custody of the tax list remains at the time of said certification, to be by him, placed upon the tax rolls for the current year as provided by state law, and to be collected in the same manner as other taxes are collected, with ten percent penalty thereon to defray the cost of collection and with all other remedies available to him by law for the assessment and collection of general taxes. 
(Ord. No. 775, (part), 1993.)  
CHAPTER 14A. - LODGERS' TAX. 
 
Sec. 14A-1. - Citation. 
The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be known as and may be cited as "The Lodgers' Tax Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 537, § 1.)  
Sec. 14A-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this Chapter is to impose a tax which will be borne by transient persons using commercial lodging accommodations in the city including users of commercial campground facilities, which tax will provide revenues for advertising the community, improving its services, financing new facilities, attracting conferences, conventions and meetings of a commercial, cultural, educational, and social nature to the city, to provide for the beautification of the city, and to allocate a part thereof for administrative and clerical expenses. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 2; Ord. No. 601, § 1.)  
Sec. 14A-3. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter: 
City manager. The city manager of Cortez, or his designated representative. 
Gross taxable rent. The total amount of rent paid for lodging. 
Lodgers' tax. The tax on lodging, authorized by this chapter. 
Lodging. The transaction of furnishing rooms or other accommodations including commercial campground units by a vendor to a vendee who for rent uses, possesses or has the right to use or possess any room or rooms or other units of accommodation including trailer space units in or at a taxable premises, provided that the tax shall not be imposed on food, service, beverage, telephone, laundry or like services incidental to the furnishing of lodging or shelter and for which a separate charge is customarily made. 
Person. A corporation, firm or other body corporate, partnership, association or individual, including an executor, administrator, trustee, receiver or other representative appointed according to law and acting in a representative capacity, and as herein limited includes the United States of America, the state of Colorado, any corporation, department, instrumentality or agency of the federal government or the state government, or any political subdivision of the state. 
Taxable premises. A hotel, motel or commercial campground. 
Vendee. A natural person to whom lodgings are furnished in the exercise of the taxable service of lodging. 
Vendor. A person furnishing lodgings in the exercise of the taxable service of lodging. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 3; Ord. No. 601, § 2.)  
Sec. 14A-4. - Imposition of tax. 
There is imposed an occupancy tax of revenues of two percent of gross taxable rent for lodging paid vendors beginning November 1, l98l. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 4; Ord. No. 563, § 1.)  
Sec. 14A-5. - Exemptions. 
The tax imposed in section 14A-4 shall not apply: 
(a)  As to vendees: 
(1)  Is a resident of the taxable premises for a period of at least thirty consecutive days; or 
(2)  Enters into or has entered into a written agreement for lodgings at the taxable premises for a period of at least thirty consecutive days. 
(b)  Political subdivisions, others: 
(1)  The federal government, state of Colorado and its subdivisions, departments and institutions and the political subdivisions thereof, but only in their governmental functions and activities; 
(2)  Religious, charitable and quasi-governmental organizations only in the conduct of their regular religious, charitable and quasi-governmental capacities; provided such organization, corporation or governmental entity furnishes to the person who performs or causes to be performed the taxable service or labor sufficient evidence to demonstrate that they are entitled to said exemption. 
(c)  As to vendor: 
(1)  To clinics, hospitals or other medical facilities; 
(2)  To privately owned and operated convalescent homes of the aged, infirm, indigent or chronically ill; or 
(3)  If the taxable premises does not have at least three rooms or three other units of accommodations for lodging. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 5.)  
Sec. 14A-6. - Taxable transactions. 
It shall be a violation of this chapter for any lessee of a hotel room or motel room located in the city as defined in section 14A-3 to fail to pay, or for any lessor of such accommodation to fail to collect the tax levied by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 6.)  
Sec. 14A-7. - Licensing. 
(a)  No vendor shall engage in the business of providing lodging in the city after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter who has not first obtained a license as provided in this section. 
(b)  Applicants for a vendor's license shall submit an application to the city manager upon forms to be furnished by him prior to January 1, 1980, which forms shall at least show the name and address of the vendor together with a correct mailing address of the vendor. 
(c)  The city manager shall issue upon a form to be prescribed by him a license bearing an identifying number together with the name and address of the vendor and the manager, owner or proprietor. For each license issued a fee of ten dollars shall be paid. Such license will be invalidated and must be reissued and repurchased if there is (1) change in business name; or (2) change in business address; or (3) change in business ownership. All forms thereafter filed by the vendor with the city upon reporting and paying the tax shall bear the number of the vendor's license. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 7.)  
Sec. 14A-8. - Collection of tax—Reporting. 
Every vendor providing lodgings as provided in this chapter shall collect the tax thereon on behalf of the city and shall act as a trustee therefor. The tax shall be collected from vendees in accordance with this chapter and shall be remitted to the city on or before the twentieth day of the month succeeding the month in which the tax has been paid and collected. Each vendor shall make a report upon payment of the tax upon such form as shall be provided by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 8.)  
Sec. 14A-9. - Duty of vendor—Books and records. 
The vendor shall maintain adequate records to be maintained at vendor's offices in the city and shall be opened to the inspection of the city during reasonable hours, the same to be retained for no less than three years. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 9.)  
Sec. 14A-10. - Failure to pay tax; failure to make return; computation; penalty; notice. 
(a)  If any vendor makes a return as required by this chapter without paying the tax then due, he shall be liable for the tax and a penalty equal to ten percent thereof but not less than ten dollars penalty in addition to the tax, without notice from the city with regard thereto. Promptly thereafter, the city shall give the delinquent vendor written notice of such estimated tax penalty and interest, which notice shall be served personally or by certified mail. 
(b)  If any vendor neglects or refuses to make a return and pay the tax as required by this chapter, the city manager shall make an estimate based upon an examination of the vendor's books and records, or upon any information in its possession, of the amount of the gross taxable rents of the delinquent vendor for the period in respect to which he has failed to make return, and upon the basis of the estimated amount shall compute and assess the tax payable by the delinquent vendor, adding to the sum thus arrived at a penalty equal to ten percent thereof, but not less than ten dollars. Promptly thereafter the city shall give the delinquent vendor written notice of such estimated tax, penalty and interest, which notice shall be served personally or by certified mail. 
(c)  If payments are not made by the vendor within fifteen days of such notice, the city manager shall bring an action in law or equity in court for the collection of any amounts due, including without limitation penalties thereon, interest on the unpaid principal at a rate of not exceeding one percent per month, the cost of collection and reasonable attorney's fees incurred in connection there with. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 10.)  
Sec. 14A-11. - Administration. 
Administrative duties are assigned to the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 11.)  
Sec. 14A-13. - Budget and expenditures. 
(a)  There is created an advisory board of trustees whose duty it shall be to advise with the city manager and the city council concerning the preparation of a budget for the fund so collected and whose duties it shall be to recommend to the city manager and the city council allocation of moneys from the funds for the stated purposes hereinabove set forth. 
(b)  The advisory board of trustees shall be appointed by the city council to serve at the will of the council and shall consist of at least the following: 
(1)  One member of the city's lodgers association, one member of the county's lodgers association, and three members of the city council. 
(c)  There shall be budgeted from the moneys received from the imposition of the tax fifteen percent thereof for beautification projects within the city and five percent shall be allocated to reimburse the city for administrative and clerical expenses in administering the fund. 
(Ord. No. 537, § 13; Ord. No. 563, §§ 2—4; Ord. No. 1083.)  
CHAPTER 15. - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS GENERALLY. 
 For state law as to authority of city to license, regulate and tax businesses and occupations generally, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 31-15-301, 31-15-501. 
 As to alcoholic beverages generally, see Ch. 4 of this Code. As to the licensing of dogs, see §§ 5-31 to 5-34. As to finance and taxation generally, see Ch. 9. As to licenses required for sale of fireworks, see § 11-7. As to gas insulation, construction, etc., license, see §§ 13-4, 13-5. As to licensing of bicycles, see §§ 16-9 to 16-12. As to licensing of plumbers, see §§ 21-3 to 21-5.  
Article I. - In General. 
 
Secs. - 15-1 to 15-5. Reserved.  
Article II. - Licenses Generally. 
 
Sec. 15-6. - Required. 
The various objects, subjects, persons, corporations, trades, vocations, professions and occupations mentioned in this chapter, within the city, shall be licensed generally in accordance with this chapter and any and all persons are hereby prohibited from engaging in or carrying on any of the occupations, professions or trades in this chapter, within the city, without first having been granted therefor a license from the city as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 12-1-1.)  
Sec. 15-7. - Issuance; fee; terms and conditions. 
Licenses shall be granted to persons to engage in or carry on the occupations, professions, trades or business callings set forth by this chapter upon payment to the director of finance for the use of the city the sums set forth and established by this chapter. Any and all persons receiving any license from the city shall be subject to the Code, ordinances and regulations of the city which may be in force at the time of the issuance thereof, or which may be subsequently made and ordained by the city manager, and if any person so licensed violates any of the provisions thereof, he shall be liable to be proceeded against for any fine, forfeiture or penalty imposed thereby. In addition, such license may be revoked by the city manager and any and all license fees paid by him shall in such case by forfeited to the city. 
(Code 1968, § 12-1-2.)  
Sec. 15-8. - Signing and attestation. 
All licenses named under this chapter shall be signed by the city clerk or the duly appointed deputy city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 632, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-9. - Revocation. 
Any license may be revoked by the city manager when it appears that the licensee has not complied with the Code or ordinances regulating his business, trade, profession or calling, when he has practiced fraud, misrepresentation or deceit in obtaining such license or whenever it appears that such business, trade, profession or calling so licensed is against good morals or contrary to the general welfare of the inhabitants of the city. Any and all license fees paid by such licensee shall in such case be forfeited to the city. 
(Code 1968, § 12-1-3.)  
Sec. 15-10. - Register to be kept by city clerk. 
The city clerk shall keep a register in which shall be entered the name of each and every person licensed under this chapter, the date of the license, the purpose and place for which the license is granted, the amount paid therefor and the time such will expire or continue in force. 
(Ord. No. 632, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-11. - One year to be maximum term. 
No license shall be issued at any time for a longer period than one year and in all cases the period or term covered by the license shall be expressed therein. 
(Code 1968, § 12-1-5.)  
Sec. 15-12. - Applications generally. 
All applicants for licenses under this chapter shall file an application as required by this chapter, and shall pay an application fee, if any shall be required. Application fees shall be set by resolution of the council. 
All continuously annually licensed individuals, partnerships or corporations under this chapter shall file an updated application with the city clerk every third year of renewal of license. If an annual license is not renewed within thirty days of the expiration date of the license, a new application plus all applicable fees shall be required. Licenses for terms of less than one year shall require a new application for each license. 
(Ord. No. 632, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-13. - Partial payment prohibited. 
The director of finance is hereby prohibited from receiving any less sum at any one time than the amount required by the Code, ordinances and resolutions of the city to take out a license for the period fixed thereby. No partial payments shall be received upon any license fee or license. 
(Ord. No. 632, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-14. - Display. 
It shall be the duty of each and every person to whom a license has been issued to show such at any time during the business hours of any day to the chief of police or to any officer of the city upon request. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to show such license when requested by such authority. 
(Code 1968, § 12-1-8.)  
Sec. 15-15. - Assignability. 
No license granted under the provisions of this chapter shall be assignable without the written permission of the city manager or city council. 
(Code 1968, § 12-1-9.)

Secs. 15-16 to 15-18. - Repealed by Ord. No. 561.  
Article IV. - Billiard and Pool Tables. 
 
Secs. - 15-19 to 5-21. Repealed by Ord. No. 561.

Article V. - Reserved. 
 
Secs. - 15-31 to 15-37. Reserved.  
Article VI. - Shows, Exhibitions, Etc. 
 For state law as to authority of city to license and regulate shows, exhibitions, etc., see C.R.S. 1973, § 31-15-501(g). 
 
Sec. 15-38. - License—Required. 
No person shall exhibit, conduct or manage for gain within the city any performance, entertainment, amusement or transient business as set forth in this article or any other amusement or transient business for gain without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1968, § 12-5-4.)  
Sec. 15-39. - Same—Schedule of fees. 
The license fee or charge shall be as follows: 
Circus, menagerie or carnival, one hundred and fifty dollars per day. 
(Code 1968, §§ 12-5-1 to 12-5-3.)  
Sec. 15-40. - Same—To indicate period of validity and place of exhibition, etc. 
The city clerk in issuing any license granted under the provisions of this article shall specify therein the objects and length of time for which such is granted and the place where the circus, menagerie or carnival is to be rendered or located. 
(Ord. No. 632, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-41. - Reserved.  
Article VII. - Junk and Secondhand Dealers. 
 For state law as to authority of city to license and regulate junk and secondhand dealers, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 31-12-101(74), 31-15-301(b). 
 
Sec. 15-42. - License—Required. 
No person in the city shall engage in the business of keeping a secondhand store or a place for buying and selling secondhand goods or engage in the business of a junk dealer or collector without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1968, § 12-9-1.)  
Sec. 15-43. - Same—Application; fee; term. 
Any person desiring a license under this article shall apply to the city clerk or his agent therefor. The application shall be in writing, shall set forth the full name of the applicant and the location at which such business is to be carried on and shall be accompanied by a fee set by resolution of the city council. Such license shall, unless sooner suspended or revoked, continue in force for one year from the issuance thereof. 
(Ord. No. 632, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-44. - Same—Change of address to be noted. 
In the event that any person licensed under this article removes his place of business from the location designated in such license, such person shall immediately give notice to the city clerk and have the change noted upon such license. 
(Ord. No. 632, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-45. - Record of purchases required; access to records. 
Every person licensed under this article shall keep a book in which shall be written in ink the time of each purchase, an accurate description in English of the goods, article or thing purchased, the time of the receipt of same, the name, residence and description of the person selling the same and such book, as well as the article or articles purchased, shall, at all reasonable times, be open to the inspection of any member of the police department. 
(Code 1968, § 12-9-3.)  
Sec. 15-46. - Examination of articles and premises by police. 
The chief of police or any police officer of the city shall have the right to examine any article purchased by the licensee and may demand that any article so purchased be exhibited. Such officer shall have the right to inspect the place of business of the licensee and all articles being kept therein whenever he deems it necessary so to do. 
(Code 1968, § 12-9-8.)  
Sec. 15-47. - Purchased goods to be kept seventy-two hours. 
No person licensed under this article shall sell or remove from his place of business any goods or articles purchased by him for at least seventy-two hours. 
(Code 1968, § 12-9-4.)  
Sec. 15-48. - Prohibited purchases; hours of business. 
No person licensed under this article shall purchase any secondhand goods, articles or thing from any person who at the time is intoxicated, from any person known by him to be a thief or a receiver of stolen property or from any person whom he has reason to suspect of being such. 
No purchases shall be made between the hours of 6 o'clock P.M. and 6 o'clock A.M. 
(Code 1968, § 12-9-5.)  
Sec. 15-49. - Purchases from minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person licensed as a secondhand dealer, junkshop keeper or house-to-house secondhand buyer to purchase from, sell to or in any manner deal with any minor under the age of eighteen years; except, that such licensees may purchase old rags and waste paper from minors under the age of eighteen years. This section shall apply to employees, agents, or servants of such licensees. 
(Code 1968, § 11-1-4.)  
Sec. 15-50. - Daily reports. 
Every person licensed under this article shall make out and deliver to the chief of police of the city, every day, before the hour of 12:00 Noon, a report on forms provided by the chief of police giving an accurate account and description of each and all of the articles purchased during the preceding day, the price paid therefor, the time of purchase and the names and residences of the persons from whom such purchases were made. 
(Code 1968, § 12-9-6.)  
Article VIII. - Pawnbrokers. 
 For state law as to authority of city to license and regulate pawnbrokers, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 31-12-101(63), 31-15-301(b), 12-56-102. As to pawnbrokers generally, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 12-56-102 to 12-56-119. 
 
Sec. 15-51. - Requirements generally. 
Pursuant to C.R.S. 12-56-102, any corporation, partnership or individual wishing to operate a pawnbrokering establishment within the city shall be licensed and bonded according to the regulations set forth in this article. 
The pawnbrokering establishment shall comply with the rules and regulations as established by C.R.S. 12-56-101 et seq., as amended, in the conduct and operation of the establishment. 
(Ord. No. 629, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-52. - License—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of pawnbrokering, whether as an individual, business or in connection with any other lawful business, except as provided in and authorized by this article and without first obtaining a license from the city clerk. 
(Code 1968, § 12-7-2.)  
Sec. 15-53. - Same—Application; fee. 
All applicants for a license under this article shall apply to the city clerk and such application shall contain such pertinent information as may be required by the city clerk and upon such forms as the city clerk may prescribe. 
An application fee shall be assessed each applicant for license in an amount that shall be set by resolution of the city council. In the event that a license is denied the applicant, the applicant shall not be entitled to a refund of all or any part of the application fee. 
(Ord. No. 629, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-54. - Same—Fee; display. 
The annual license fee for carrying on the business of pawnbrokering shall be established by the city council by resolution. 
The license shall be prominently displayed at the location in which such pawnbrokering activities are being conducted. 
(Ord. No. 629, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-55. - Same—Bond required. 
The licensee or applicant shall furnish good and sufficient bond, with sureties to be approved by the city clerk, in the sum of one thousand dollars conditioned upon the faithful observance of this article and upon the safekeeping, or return, of all articles held in pledge by such pawnbroker. 
(Code 1968, § 12-7-5.)  
Sec. 15-56. - Same—Requirements generally; issuance or denial; transferability. 
All applicants for a license under this article shall satisfy the city clerk of his financial responsibility, experience, character and general fitness and if the applicant is a firm or corporation, of the officers and directors thereof. If the city clerk should find that any applicant is not of proper character, has been convicted of a felony or does not have a reputation for truth or fair dealing, then the city clerk shall have the right, upon the approval of the mayor and city council, to refuse to issue such license to such applicant. Such license shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1968, § 12-7-6.)  
Sec. 15-57. - Same—Forfeiture, revocation, suspension. 
Any person who does not comply with the rules and regulations as established by C.R.S. 12-56-101 et seq., as amended, shall forfeit the license. All penalty and penal regulations of the state as found in C.R.S. 12-56-104 shall be applicable and are in no way affected by the ordinance codified in this section. 
The city shall revoke or suspend any license issued for any violation of the requirements of application, bonding or licensing as provided by this article. Such revocation or suspension shall be for a period of time and upon such terms as the city council may determine. 
Forfeiture, revocation or suspension of any license under this article shall not entitle a pawnbroker to a refund of all or any part of the license fee. 
(Ord. No. 629, § 2.)  
Secs. 15-58 to 15-65. - Repealed by Ord. No. 629.  
Article IX. - Mobile Food Vendors.[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1220 , §§ 1—11, adopted March 28, 2017, amended article IX, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article IX, §§ 15-66—15-68.9, pertained to similar material, and derived from Ord. No. 1191 , adopted September 9, 2014. 
 
Sec. 15-66. - Definition. 
As used in this article only, "mobile food vendor" shall mean a retail food establishment that is not intended to be permanent and is a motorized wheeled vehicle or trailer attached to a motor vehicle designed and equipped to serve food and beverages, operating in either a static or transitory location and serving the public during the hours of operation authorized by this article. The sale and distribution of frozen milk, frozen dairy or ice confection products, candy, gum or other confection products shall be permitted for mobile food vendors. 
Temporary buildings for the purpose of mobile vending are not allowed in the City of Cortez. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 1, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-67. - Operations. 
The operation of a mobile food vendor is allowed provided that such operation is in compliance with all requirements and limitations contained in this article. In the event that a food vender is authorized to operate within the city pursuant to authority granted and limits found elsewhere in the code, this article shall not apply. This program may be expanded to include other types of non-food items at the discretion of city council. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 2, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-68. - Licenses. 
A Cortez business or sales tax license or transient vendor license, if applicable, proof of inspection by the Montezuma County Health Department are required as well as any land owner written permission required in section 15-68.4 and must be conspicuously displayed at all times during the operation of a mobile food vendor. Failure to display received licenses shall be a violation and punishable as set forth in section 15-68.8. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 3, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-68.1. - Hours of operation. 
Mobile food vendors may operate only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. The mobile food vendor operation and equipment must be removed from the location described in sections 15-68.4 and 15.68.5 when not open for business. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 4, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-68.2. - Zone districts. 
Mobile food vendors shall not operate in the following zone districts: CBD, central business district. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 5, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-68.3. - Operating within public right-of-way. 
Mobile food vendors may operate within the public right-of way provided they meet the following requirements: 
(a)  Mobile food vendor must be parked in a legal parking space and comply with all city and state parking restrictions; 
(b)  When operating within the public right-of-way mobile food vendor may only serve customers from an adjacent sidewalk or from the curbside of the vehicle. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 6, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-68.4. - Operating on private property. 
Mobile food vendors may operate on private property provided they meet the following requirements: 
(a)  Mobile food vendor operator must obtain prior written permission from the private property owner and must have available an original copy of such permission for inspection purposes at all times; 
(b)  Mobile food vendor must be parked on a paved surface or weather proof surface outside any designated fire lane and outside the corner visibility triangle, as that term is defined in section 5.02(j)(3) City of Cortez Land Use Code. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 7, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-68.5. - City-owned property. 
Mobile food vendors shall not operate on city property including city parking lots regardless of the zone district unless such authority to operate is provided for elsewhere in this Code or otherwise authorized by the city manager. This prohibition shall not apply to city-owned public right-of-way as provided for in section 15-68.3 of this article. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 8, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-68.6. - Littering and trash removal. 
Mobile food vendor operators must keep the sidewalks, roadways and other spaces adjacent to their business site or location clean and free of paper, peelings, trash, debris and other refuse of any kind generated from the operation of their business. All trash or debris accumulating within twenty-five feet of any mobile food vendor shall be collected by the operator and deposited in a trash container maintained by the operator in good condition and constructed of a non-corrodible and watertight material, sufficient to hold the refuse generated by the business. Such container and its contents shall be removed from the site by the operator whenever the mobile food vendor moves to another location or at the close of business. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 9, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-68.7. - Noise. 
Mobile food vendors must adhere to the provisions of Cortez City Code and Cortez Land Use Code now in effect or as may be amended from time to time regarding noisemaking devices. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 10, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 15-68.8. - Violations. 
A violation of this article shall be punishable as set forth in section 17-16A of the Cortez City Code now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
( Ord. No. 1220 , § 11, 3-28-17)  
Article X. - Merchant Police Force. 
 
Sec. 15-69. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section. 
(a)  Merchant patrol. Any person who conducts or is engaged in the business of keeping surveillance upon any premises for the purposes of ascertaining that such premises are safe and secure, such surveillance being generally for the determination of suspicious circumstances which would indicate unlawful trespass or other illegal interference with such premises, including but not limited to lights being turned out, doors locked and windows intact. 
The term "merchant patrol" shall not include an individual or a firm duly licensed by the state as a detective agency; provided, that such individual or firm is carrying on detective business and not surveillance for security and notifies the chief of police of such detective business in advance thereof. The term shall not apply to individuals employed as watchmen or security guards for the purpose of maintaining surveillance upon any premises; provided, that such surveillance activity does not involve the use of public ways. 
(b)  Individual merchant patrolman. Any employee of a merchant patrol business who is engaged in surveillance and patrol work for his employer. 
(c)  Owner. Any individual owner or general partner. If a limited partner, owner shall mean any limited partner having a financial interest of twenty percent or greater. If a corporation, owner shall mean any stockholder holding twenty percent or more of the total outstanding stock of the corporation. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 1.)  
Sec. 15-70. - License—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate and engage in the merchant patrol business as provided herein without first having obtained a license from the city. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-71. - Same—Application. 
Application for a business license to operate and engage in the business of merchant patrol within the city shall be submitted in writing to the city clerk upon such forms as may be provided by the city clerk for such purposes. The application shall set forth the following information: 
(a)  The name and address of the applicant and the owner or owners of the merchant patrol business. 
(b)  The present occupation and occupations for the preceding five years of the applicant and each owner. 
(c)  The trade or other name, if any, under which the applicant and owner conduct business or propose to conduct business. 
(d)  The training and experience of the applicant in the merchant patrol business. 
(e)  A list of names and addresses of all other businesses in which any of the persons listed in subsections (a) and (b) above have an interest. 
(f)  Any other pertinent information requested by the city clerk for the purpose of administering the provisions of this article. Applications for licenses under the provisions of this section shall require an application fee as set by the council by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 632, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-72. - Same—Affidavits required. 
There shall be submitted with the application for a merchant patrol license, individual affidavits setting out sufficient facts to prove the good character, competency and integrity of the applicant and of each owner with financial interest greater than twenty percent. Such affidavits shall list any previous police record. Each affidavit shall be supported by statements in writing from not less than five reputable citizens, each of whom shall certify that he has personally known the applicant or owner for a period of at least five years prior to the filing of the aforesaid affidavit and that he believes the applicant or owner is competent, honest and of good character and that he would recommend to the city manager that the applicant or owner be licensed to engage in the merchant patrol business. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 4.)  
Sec. 15-73. - Same—Issuance. 
The application for a merchant patrol business license as herein provided shall be forwarded to the city manager, who, if he shall find after investigation that the requirements set forth in this division have been met and that the character, competence and integrity of all those whose names which appear on the application for the license are such as to command the confidence of the public and to warrant belief that the business will operate lawfully, honestly, fairly and efficiently, shall thereupon direct the city clerk to issue and deliver to the applicant a merchant patrol business license. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 4.)  
Sec. 15-74. - Same—Fees; renewal. 
(a)  The annual license fees for persons engaged in the merchant patrol business as herein defined shall be as follows: 
(1)  Individuals ..... $10.00 per year 
(2)  Partnerships and corporations employing fewer than six agents or employees ..... 25.00 per year 
(3)  Partnerships and corporations employing six to nine agents or employees ..... 50.00 per year 
(4)  Partnerships or corporations employing ten or more agents or employees ..... 75.00 per year 
(b)  Renewal date of all licenses shall be the first day of July of each year. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 7.)  
Sec. 15-75. - Same—Insurance requirements. 
No license shall be issued until a merchant patrol business has secured such insurance as will protect itself and the city from claims of bodily injury, death or property damage which may arise from carrying on a merchant patrol business. The following insurance coverage shall be required in the name of the licensee with the city as a named insured: 
Public liability and property damage: 
Bodily injury: 
Each person ..... $100,000.00 
Each accident ..... 300,000.00 
Property damage: 
Each accident ..... $50,000.00 
Aggregate ..... 100,000.00 
Each such policy of insurance shall contain an endorsement to the effect that the insurance carrier shall notify the city clerk at least thirty days in advance of the effective date of any reduction or cancellation of the policy. The cancellation or reduction of insurance shall be the cause for automatic suspension of the license until the coverage shall be reinstated. All policies shall be kept in force for the period of the license. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 9.)  
Sec. 15-76. - Same—Indemnification of city. 
The licensee shall be responsible for any and all damage to property or injury to persons arising out of the exercise of the license and the licensee shall indemnify and save harmless the city and all of its officers, agents and employees from all suits, actions or claims of injuries received or sustained by any person or persons or property on account of the exercise of the license or of any act or omission of the licensee thereunder, his agents or employees, or on account of the failure of the licensee to observe this division and further to faithfully perform and honestly conduct all surveillance undertaken by the merchant patrol business and each individual merchant patrolman employed thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 9.)  
Sec. 15-77. - Permit—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who shall be an employee of a merchant patrol business to engage in surveillance and patrol work without first having obtained a permit from the city. No permit shall be issued to any person who has not reached the age of eighteen years. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 3.)  
Sec. 15-78. - Same—Application. 
Applications for individual merchant patrolmen permits shall be made to the city clerk upon such forms as may be provided by him for such purpose. The application shall set forth the following information: 
(a)  The name and address of the applicant, and the places of residence two years previous to moving to his present address, and the length of time he has resided in the city. 
(b)  The age of the applicant. 
(c)  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, and if so, the pertinent facts relating thereto. 
(d)  The applicant's training and experience in surveillance and patrol work. 
(e)  Whether the applicant is licensed to operate motor vehicles and whether this license has ever been revoked or suspended in any jurisdiction and if so, for what cause. 
(f)  Two character references. 
(g)  Any other pertinent information requested by the city clerk for the purpose of administering the provisions of this section concerning individual merchant patrolmen permits. 
Applications for permits under the provisions of this section shall require an application fee as set by the council by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 632, § 2.)  
Sec. 15-79. - Same—Affidavit required. 
There shall be submitted with the application an affidavit from the holder of the merchant patrol license by whom the applicant will be employed stating that he believes the applicant is competent, honest and of good character, and that the applicant is qualified to do basic surveillance work and the reasons upon which such statements are based. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 5.)  
Sec. 15-80. - Same—Issuance. 
The application for an individual merchant patrolman permit shall be forwarded to the chief of police, who, if he shall find after investigation that the requirements in this division have been met and that the character, competency and integrity of the applicant is such as to command the confidence of the public, shall thereupon issue and deliver to the applicant an individual merchant patrol man permit in the form as the city police department shall direct. 
(Ord. No. 476, § 5.)  
Sec. 15-81. - Same—Fees; renewal.
