(1)  Applications for a retail marijuana store or for the relocation of a retail marijuana store, which shall be reviewed by the city council; 
(2)  The applications described in subsection (b) when the city clerk determines grounds exist for denial per subsection 15-410(b) of this article; and 
(3)  Suspensions or revocations of any license, which shall be heard by the Cortez City Council or a hearings officer appointed by city council. 
(4)  Applications for a retail marijuana cultivation license or for the relocation of such a license; 
(5)  Applications for a retail marijuana testing facility or for the relocation of such a license; and 
(6)  All renewal applications; 
(7)  Applications to modify the ownership structure of an existing licensee. 
(b)  In the event an application is scheduled for a public hearing the city clerk shall post and publish public notice thereof not less than ten days prior to the hearing. 
(1)  Public notice given by posting shall include sign of suitable material, not less than twenty-two inches wide and twenty-six inches high, composed of letters not less than one inch in height and stating the nature of the type of license applied for, the nature of the hearing, the date of the application, the date of the hearing, the name and address of the applicant, and such other information as may be required to fully apprise the public of the nature of the application. In the case of a new license application, the sign shall contain the names and addresses of the officers, directors, or manager of the facility to be licensed. The sign shall be placed on the subject premises in a location that is conspicuous and plainly visible to the general public. 
(2)  Public notice given by publication shall contain the same information as that required for signs and shall be made in a newspaper of general circulation in Montezuma County. 
(c)  At the public hearing held pursuant to this section, any party in interest shall be allowed to present evidence and to cross-examine witnesses. 
(1)  "Party in interest" means any of the following: 
(A)  The applicant; 
(B)  An adult resident of the neighborhood under consideration; or 
(C)  The owner or manager of a business located in the neighborhood under consideration. 
(2)  The city council or a hearing officer appointed by city council may limit the presentation of evidence and cross-examination so as to prevent repetitive and cumulative evidence or examination. 
(3)  Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prevent a representative of an organized neighborhood group that encompasses part or all of the neighborhood under consideration from presenting evidence subject to this section. Such representative shall reside within the neighborhood group's geographic boundaries and shall be a member of the neighborhood group. Such representative shall not be entitled to cross-examine witnesses or seek judicial review of the licensing authority's decision. 
( Ord. No. 1192, 8-26-14 )  
Sec. 15-413. - Persons prohibited as licensees. 
(a)  No license approval provided by this article shall be issued to or held by: 
(1)  Any person whose criminal history indicates the person is not of good moral character; 
(2)  Any corporation, any of whose officers', directors', or stockholders' criminal histories indicate such person is not of good moral character; 
(3)  Any partnership, association, or company, any of whose officers', or any of whose members', criminal histories indicate such person is not of good moral character; 
(4)  Any person employing, assisted by, or financed in whole or in part by any other person whose criminal history indicates such person is not of good moral character or who is not a resident of Colorado; 
(5)  Any cooperative association, any of whose officers', directors', or stockholders' or members' criminal histories indicate that such person is not of good moral character; 
(6)  A person under twenty-one years of age; 
(7)  A person approved pursuant to this article who, during a period of licensure or approval, or who, at the time of application, has failed to: 
(A)  Provide surety bond or file any tax return with a taxing agency relating to the operation of a retail marijuana establishment; 
(B)  Pay any taxes, interest, or penalties due to a taxing agency relating to the operation of a retail marijuana establishment. 
(8)  A person who has discharged a sentence in the five years immediately preceding the application date for a conviction of a felony or a person who has discharged a sentence for a conviction of a felony pursuant to any state or federal law regarding the possession, distribution, manufacturing, cultivation, or use of a controlled substance in the ten years immediately preceding his or her application date or five years from the effective date of HB 13-17, enacted in 2013, whichever is longer; except that the local licensing authority may grant a license to a person if the person has a state felony conviction based on possession or use of marijuana or marijuana concentrate that would not be a felony if the person were convicted of the offense on the date he or she applied for licensure; 
(9)  A person who employs another person at a retail marijuana establishment who has not submitted fingerprints for a criminal history record check or whose criminal record history check reveals that the person is ineligible; 
(10)  A sheriff, deputy sheriff, police officer, or prosecuting officer, or an officer or employee of the state licensing authority or a local licensing authority; 
(11)  A person for a location that is currently licensed as a retail food establishment or wholesale food establishment; or 
(12)  A person who has not been a resident of Colorado for at least two years prior to the date of the person's application. 
(b)  In making a determination as to character or when considering the conviction of a crime, the local licensing authority shall be governed by the provisions of C.R.S. § 24-5-101. 
(c)  The focus of the inquiry into the character of any person associated with the operation of a retail marijuana business shall be whether the person's character is such that violations of state law or city ordinances pertaining to the possession and distribution of marijuana and/or the operation of retail marijuana establishments would be likely to result if a license were granted. 
( Ord. No. 1192, 8-26-14 )  
Sec. 15-414. - Issuance or denial of approval. 
(a)  In determining whether to issue an approval under this article, the city council may consider the following: 
(1)  Whether the application is complete and signed by the applicant; 
(2)  Whether the applicant has paid the application fee; 
(3)  Whether the application complies with all the requirements of this article, the Colorado Retail Marijuana Code, and rules promulgated by the state licensing authority; 
(4)  Whether the application contains any material misrepresentations; 
(5)  Whether the proposed retail marijuana establishment complies with applicable zoning regulations. The local licensing authority shall make specific findings of fact with respect to whether the building in which the proposed medical marijuana business will be located conforms to the distance requirements set forth in the applicable use criteria; 
(6)  The facts and evidence adduced as a result of its investigation as well as any other facts and any other pertinent matters affecting the qualifications of the applicant for the conduct of the type of business proposed; 
(7)  Any other facts pertinent to the type of license approval for which application has been made, including the number, type, and availability of retail marijuana outlets located in or near the premises under consideration; and 
(8)  For applications to approve any retail marijuana store in the same location where any medical marijuana center or retail marijuana store is or has previously been licensed, evidence that the licensed premises have been previously operated in a manner that adversely affects the public health, welfare or safety of the immediate neighborhood in which the establishment is located. 
(9)  Is the applicant current in payment to the city of Cortez, all taxes, fees, sales tax, assessments or charges under section 15-409(d) above. 
(b)  The city council may deny the approval application for good cause as defined in the Colorado Retail Marijuana Code. 
(c)  The city council may impose reasonable conditions upon any license approval issued pursuant to this article. 
(d)  Retail cultivation approvals shall not be subject to this limit if the licensee holds or has successfully applied for a retail marijuana store license. In the case of multiple applications for an available license, the city clerk shall publish the availability of the license and assign priority by lot to each completed application received within forty-five days of the date of publication. 
(e)  No person shall own, operate, manage, control, or hold any interest in more than one retail sales marijuana establishment in the city. 
(f)  Within thirty days after the public hearing or completion of the application investigation, the local licensing authority shall issue its decision approving or denying the application. The decision shall be in writing, shall state the reasons for the decision, and a copy of the decision shall be mailed by certified mail to the applicant at the address shown on the application. 
(g)  The city clerk shall not issue certificate of approval nor notify the state licensing authority of an approval until the building in which the business to be conducted has been issued a certificate of occupancy and is in compliance with the architects drawing, plot plan, and detailed sketch for the interior of the building submitted with the application and all state and city laws, rules and regulations now in effect or as may be adopted or amended from time to time. 
(h)  After approval, the local licensing authority shall notify the state licensing authority of such approval and issue to the successful applicant a certificate of local approval. 
( Ord. No. 1192, 8-26-14 )  
Sec. 15-415. - Contents and display of approval. 
The approved licensee shall post the certificate approval in a conspicuous location on the premises. A retail marijuana establishment approval shall contain the following information: 
(a)  Type of approval; 
(b)  The name of the licensee; 
(c)  The date of issuance of the approval; 
(d)  The street address at which the licensee is authorized to operate the retail marijuana establishment; 
(e)  Any conditions of approval imposed upon the license by the city council; 
(f)  The date of expiration of the approval; and 
(g)  The signature of the city clerk. 
( Ord. No. 1192, 8-26-14 )  
Sec. 15-416. - Transfer/changes in ownership structure. 
(a)  License approvals held by natural persons may not be transferred. In the event a natural person or persons holding a license sell the associated retail marijuana establishment, the purchaser shall be entitled to apply for a new retail marijuana establishment license for the purchased business notwithstanding the provisions of subsection 15-414(f) If the proposed sale or conveyance of a partial interest in the retail marijuana establishment to a person who previously did not own ten percent or more of the retail marijuana establishment will, after the sale, result in that person owning ten percent or more of the retail marijuana establishment, the licensee shall apply for a change in ownership structure, which the local licensing authority shall process as a new license approval application by the new owner. 
(b)  License approvals held by partnerships, corporations, limited liability companies, or other business entities are not transferable and terminate automatically upon dissolution of the entity. If the proposed sale or conveyance of any interest in the entity to a person who previously did not own ten percent or more of the business will, after the sale, result in the person owning ten percent or more of the entity, the licensee shall apply for a change in ownership structure, which the local licensing authority shall process as a new license approval application by the new owner. 
(c)  Changes in ownership structure that do not result in a person increasing that person's interest from less than ten percent to more than ten percent shall be reported to the local licensing authority and may be approved administratively by the city clerk. 
( Ord. No. 1192, 8-26-14 )  
Sec. 15-417. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  A license approval issued pursuant to this article may be suspended or revoked by the city council or a hearing officer appointed by the city council after a hearing for the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or a false statement of material fact contained in the permit application; 
(2)  Any violation of city ordinance or state law pertaining to the operation of a retail marijuana establishment or a medical marijuana business, including regulations adopted by the state licensing authority, for the possession or distribution of marijuana; 
(3)  A violation of any of the terms and conditions of the license; 
(4)  A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  In deciding whether a license approval should be suspended or revoked, and in deciding whether to impose conditions in the event of a suspension the local licensing authority shall consider: 
(1)  The nature and severity of the violation; 
(2)  Corrective action, if any, taken by the licensee; 
(3)  Prior violation(s), if any, by the licensee; 
(4)  The likelihood of recurrence of the violation; 
(5)  The circumstances of the violation; 
(6)  Whether the violation was willful; and 
(7)  Previous sanctions, if any, imposed on the licensee. 
(c)  The provisions of Part 6 of the Colorado Retail Marijuana Code shall govern proceedings for the suspension or revocation of a license approval issued hereunder. 
(d)  The city council or the hearings officer may impose a fine in lieu of a suspension in accordance with the provisions of the Colorado Retail Marijuana Code. 
( Ord. No. 1192, 8-26-14 )  
Sec. 15-418. - Change of location. 
(a)  A licensee may move his or her permanent location to another location in the city, but it shall be unlawful to cultivate, manufacture, distribute, or sell retail marijuana at any such place until permission to do so is granted by the city and the state licensing authority. 
(b)  In permitting a change of location, the city council shall consider all reasonable restrictions that are or may be placed on the new location and any such new location shall comply with all requirements of this article, the city of Cortez Land Use Code, the Colorado Retail Marijuana Code, and rules promulgated by the state licensing authority. 
(c)  The local licensing authority shall not authorize a change of location until the applicant produces a license issued and granted by the state licensing authority covering the period for which the change of location is sought. 
( Ord. No. 1192, 8-26-14 )  
Sec. 15-419. - Operational requirements. 
Retail marijuana establishments shall comply with the following operational requirements: 
(a)  Retail marijuana establishments shall provide customers with contact information for local drug abuse treatment centers as well as educational materials regarding the hazards of substance abuse. 
(b)  Retail marijuana stores shall operate only during the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. 
(c)  Retail marijuana establishments shall provide adequate security on the business premises, which shall include the following: 
(1)  Twenty-four hour security surveillance cameras to facilitate the investigation of crimes and to include video and audio capabilities, with a redundant power supply and circuitry to monitor entrances/exits and parking lot along with the interior and exterior of the premises. Security video and audio shall be preserved for forty five days. The owner shall provide segments of surveillance footage upon request to law enforcement officers investigating crimes committed against the establishment or its customers. The owner shall be required to produce surveillance footage disclosing the identity of customers and shall not edit surveillance footage to protect customer privacy. The resolution of these color cameras shall be of sufficient quality to allow for the identification of the subject's facial features, in all lighting conditions, in the event of a crime; 
(2)  A burglar fire alarm system that is professionally monitored and maintained in good working order; a locking safe permanently affixed to the premises suitable for storage of inventory and cash, all to be stored during non-business hours. Live plants being cultivated shall not be deemed inventory requiring storage in a locked safe; 
(3)  Exterior lighting that illuminates the exterior walls of the establishment and that complies with the lighting code set forth in this city of Cortez Land Use Code. 
(d)  No firearms, knives, or other weapons shall be permitted in a retail marijuana store except those carried by sworn peace officers. 
(e)  Marijuana shall not be consumed or used on the premises of a retail marijuana store and it shall be unlawful for a retail marijuana store licensee to allow marijuana to be consumed upon its licensed premises. In the case of a retail marijuana store located in a structure with a legal secondary unit or other legal dwelling unit, the dwelling unit shall not be considered part of the retail marijuana store premises if access to the dwelling unit is prohibited to the retail marijuana store customers. 
(f)  Retail marijuana establishments shall comply with the provisions of the Colorado Retail Marijuana Code, rules promulgated by the state licensing authority, and with any other relevant Colorado statute or administrative regulation. 
(g)  Retail marijuana stores shall produce such quantities of product sold as required by the applicable state statutes, rules and regulations regarding cultivation of product sold now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(h)  The chief of police or other appropriate city department head shall report to the city clerk all violations of this article and other applicable state and local laws and the city clerk shall maintain a record for each license issued and record the reports of the violations there. 
(i)  Immediately upon receipt from the state licensing authority the licensee, owner, or manager shall provide the city clerk with a photo copy of any and all state "badges" or other form of official identification issued to owners, operators, managers or employees of any retail marijuana establishment in the city of Cortez. 
( Ord. No. 1192, 8-26-14 ; Ord. No. 1194, 9-23-14 ; Ord. No. 1215 , 7-26-16)  
Sec. 15-420. - Penalty. 
A violation of this article shall be punishable as set forth in section 17-16A Cortez City Code now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
( Ord. No. 1192, 8-26-14 )  
CHAPTER 15A. - MOBILE HOMES. 
 As to licensing of mobile home parks, see §§ 15-87 to 15-90. 
 As to Fire Code and fire prevention generally, see Ch. 10. 
 As to Building Code and standards and buildings generally, see Ch. 6.  
Article I. - In General. 
 
Secs. 15A-1 to 15A-5. - Reserved.  
Article II. - Regulations and Minimum Standards for Location of Mobile Homes. 
 
Sec. 15A-6. - On single sites. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to locate a mobile home on any single lot for the purpose of occupancy without first applying for and securing a building permit from the city. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 1.)  
Sec. 15A-7. - Blocking diagram required. 
The request for a building permit shall be accompanied by a blocking diagram supplied by the manufacturer of the mobile home for the model proposed for location. The city may accept, in lieu of such blocking diagram, a complete stabilizing and tie-down system designed by a registered engineer or architect. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 2.)  
Sec. 15A-8. - Building permit for construction required. 
The city shall issue a building permit for the construction of foundations or stabilizing system in accordance with all of the city requirements regarding the issuance of building permits. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 3.)  
Sec. 15A-9. - Conformance to Uniform Building Code; other requirements. 
(a)  In the event a permanent foundation is to be constructed, the foundation shall meet all the requirements of the Uniform Building Code as well as providing additional supports for the carrying frame as recommended by the unit's manufacturer. 
(b)  Stabilizing devices or piers shall be installed and inspected in accordance with the support system recommended by the manufacturer or designed by the engineer or architect. 
(c)  Ground anchors shall be installed and inspected following the application for and securing of a permit therefor. Unless the entire tie-down system, including ground anchors, is designed by a professional engineer or architect, ground anchors shall be not more than twenty-four feet on centers beginning from the front line of the mobile home, and not more than six feet open-end spacing at the rear line of the mobile home unless additional tie-downs are installed. Ground anchors for diagonal ties shall be provided in conjunction with each vertical tie-down. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 4.)  
Sec. 15A-10. - Exemptions from Uniform Building Code. 
Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, from and after April 8, 1975 any mobile home being hereafter erected upon a foundation within the designated R-4 zones of the city and which mobile home bears a certification insignia issued by the state, shall be deemed to be exempt from the minimum requirements of the Uniform Building Code of this city and such mobile home shall be approved by the city building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 5.)  
Sec. 15A-11. - Minimum size. 
No mobile home installed in accordance with this section shall have a width of less than ten feet nor a length of less than fifty feet. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 6.)  
Sec. 15A-12. - Skirting required. 
Mobile home units not placed on permanent foundations such that all of the undercarriage and running gear are unexposed shall be skirted in a manner to so conceal said undercarriage and running gear. A permit shall be applied for and issued by the city for such skirting. Installation shall be inspected and approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 7.)  
Sec. 15A-13. - Utility connections. 
Utility connections for water, sanitary sewer, electricity and natural gas shall be provided by no lesser standards than those stated in the preceding sections and shall be inspected and approved by the city or other appropriate agency having jurisdiction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 8.)  
Sec. 15A-14. - Certificate of occupancy required. 
Prior to the occupancy of any mobile home on a single lot the city shall issue a certificate of occupancy which indicates that all of the requirements of the city have been met. All of the procedural requirements of the city regarding certificate of occupancy shall be complied with. 
(Ord. No. 470, § 9.)  
Article III. - Standards for Mobile Home Parks. 
 
Sec. 15A-15. - Inspection. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city manager to cause to be made with the assistance of the building inspector, police, fire and health department and the owner or his authorized agent, an inspection of each park, including all mobile homes. 
(b)  It shall be the direct responsibility of the city manager or his agent to enforce this ordinance and to issue a summons directly to the offending party. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 2.)  
Sec. 15A-16. - Community facilities to conform to construction regulations. 
Every building or structure within a mobile home park shall be constructed in accordance with the applicable provisions of all city building and construction regulations and codes as set out in this Code or any other ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 3.)  
Sec. 15A-17. - Lot standards. 
(a)  Utility connections serving the mobile home shall be located to properly service the mobile home erected on the stand. 
(b)  Mobile home utility service shall be connected to the mobile home park system by means of approved materials. No rigid utility connections shall be made. 
(c)  No mobile home shall be permanently attached to a foundation. Stabilizing devices or piers may be used. Where specified by the manufacturer, they shall be installed in accordance with his instructions. 
(d)  No combustible material shall be stored under any mobile home. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 4.)  
Sec. 15A-18. - Plumbing standards. 
(a)  Connections shall be made to the city public water supply and be made available to every lot within the park. 
(b)  All new water piping, fixtures and other equipment shall be constructed and all existing piping fixtures and other equipment shall be maintained in accordance with local regulations and requirements and shall be of a type, size and in location approved by the city. 
(c)  A shutoff valve located below frost line shall be provided on the water riser pipe of each mobile home lot. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 5.)  
Sec. 15A-19. - Sewage disposal standards. 
(a)  Connections shall be made to the city sewage collection system and be available to every lot within the park. 
(b)  All new sewage collection lines shall be installed in accordance with all applicable city standards and requirements as set out in this Code or any other ordinance of the city. 
(c)  The sewage collection inlet for each lot shall have a nominal inside diameter of at least three inches. 
(d)  The lateral line from the mobile home discharge to the sewage collection line shall have a slope of at least one-fourth inch per foot. All joints shall be secure and watertight, and the pipe shall be firmly supported to prevent deflection and movement. 
(e)  All materials used for sewer connections between a mobile home and the inlet shall be semi-rigid, corrosive resistant, nonabsorbent and durable. The inner surface shall be smooth. 
(f)  Provisions shall be made for plugging the sewage collection inlet with a tamperproof fitting when a mobile home does not occupy the lot. Surface drainage shall be diverted away from the inlet. The rim of the inlet shall extend not more than four inches above ground elevation. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 6.)  
Sec. 15A-20. - Electrical standards. 
(a)  All new electrical installations in mobile home parks shall be designed and constructed in accordance with state law, this Code or any other ordinance of the city. 
(b)  All existing electrical systems shall be maintained in a safe condition. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 7.)  
Sec. 15A-21. - Natural or liquefied petroleum gas system standards. 
(a)  Gas equipment and installations within a mobile home park shall be designed in accordance with this Code or any other ordinance of the city. 
(b)  All new gas piping installed below ground shall have a minimum cover of eighteen inches. 
(c)  Each mobile home lot shall have an approved gas shutoff valve installed upstream of the mobile home lot gas outlet. Such valve shall be readily accessible and the location clearly labeled. Whenever the mobile home lot outlet is not in use the outlet shall be equipped with an approved cap or plug to prevent accidental discharge of gas. 
(d)  Each new installation of a mobile home utilizing gas shall be connected to the mobile home lot outlet by an approved three-fourths inch mobile home connection not more than six feet in length. Approved pipe and fittings may be used between the flexible connector and the mobile home lot gas outlet when the distance between the mobile home gas service connection exceeds that required to make a safe installation with only a mobile home connector. 
(e)  All gas outlets, risers, regulators, meters, valves or other exposed equipment shall be protected from mechanical damage by vehicles or other causes. 
(f)  The storage, handling, and use of liquefied petroleum gas shall be in conformity with N.F.P.A. Manual d58. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 8.)  
Sec. 15A-22. - Fire safety standards. 
(a)  The arrangements of lots and streets and roads of each mobile home park shall meet the approval of the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  Fire hydrants shall be provided, installed and connected to the public water system within approximately five hundred feet of all mobile home lots. 
(c)  There shall be no burning of rubbish or trash within the boundaries of any mobile home park. 
(d)  Care shall be taken to maintain the park free of dry brush, leaves, and weeds which might communicate fires between mobile homes and other buildings in the park. 
(e)  Permanent public buildings shall be provided with portable fire extinguishers in accordance with all city regulations. 
(f)  The connecting and disconnecting of all public utility services to mobile homes shall be made by qualified or authorized persons as determined by the city. 
(g)  Owners shall not place empty liquefied petroleum gas containers under their mobile homes. Empty containers shall be left in place if there is more than one container. If the mobile home's liquefied petroleum gas supply is limited to one container and a replacement has been secured, any empty container shall be stored in the area designated for such storage. 
(h)  Operators of vehicular equipment shall observe all posted signs and shall keep all designated fire lanes and access to fire hydrants open at all times. 
(i)  Heat tapes shall be of a type approved by a recognized testing laboratory. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 10.)  
Sec. 15A-23. - Removal of wheels from mobile homes in parks. 
The removal of permanent running gear, including hubs and axles, from any mobile home located in a mobile home park is hereby prohibited except temporarily for the purpose of repairs. The removal of rubber tires and wheels for the protection against decay shall be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 11.)  
Sec. 15A-24. - Maintenance. 
(a)  All mobile home lots, mobile home stands and utilities existing and new shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition. All buildings, utilities or structures which were required to have been erected or installed pursuant to any previous building code or ordinance relating to this use shall be maintained in good working order. The owner shall be responsible for the maintenance of all buildings, structures and utilities. 
(b)  No mobile home or travel trailer shall be parked or permitted to stand upon any public street, highway, road, alley or other such right-of-way for more than twenty-four hours. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 12.)  
Sec. 15A-25. - Penalties. 
In addition to all other penalties herein provided, any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter or suffering or permitting the same to be violated shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. The imposition of one penalty for any one violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and each day thereafter that prohibitive conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate and chargeable offense. 
(Ord. No. 482, § 13; amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 15, 9-25-12)  
CHAPTER 15B. - MECHANICAL CODE. 
 
Sec. 15B-1. - Mechanical Code—Adopted. 
There is hereby adopted by reference, as though the same were fully printed and set forth herein, the International Mechanical Code (IMC), 2009 Edition, Copyright 2009, 1st Printing, prepared by said International Code Council, and containing a total of one hundred forty-five pages. 
(Ord. No. 585, § 2; Ord. No. 636, § 2; Ord. No. 701, § 2; Ord. No. 854, § 2.) 
(Ord. No. 1137, § II (part))  
Sec. 15B-2. - Same—Copies on file. 
Three true and exact official copies of the above-described 2009 Edition of the International Mechanical Code (IMC) are on file in the municipal offices of the City of Cortez, Colorado, duly certified by the mayor and attested by the city clerk, and may be examined, duplicated, or copied by any interested person during the regular business hours of said offices, all such reproduction or copying to be at the expense of the person requesting the same. 
(Ord. No. 585, § 3; Ord. No. 636, § 3; Ord. No. 701, § 3; Ord. No. 854, § 3.) 
(Ord. No. 1137, § III (part))  
Article I. - In General. 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Model Traffic Code—Adoption. 
Pursuant to parts 1 and 2 of article 16 of title 31, C.R.S., as amended and part 4 of article 15 of title 30, C.R.S., and article III, section 6, of the Cortez City Charter, there is hereby adopted by reference articles I and II, inclusive, of the 2003 Edition of the "Model Traffic Code for Colorado Municipalities," promulgated and published as such by the Colorado Department of Transportation, Staff Traffic and Safety Projects Branch, 4201 East Arkansas Avenue, EP 700, Denver, CO 80222. The subject matter of the Model Traffic Code relates primarily to comprehensive traffic control regulations for the city. The purposes of this article and the Code adopted herein is to provide a system of traffic regulations consistent with state law and generally conforming to similar regulations throughout the state and the nation. Three copies of the Model Traffic Code adopted herein are now filed in the office of the clerk of the city of Cortez, Colorado, and may be inspected during regular business hours. The summary of this article is deemed sufficient by the city council in accordance with article III, section 6 of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 817, § 1: Ord. No. 990, § 1.) 
 For state law as to authority of city to adopt Model Traffic Code by reference, see CRSA § 42-4-110.  
Sec. 16-2. - Model Traffic Code—Deletions. 
The 2003 Edition of the Model Traffic Code is adopted as if set out at length. No articles and/or sections are declared to be inapplicable to the city of Cortez. 
(Ord. No. 817, § 2: Ord. No. 990, § 2.)  
Sec. 16-3. - Model Traffic Code—Additions or modifications. 
The adopted Code is not subject to any additions or modifications. 
 Section 1212 Sales to the Public on City Streets, Alleys—Prohibited: 
 No person may, except as otherwise provided in the Cortez Municipal Code, sell any personal property or goods or services on the streets, alleys, sidewalks or other City property located in or owned by the City of Cortez, unless approved by the City Council or City Manager. 
 Penalty: a violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of up to $500.00 or a jail sentence of up to 180 days or both a fine and a jail sentence. 
 Section 102 Definitions, shall be amended to add the following provisions: 
 (90)—"Toy Vehicles" whether or not home built by the user that has wheels with an outside diameter of not more than 14 inches and is not designed, approved, or intended for use on public roadways or highways. Toy vehicles includes but is not limited to gas powered or electric powered vehicles commonly known as minibikes, pocket bikes, kamikazie boards, mopeds, and stand up scooters. 
 (91) — "Off highway vehicles" means any self-propelled vehicle, which is designed to travel on wheels or tracks in contact with the ground which is designed primarily for use off of the public highways and which is generally and commonly used to transport persons for recreational purposes. Off highway vehicle does not include the following: 
 a. vehicles designed and used primarily for travel on, over, or in the water; 
 b. snowmobiles; 
 c. military vehicles; 
 d. golf carts; 
 e. vehicles designed and used to carry disabled persons; 
 f. vehicles designed and used specifically for agricultural, logging or mineral purposes; or 
 g. vehicles registered pursuant to Colorado State Statute, Article 3, Title 42. 
 Section 220 Motorized bicycles, Motor Driven Cycles, Riding Equipment, Department Control, Use and Operation of the Model Traffic Code shall be amended to add the following: 
 (3.) All motorized bicycles shall be registered pursuant to Colorado State Statute and insured as required by this code and Colorado State Statute. 
 Section 109 Motorized bicycles, animals, skis, skates, toy vehicles, and all terrain recreational vehicles on highways of the Model Traffic Code shall be amended to add the following: 
 (13.) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle, which is not registered or insured on the streets, alleys, sidewalks and public ways of the City of Cortez. 
 Penalty Clause 
 Any violation of this section shall result in the imposition of fines, jail time or other sentence as set forth in section 17-16a Cortez Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 817, § 3: Ord. No. 990, § 3; Ord. No. 1095; Ord. No. 1121.)  
Sec. 16-4. - Model Traffic Code—Penalties. 
The following penalties, herewith set forth in full, shall apply to this article: 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions adopted in this article. 
(b)  Every person convicted of a violation of any provision adopted in this article shall be punished by a fine not exceeding four hundred ninety-nine dollars except that the offenses listed below in (c) may be punished by a fine and imprisonment as set forth in section 17-16A Cortez City Code. 
(c)  The following Model Traffic Code offenses now in effect or as may be amended from time to time shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A now in effect or as may be amended from time to time: 
Model Traffic Code section 1903(1)(a), stopping for school bus. 
Model Traffic Code section 1101(12)(b), speeding in excess of twenty-five miles per hour of the reasonable and prudent speed. 
Model Traffic Code section 1105, speed contests. 
Model Traffic Code section 1413, eluding, attempting to elude a police officer. 
Any other offense not listed above with a point assessment by the Colorado Department of Revenue of greater than six points. 
(All Model Traffic Code sections listed are as currently stated or as may be amended from time to time.) 
(Ord. No. 817, § 4: Ord. No. 990, § 4.) 
( Ord. No. 1200, 5-26-15 )  
Sec. 16-5. - Model Traffic Code—Application. 
This article shall apply to every street, alley, sidewalk area, driveway, park, and to every other public way or public place or public parking area, either within or outside the corporate limits of this municipality, the use of which this city has jurisdiction and authority to regulate. The provisions of sections 1401 through 1407.5 and 1409 through 1415, respectively concerning reckless driving — penalty, careless driving — penalty, following fire apparatus prohibited, crossing fire hose, riding in trailers, foreign matter on highway prohibited, spilling loads on highways prohibited, splash guards, when required, compulsory insurance — penalty, use of earphones while driving, operation of bicycles and other human-powered vehicles, eluding or attempting to elude a police officer, moving construction-related equipment, and use of dyed fuel on highways prohibited, shall apply not only to the public places and ways but also throughout this municipality. 
(Ord. No. 817, § 5: Ord. No. 990, § 5.)  
Article II. - Parking. 
 
Sec. 16-6. - Repealed by Ord. No. 860.  
Sec. 16-7. - Limitation on parking. 
(a)  The city of Cortez shall from time to time establish parking areas within the city in which the time and/or place in which one may park is limited or restricted. The city council shall establish such time periods for parking as they deem fit and reasonable. 
(b)  Such limitation as to time or place shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  All such areas which are regulated in accordance with this section as to length of time and/or place shall be clearly marked with signs advising the restriction on parking. 
(d)  The fine for violation of this article shall be eight dollars for each and every violation. If the fine is not paid within five days from the date of the notice of parking violation the fine shall be fifteen dollars. The registered owner and/or owners of a vehicle improperly parked shall be responsible for any fine assessed for improper parking of the vehicle. 
(e)  The City of Cortez fire marshal as well as the Cortez police department and designees of the Cortez police chief are hereby authorized to issue parking tickets for parking in fire lanes properly marked and signed. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1.) 
(Ord. No. 1128)  
Sec. 16-8. - Prohibition against parking and occupying a recreational vehicle or park trailer on city streets, alleys and other city property. 
(a)  No person shall park and occupy any recreational vehicle or park trailer as defined in the City of Cortez Land Use Code at section 2.02, on any City of Cortez street, alley or other city property including but not limited to parking lots, vacant land, etc. 
It shall be a rebuttable presumption that the recreational vehicle or park trailer is parked and occupied if the recreational vehicle or park trailer is connected to any power source, water source, or sewer discharge location on adjacent real property while parked on a city street or any other signs of occupation that the recreational vehicle or park trailer is parked and in use is observed. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of up to four hundred ninety nine dollars. A violation of this section may be ticketed as a parking ticket with a fine of four hundred ninety nine dollars. 
(c)  In addition to the penalty specified above, the municipal judge may order suspended fines to insure compliance and may also order the removal of said recreational vehicle or park trailer from city streets, alleys and other city property by city staff. 
(d)  This section shall be enforceable by the Cortez Police Department, Cortez Code Enforcement Officers, or the City of Cortez Planning and Building Department or any other city employee authorized by the city manager. 
(e)  Each day a violation or non-compliance exists shall be and constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1179, 6-11-13; Ord. No. 1230 , 9-26-17)  
Article III. - Bicycles. 
 For state law provision relating to bicycles, see CRSA §§ 42-4-109, 42-4-220, 42-4-224(3). 
 
Sec. 16-9. - License—Required. 
No person, who resides within the city, shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, unless such bicycle has been licensed and a license plate attached thereto. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-1.)  
Sec. 16-10. - Same—Application. 
Application for every bicycle license and license plate shall be made to the city police department. There shall be no charge for the license. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-2.)  
Sec. 16-11. - Same—Issuance. 
The chief of police upon receipt of a proper application is authorized to issue a bicycle license which shall be effective upon issuance. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-3.)  
Sec. 16-12. - Same—Records to be kept. 
The chief of police shall keep a record of the number of each license, the date issued, the name and address of the person to whom issued and the number of the frame of the bicycle for which issued. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-3.)  
Sec. 16-13. - License plates or decals—Issuance. 
The chief of police upon issuing a bicycle license shall also issue a license plate or decal bearing the license number assigned to the bicycle and the name of this city. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-4.)  
Sec. 16-14. - Same—Attachment. 
The chief of police shall require such license plate or decal to be firmly attached to the rear mudguard or frame of the bicycle for which such license was issued in such position as to be plainly visible from the rear. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-4.)  
Sec. 16-15. - Same—Removal prohibited; exceptions. 
No person shall remove a license plate or decal from a bicycle except upon a transfer of ownership or in the event the bicycle is dismantled and no longer operated upon any street in this city. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-4.)  
Sec. 16-16. - Transfer of ownership generally. 
Upon the sale or other transfer of a licensed bicycle, the licensee shall remove the license plate or decal and shall either surrender such plate or decal to the chief of police or may, upon proper application, but without payment of additional fee, have such plate or decal assigned to another bicycle owned by the applicant. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-5.)  
Sec. 16-17. - Rental agencies to comply with article. 
A rental agency shall not rent or offer any bicycle for rent unless the bicycle is licensed and a license plate or decal is attached thereto as provided by this article, and unless such bicycle is equipped with the lamps, brakes and other equipment required in this article. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-6.)  
Sec. 16-18. - Equipment—Lights. 
Every bicycle shall be equipped with a lamp on the front exhibiting a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred feet to the front and with a lamp on the rear exhibiting a red light visible from a distance of five hundred feet to the rear; except, that a red reflector meeting the requirements of this article may be used in lieu of the red light. All such lamps and reflectors shall be in place and in operation whenever such bicycle is operated after sundown. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-7.) 
 For state law as to equipment required on a bicycle generally, see C.R.S. 1973, § 42-4-218.  
Sec. 16-19. - Same—Sirens or whistles prohibited. 
No bicycle shall be equipped with, nor shall any person use upon a bicycle, any siren or whistle. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-7.) 
For state law prohibiting the use or existence of a siren or whistle upon any bicycle, see C.R.S. 1973, § 42-4-221(3).  
Sec. 16-20. - Same—Brakes. 
Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make a braked wheel-skid on dry, level and clean pavement. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-7.)  
Sec. 16-21. - Riding, etc., on sidewalk prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or propel any bicycle upon any sidewalk within the city, or to ride any skateboard, roller skates, inline skates or scooters on all city streets and sidewalks in the area bounded to North Street on the North, to First Street on the South, to Maple Street on the West, and to Washington Street on the East. 
(Ord. No. 711, § 1: Ord. No. 941 (part).)  
Sec. 16-22. - Penalties. 
Upon conviction of a violation of this article, every person not a juvenile as defined by state law shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A as now in effect or as may be amended from time to time upon first conviction of the violation of the ordinance codified in this section; if a juvenile as set forth in Section 18-B9 Juvenile Sentencing now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. Upon a second conviction of any offender the judge of the municipal court shall impound the bicycle, roller skates, roller blades, skateboards or scooters of the offending party and the same shall be turned over to the Cortez police department for disposal in accordance with departmental regulations and city ordinances. Said impoundment shall not be in lieu of any punishment applicable as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A now in effect or as may be amended from time to time that the municipal judge wishes to levy upon an adult or any fine as set forth in section 18B-9 juvenile sentencing that the judge may wish to levy upon a juvenile. 
(Code 1968, § 14-3-9: Ord. No. 941 (part); amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 16, 9-25-12)  
Article IV. - Vehicles. 
 
Sec. 16-23. - Neighborhood electric vehicles (NEV). 
Neighborhood electric vehicles (NEV) are described as follows: 
(a)  Vehicles meet the equipment standards set forth in Article 1, Part 2, of the Model Traffic Code; 
(b)  Are designed to carry four or fewer persons; 
(c)  Are designed to be operated at speeds of twenty-five miles per hour or less; 
(d)  Has at least four wheels in contact with the ground; 
(e)  Has an empty weight of less than one thousand eight hundred pounds; and 
(f)  Must be electric motor powered. 
(Ord. No. 1120 § 1.)  
Sec. 16-24. - Regulation of NEV's. 
Regulation of NEV's includes the following: 
(a)  No person shall operate a neighborhood electric vehicle on a limited access highway. 
(b)  No person shall operate a neighborhood electric vehicle on any street or highway with a posted speed limit of more than thirty miles per hour, provided, however, that neighborhood electric vehicles shall be allowed to cross, at intersections, streets and highways that have a posted speed limit in excess of thirty miles per hour. 
(c)  Neighborhood electric vehicles shall not be operated at a speed in excess of twenty-five miles per hour. 
(d)  Neighborhood electric vehicles shall not carry a greater number of persons or carry a greater load than that specified by the manufacturer. The driver and all passengers must be seated in seats substantially similar to those placed in the vehicle by the manufacturer. 
(e)  No person shall operate a neighborhood electric vehicle on a city-owned or maintained trail. 
(f)  Neighborhood electric vehicles shall only be operated by persons holding a valid driver's license. 
(g)  Operators of neighborhood electric vehicles shall obey all traffic laws of the state of Colorado, including but not limited to, laws concerning financial responsibility, and all traffic laws and regulations of the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. 1120 § 2.)  
Sec. 16-25. - Use of retarders prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person while driving any truck, bus, automobile or other motor vehicle to use a retarder (commonly known as a jake brake or compression brake) on any truck, bus, automobile or other motor vehicle within the city of Cortez. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings as stated below. 
(1)  "Retarder" shall mean any device or piece of equipment which helps increase a vehicle's braking power, and includes any exhaust or engine braking device. When activated, a retarder creates noise through a vehicle's exhaust system. 
(b)  Emergencies. This provision shall not prohibit the use of a retarder in an emergency. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be punished as set forth in chapter 17, section 17-16A, sentencing/municipal court, now in effect, or as may be amended from time to time. 
( Ord. No. 1188, 5-13-14 )  
CHAPTER 17. - MUNICIPAL COURTS. 
 For state law as to municipal courts generally, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 13-10-101 to 13-10-125. 
 
Sec. 17-1. - Procedure for handling violations established. 
In order to provide a simple and expedient method for the handling of violations of the Code or ordinances of the city, but one which will also guarantee to all defendants a method of exercising their constitutional rights, the city council does hereby establish the following procedure for the handling of violations of the Code or ordinances as set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-1.)  
Sec. 17-2. - Initiation of prosecution. 
Prosecution of a violation of the Code or ordinance of the city shall be made in the name of the city and shall be commenced by the issuance of a summons and complaint, by the issuance of summons following a complaint filed with Cortez Municipal Court or by the filing of a complaint following arrest. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-2.) 
(Ord. No. 1181, 9-24-13) 
 For state law as to commencement of actions in municipal courts by service of process, etc., see C.R.S. 1973, § 13-10-111.  
Sec. 17-3. - Summons and complaint—Issuance; where filed; service. 
A summons and complaint may be issued by any city of Cortez Police Officer, Animal Control Officer or Code Enforcement Officer for a violation of this Code or other ordinance of the city committed in his presence, or if not committed in his presence, concerning matter which he has reasonable grounds for believing was committed by the person charged. A copy of the summons and complaint so issued shall be immediately filed with the municipal court. A copy shall also be served by immediate delivery to the person charged 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-3.) 
(Ord. No. 1181, 9-24-13) 
 For state law as to service of summonses, see C.R.S. 1973, § 16-5-205.  
Sec. 17-4. - Same—Content. 
The summons and complaint issued by any city of Cortez Police Officer, Animal Control Officer or Code Enforcement Officer shall contain the name of the defendant, shall identify the offense charged by the Code or ordinance alleged to have been violated, shall contain a brief statement or description of the offense charged, including the date and approximate location thereof and shall direct the defendant to appear before the municipal court at a stated date, time and place. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-5.) 
(Ord. No. 1181, 9-24-13) 
 For state law as to content of summons, see C.R.S. 1973, § 16-5-206.  
Sec. 17-5. - Same—Methods of service. 
A summons or summons and complaint shall be served personally upon the defendant and a copy given to him. In lieu of personal service, service may be made by leaving a copy of the summons and complaint at the usual place of abode with any person over the age of eighteen years residing therein or by mailing a copy to the defendant's last known address by certified mail, return receipt requested, not less than five days prior to the time that the defendant is required to appear; provided, that such place of abode or last known address of the defendant is within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-7.) 
 For state law as to service of summons, see C.R.S. 1973, § 16-5-206.  
Sec. 17-6. - Same—Issuance by clerk of summons upon complaint. 
A summons may be issued by the clerk of the municipal court if a sworn complaint has been filed by any person requesting the issuance of a summons and it appears from the complaint that there is probable cause to believe that a violation of the City Code or ordinance has been committed and that the defendant committed it. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-4.)  
Sec. 17-7. - Warrants—Issuance upon request. 
Warrants shall be issued upon specific request from the officer in charge, in place of a summons, but only when specifically requested. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-6.) 
 For state law as to issuance of warrants, see C.R.S. 1973, § 16-5-206.  
Sec. 17-8. - Same—Issuance upon failure to appear in court. 
If a person upon whom a summons has been served pursuant to this article fails to appear in person or by counsel before the municipal court as specified therein, a bench warrant shall be issued for his arrest. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-8.) 
 For state law as to issuance of warrant upon failure to respond to summons, see C.R.S. 1973, § 16-5-207.  
Sec. 17-9. - Posting of bond. 
When the court is not immediately available, provision for bail of persons arrested and brought to the city jail on charges of violations of the Code or ordinances of the city shall be made. Such persons may post bail pursuant to rules of the municipal court, by the court clerk or by any other responsible or appropriate officer designated by the court. The court shall provide, by rule, for the conditions and circumstances under which such bail will be granted pending appearance before the court. Bail so required may be, at the election of the accused, in the form of cash security, real property, tangible or intangible personal property, acceptable corporate surety bond or adequate and acceptable private sureties. In cases when so permitted by court rules promulgated pursuant to this section, bail may be upon personal recognizance without security or surety. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-9.) 
 For state law authorizing city to accept bail bond, see C.R.S. 1973, § 31-12-101(61).  
Sec. 17-10. - Right to jury trial; prerequisites; selection. 
(a)  Any defendant charged with a Cortez City Code or city ordinance offense, other than a noncriminal traffic infraction or offense, shall have the right to a jury trial if, within twenty days after arraignment or entry of plea, such defendant files with the court a written jury demand and at the same time tenders to the court a jury fee of twenty-five dollars for a three-person jury or forty-three dollars for a jury of six persons. The fee may be waived by the court because of the indigence of a defendant. 
(b)  No defendant shall have a right to a trial by jury for any noncriminal traffic infraction or offense. Except as hereinafter provided in Cortez City Code section 16-4, all offenses that violate any provision of chapter 16 of the Cortez City Code or of any provision of the Model Traffic Code for Colorado Municipalities, as currently adopted or as may be amended from time to time are hereby declared to be noncriminal traffic infractions or offenses. Noncriminal offenses are punishable by a fine of up to four hundred ninety-nine dollars only, except as set forth in Cortez City Code section 16-4. 
(c)  Any defendant charged with violation of any of the offenses of the Model Traffic Code for Colorado Municipalities now in effect or as may be amended from time to time listed in Cortez City Code section 16-4. 
(d)  In the event that a defendant is charged with more than one traffic offense arising out of the same incident and at least one of the charged offenses is listed in Cortez City Code section 16-4 of this Code the defendant shall have the right to demand a trial by jury as to all such offenses, which shall be consolidated for purposes of trial. 
(e)  No defendant convicted of any offense declared to be a noncriminal traffic infraction or offenses shall be punished by imprisonment for any such conviction. 
(f)  Where applicable, failure to make a demand in writing for a jury trial shall constitute a waiver of such right. The defendant shall be tried by a jury of three in number unless at the time of making a demand for a jury trial, request is made for a greater number, not to exceed six jurors. Failure to designate the number of jurors to try the case shall constitute waiver of a jury in excess of three jurors. Upon request for a jury trial, the court shall set a time and place for such trial and shall bring before the court a sufficient number of jurors for the trial of the case. 
(Ord. No. 693, § 1; Ord. No. 1101.) 
( Ord. No. 1200, 5-26-15 ) 
 For state law as to trial by jury in municipal courts, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 13-10-101, 13-10-114.  
Sec. 17-11. - Officer to give testimony. 
(a)  At any hearing on a traffic violation which carries only a fine and no jail time, as set out in section 17-10 of this chapter, the officer who issued the citation may offer evidence of the facts concerning the alleged infraction. 
(b)  The officer may give the court a statement of the facts, at which time the party receiving the citation shall be allowed to cross-examine the officer. 
(c)  The officer may not be allowed to conduct any cross-examination, although he may make a statement in rebuttal after the person receiving the citation or any witness called has testified. 
(d)  The officer may be questioned by the court. 
(e)  Nothing provided herein shall prevent the officer from being represented by the city attorney's office if the defendant shall have counsel present. 
(Ord. No. 777.)  
Sec. 17-12. - Adoption of state and county rules of procedure; promulgation of additional rules by judge. 
Rules concerning the selection of jurors, challenges for cause and other matters concerning court procedure and trials shall, as far as practical, be governed by the statutes of the state and the Municipal Law Rules of Procedure promulgated by the Colorado Supreme Court. The municipal judge is hereby authorized to make such rules of court as he may deem advisable for the conduct of the business of the court, subject to the approval of the city attorney. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-12.) 
 For state law as to powers and procedures of municipal court, see C.R.S. 1973, § 13-10-112.  
Sec. 17-13. - Entry of judgment generally. 
In all cases either tried by a jury or to the court when the defendant is found guilty, the court, in its discretion, shall fix and determine the sentence, penalty and punishment together with costs, or the court may suspend all or any part thereof or may exercise the powers of probation as deemed advisable under the circumstances, within the discretion of the court, and judgment shall be entered and execution issued thereon without delay. The court may, however, in its discretion, stay the execution of any penalty for a period not to exceed ten days; provided, that the defendant or his counsel have an opportunity to offer testimony or statements in mitigation before judgment is entered. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-13.) 
 For state law as to power of municipal judge to impose fines and penalties, see C.R.S. 1973, § 13-10-113.  
Sec. 17-14. - Municipal court costs and fees. 
(a)  Court costs before the municipal court of the city of Cortez shall be set as follows: 
(1)  Court costs shall be reviewed annually and set in the annual budget process by resolution. 
(2)  Court costs shall be imposed upon the entry of a guilty plea or after a conviction at trial. Five dollars of court costs assessed for each case where defendants appear in court shall be paid into the police department budget for the use of the drug awareness resistance and education (DARE) program. The balance of any court costs so assessed shall be paid into the general fund. 
(3)  Court costs shall be assessed on all other offenses which are paid prior to the date of court appearance. All court costs collected in this manner shall be paid into the general fund. 
(4)  Jury demand fees in cases tried to a jury of three shall be set annually by resolution and the cost of each additional juror over three shall also be set by annual resolution. 
(5)  All other court costs for copies, transcripts, CDs, etc. shall be in accordance with the city's open records/criminal justice records, fees and costs annually set by resolution. In the event that the cost of a particular item, copy, etc. is not set in said resolution the city shall be paid for its actual time, costs and material etc. for providing said copy or information, etc. 
(b)  Surcharges. There shall be a surcharge of ten dollars assessed on all traffic tickets and other criminal summons and complaints upon issue for the operation of the Bridge Shelter. Said surcharge shall be collected at the same time as fines and court costs. All monies collected shall be paid to the Bridge Shelter at least annually or such other more frequent times as shall be determined by the finance director and city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1158, 11-22-11; Ord. No. 1177, 2-26-13) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1158, adopted November 22, 2011, repealed the former § 17-14, and enacted a new § 17-14 as set out herein. The former § 17-14 pertained to court costs schedule and derived from Ord. No. 669; Ord. No. 832 and Ord. No. 1011. 
 For state law as to power of municipal judge to assess costs, see C.R.S. 1973, § 13-10-113.  
Sec. 17-15. - Juror fees. 
Juror fees shall be as follows: For serving as a juror, for one day or part thereof, six dollars; for each juror summoned and required to appear in attendance of court, three dollars. 
(Ord. No. 669, § 2 (part).)  
Sec. 17-16. - Repealed September 13, 2005.  
Sec. 17-16A. - Sentencing/municipal court. 
(a)  A violation of any of the provisions of the Cortez City Code/City Ordinances is punishable by a fine of up to four hundred ninety-nine dollars, a jail sentence of up to one hundred eighty days or by both a fine and jail sentence, except as set forth below or at Cortez City Code section 17-10, right to jury trial, section 18B-9, juvenile sentencing and section 16-4, Model Traffic Code. 
(b)  Unless otherwise indicated each day or portion thereof any violation of any provision of the Cortez City Code/City Ordinances shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Unpaid fines and costs may be collected by the court as set forth in C.R.S. 13-10-114 and 18-1.3-506 C.R.S. now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. Unpaid fines and court costs in appropriate circumstances may be collected as set forth/pursuant to § 31-20-105 C.R.S. and certified to the Montezuma County Treasurer for collection in the same manner taxes are collected. 
(d)  In addition to fines or a jail sentence, the court may approve deferred judgment and sentencing for a period of time of up to one year, unsupervised probation of up to one year, a deferred prosecution for up to one year, or suspend jail or fines, contingent upon such terms and conditions including payment of restitution as the court finds appropriate. 
(e)  Juveniles shall not be sentenced to jail as a result of a conviction of the Cortez City Code/City Ordinances. Juveniles shall be sentenced as set forth in Cortez City Code section 18B-9, juvenile sentencing, now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 1, 9-25-12; Ord. No. 1200, 5-26-15 ) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1170, § 1, adopted September 25, 2012, repealed the former § 17-16A, and enacted a new § 17-16A as set out herein. The former 17-16A pertained to fines; jail time; deferred judgment and derived from Ord. No. 1052.)  
Sec. 17-17. - Repealed September 13, 2005.  
Sec. 17-18. - Appeal to district court. 
Appeals from the municipal court of the city to the district court shall be as provided by state statutes. 
(Code 1968, § 1-3-18.) 
 For state law as to procedure for appeal from municipal court determinations, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 13-10-116 to 13-10-125.  
Sec. 17-19. - Court of record. 
(a)  The municipal court of the city shall be a court of record. 
(b)  A verbatim record of all proceedings and evidence at trials shall be kept by electric devices or stenographic means. 
(c)  The judge of the municipal court shall be admitted to, and currently licensed in, the practice of law in the state. 
(Ord. No. 503, §§ 1—3.)  
Sec. 17-20. - Municipal court clerk/administrator. 
(a)  Duties. The municipal court clerk/administrator shall: 
(1)  Be responsible for administering all functions of the municipal court by providing the necessary support services, including the processing of court documents and correspondence; 
(2)  Prepare the court's annual budget and monitor the same; 
(3)  Provide court information to the public, defendants, attorneys and law enforcement officers regarding court times and fines; 
(4)  Collect fines and bonds and deposit the same in the appropriate fund. The municipal court clerk/administrator shall maintain records of all funds and prepare necessary accounting statements for the director of finance; 
(5)  Record court proceedings and acts as clerk of the court, and prepare post-court paperwork; 
(6)  Perform all other duties as assigned by the city manager and as prescribed in the Charter of the codified ordinances of the city, as amended. 
(b)  Requirements. The municipal court clerk/administrator shall: 
(1)  Reserved; 
(2)  Take and subscribe an oath of office pursuant to article II, section 5 of the Charter; 
(3)  Be appointed by, and report to, the city manager, and shall be subject to any other requirements as may be prescribed by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 691, § 1.) 
(Ord. No. 1157, 11-22-11; Ord. No. 1158, 11-22-11)  
Sec. 17-21. - Evidence alcohol related offenses. 
(a)  During any trial for a violation of any alcohol related offense contained in this Code, any bottle, can, or any other container with labeling indicating the contents of such bottle, can, or container shall be admissible into evidence, and the information contained on any label on such bottle, can, or other container shall be admissible into evidence and shall not constitute hearsay. A jury or a judge, whichever is appropriate, may consider the information upon such label in determining whether the contents of the bottle, can, or other container were composed in whole or in part of ethyl alcohol. A label which identifies the contents of any bottle, can, or other container as "beer," "ale," "malt beverage," "fermented malt beverage," "malt liquor," "wine," "champagne," "whiskey" or "whisky," "gin," "vodka," "tequila," "schnapps," "brandy," "cognac," "liqueur," "cordial," "alcohol," or "liquor" shall constitute prima facie evidence that the contents of the bottle, can, or other container was composed in whole or in part of ethyl alcohol. 
(b)  The qualitative result of an alcohol test or tests shall be admissible at the trial of any person charged with a violation of any alcohol related offense contained in this Code, upon a showing that the device or devices used to conduct such test or tests have been approved as accurate in detecting alcohol by the executive director of the department of public health and environment. 
(c)  Official records of the department of public health and environment relating to the certification of breath test instruments, certification of operators and operator instructors of breath test instruments, certification of standard solutions, and certification of laboratories shall be official records of the state. Copies of such records, attested by the executive director of the department of public health and environment or his deputy and accompanied by a certificate bearing the official seal for said department, which state that the executive director of the department has custody of such records, shall be admissible in all courts of record and shall constitute prima facie evidence of the information contained in such records. The official seal of the department described in this subsection may consist of a rubber stamp producing a facsimile of the seal stamped upon the document. 
(d)  In any judicial proceeding in the Cortez Municipal Court concerning a charge of any alcohol related offense contained in the Cortez City Code, the court shall take judicial notice of methods of testing a person's blood, breath, saliva, or urine for the presence of alcohol and of the design and operation of devices certified by the department of public health and environment for testing a person's blood, breath, saliva, or urine for the presence of alcohol. This subsection shall not prevent the necessity of establishing during a trial that the testing devices were working properly and that such testing devices were properly operated. Nothing in this subsection shall preclude a defendant from offering evidence concerning the accuracy of testing devices. 
(Ord. No. 1176, 2-12-13)  
CHAPTER 18. - OFFENSES—MISCELLANEOUS. 
 For state law as to authority of city to pass police ordinances, see C.R.S. 1973, § 31-15-401(a). As to authority of city to pass ordinances generally, see C.R.S. 1973, § 31-15-103. As to the state criminal code generally, see C.R.S. 1973, § 18-1-101 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Alcoholic beverages—Drinking in public generally. 
From and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to drink any spirituous, intoxicating malt, vinous, mixed or fermented liquor at any place described in section 18-2(c) of this chapter between the hours of 12:01 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, except as authorized by section 18-3, Liquor licenses—Special events, Cortez City Code, Ordinance No. 1112, Series 2008, Cortez City Code and section 4-6, Outdoor dining central business district. A violation of this section shall be punishable as set forth in section 17-16A, Cortez City Code, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 591, § 1; Ord. No. 1112 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1227 , 8-8-17)  
Sec. 18-2. - Possession of open containers of liquor, wine, or fermented malt beverages. 
(a)  It shall be illegal to have possession of an alcohol beverage whether open or unopened on any city-owned property as the same shall be described on the city zoning map. It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to carry or have any open container of malt, vinous or spirituous liquors or fermented malt beverages on a street, sidewalk, alley, parking lot, park or other place in the city, as enumerated by the city zoning map. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink malt, vinous or spirituous liquors or fermented malt beverages in any of the above enumerated places in the city provided, however, it shall be an absolute defense if an open bottle of vinous liquor was obtained at an establishment which is the holder of a hotel and restaurant license, manufacturer's license, limited winery license, beer and wine license, tavern license, vintner's license, or brew pub license, and the said establishment had allowed the removal of one container of partially consumed vinous liquor purchased on the premises, so long as the original container did not contain more than seven hundred fifty mls of vinous liquor and has been re-corked before its removal. The establishment must have means available for the consumption in accordance with C.R.S. section 12-47-120. 
(c)  The following areas shall be exempted from the terms of the ordinance codified in this chapter. The Conquistador Golf Course, which shall be allowed to sell alcoholic beverages with a hotel and restaurant license, which may be consumed on the golf course, and according to section 18-3, Liquor licenses—Special events, Cortez City Code, Ordinance No. 1112, Series 2008. 
The organization seeking sponsorship of the special event shall obtain proper application as agreed upon by parks and recreation and the police department. 
The City of Cortez may require the permittee to provide security at any event at which alcohol is permitted. Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted as a waiver of any penal ordinance of the City of Cortez. 
And according to Cortez City Code section 4-6, Outdoor dining-central business district, a violation of this section shall be punishable as set forth in section 17-16A, Cortez City Code, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1079; Ord. No. 1112 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1221 , 3-28-17; Ord. No. 1227 , 8-8-17)  
Sec. 18-3. - Liquor licenses—Special events. 
The city council of the City of Cortez reserves to itself the right to allow the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages on all city property, including the recreation center, in accordance with its right to issue special events permits as set forth in the Colorado Revised Statutes at Section 12-48-101 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
Applicants applying for a special events permit on city property shall be a nonprofit and meet all qualifications as set forth in Section 12-48-102, C.R.S., as amended from time to time, all conditions imposed by the Colorado Department of Revenue Liquor Enforcement regulations and all applicable state, county and city laws. 
Special events permit applicants shall meet all conditions of use for city property as set forth in the City Code, as amended from time to time, as city council may impose by resolution, or through regulations promulgated by the city manager. 
The applicant shall carry premises and liquor liability insurance in an amount to be determined by resolution of the council or the city manager, if authorized by council. 
All applications for any type of special events permit shall be made on forms provided by the state licensing authority, department of revenue, liquor enforcement division. 
The applications for a special event permit shall be verified by oath or affirmation of an officer of the applicant organization. The properly verified application shall be submitted to the City of Cortez city council, or other designated agency as set forth by statute or ordinance, not less than thirty days prior to date of the special event. 
Each special event permit application shall be accompanied by a check made out to the City of Cortez in the amount necessary to cover all licensing and permit fees involved. 
All applicants shall have a state sales tax license. 
Applicants shall provide such support services as are necessary for the event in the opinion of the city manager or his designee. Support services to include clean-up, security, bathroom facilities, fencing, etc. As a condition of granting the permit, the city may make, as a condition of the permit, the provision of said support services. 
Applicant shall comply with all rules, regulations of the city and its departments. 
The city may deny an application for any grounds, for violation of the provisions of Article 48, Colorado Revised Statutes, for violation of the provisions of Title 12 Articles 46, 47, 48 C.R.S. as amended. The city may deny any application which it determines is incomplete, inaccurate, false or inappropriate. 
No applicant shall allow attendees of the event to bring onto the licensed premises or the event's complete premises, whichever is larger, their own alcoholic or fermented beverages or to violate any federal, state or city ordinances at the permitted event. 
Applicant shall be both criminally and civilly liable for any violations of the state liquor code or regulations as may be amended from time to time, and all other applicable state laws, county or city ordinances. 
A violation of this section shall be punishable as set forth in section 17-16A, Cortez City Code as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1112 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1221 , 3-28-17)  
Sec. 18-4. - Prohibition of underage consumption of alcohol. 
(a)  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise requires: 
Establishment means a business, firm, enterprise, service or fraternal organization, club, institution, entity, group, or residence, and any real property, including buildings and improvements, connected therewith, and shall also include any members, employees, and occupants associated therewith. 
Ethyl alcohol means any substance, which is or contains ethyl alcohol. 
Possession of ethyl alcohol means that a person has or holds any amount of ethyl alcohol anywhere on his person, or that a person owns or has custody of ethyl alcohol, or has ethyl alcohol within his immediate presence and control. 
Private property means any dwelling and its curtilage which is being used by a natural person or natural persons for habitation and which is not open to the public and privately owned real property which is not open to the public. "Private property" shall not include: 
(1)  Any establishment which has or is required to have a license pursuant to article 46, 47, or 48 of title 12, C.R.S.; or 
(2)  Any establishment which sells ethyl alcohol or upon which ethyl alcohol is sold; or 
(3)  Any establishment, which leases, rents, or provides accommodations to members of the public generally. 
(b)  (1)  Any person age eighteen to twenty years of age who possesses or consumes ethyl alcohol anywhere in the city of Cortez commits illegal possession or consumption of ethyl alcohol by an underage person. 
Illegal possession or consumption of ethyl alcohol by an underage person is a strict liability offense. 
(2)  Illegal possession or consumption of ethyl alcohol by an underage person shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars or jail up to one hundred eighty days or both a fine and jail sentence.
