The court, upon sentencing a defendant pursuant to this subsection, may, in addition to any fine, suspend jail time on condition that the defendant submit to and complete an alcohol evaluation or assessment, an alcohol education program, or an alcohol treatment program at such defendant's own expense. 
(c)  It shall be an affirmative defense to the offense described in subsection (b) of this section that the ethyl alcohol was possessed or consumed by a person under twenty-one years of age under the following circumstances: 
(1)  While such person was legally upon private property with the knowledge and consent of the owner or legal possessor of such private property and the ethyl alcohol was possessed or consumed with the consent of his parent or legal guardian who was present during such possession or consumption; or 
(2)  When the existence of ethyl alcohol in a person's body was due solely to the ingestion of a confectionery which contained ethyl alcohol within the limits prescribed by section 25-5-410 (1) (i) (II), C.R.S.; or the ingestion of any substance which was manufactured, designed, or intended primarily for a purpose other than oral human ingestion; or the ingestion of any substance which was manufactured, designed, or intended solely for medicinal or hygienic purposes; or solely from the ingestion of a beverage which contained less than one-half of one percent of ethyl alcohol by weight. 
(3)  The person is a student who: 
(A)  Tastes but does not imbibe an alcohol beverage only while under the direct supervision of an instructor who is at least twenty-one years of age and employed by a post-secondary school; 
(B)  Is enrolled in a university or a post-secondary school accredited or certified by an agency recognized by the United States department of education, a nationally recognized accrediting agency or association, or the "Private Occupational Education Act of 1981," article 59 of title 12, C.R.S.; 
(C)  Is participating in a culinary arts, food service, or restaurant management degree program; and 
(D)  Tastes but does not imbibe the alcohol beverage for instructional purposes as a part of a required course in which the alcohol beverage, except the portion the student tastes, remains under the control of the instructor. 
(d)  The possession or consumption of ethyl alcohol shall not constitute a violation of this section if such possession or consumption takes place for religious purposes protected by the first amendment to the United States constitution. 
An underage person and one or two other persons shall be immune from criminal prosecution under this section if they establish the following: 
(1)  One of the underage persons called 911 and reported that another underage person was in need of medical assistance due to alcohol consumption; 
(2)  The underage person who called 911 and, if applicable, one or two other persons acting in concert with the underage person who called 911 provided each of their names to the 911 operator; 
(3)  The underage person was the first person to make the 911 report; and 
(4)  The underage person and, if applicable, one or two other persons acting in concert with the underage person who made the 911 call remained on the scene with the underage person in need of medical assistance until assistance arrived and cooperated with medical assistance and law enforcement personnel on the scene. 
(e)  Prima facie evidence of a violation of subsection (b) of this section shall consist of: 
(1)  Evidence that the defendant age eighteen to twenty years of age and possessed or consumed ethyl alcohol anywhere in the city of Cortez; or 
(2)  Evidence that the defendant was age eighteen to twenty years of age and manifested any of the characteristics commonly associated with ethyl alcohol intoxication or impairment while present anywhere in the city of Cortez. 
(f)  During any trial for a violation of subsection (b) of this section, any bottle, can, or any other container with labeling indicating the contents of such bottle, can, or container shall be admissible into evidence, and the information contained on any label on such bottle, can, or other container shall be admissible into evidence and shall not constitute hearsay. A jury or a judge, whichever is appropriate, may consider the information upon such label in determining whether the contents of the bottle, can, or other container were composed in whole or in part of ethyl alcohol. A label which identifies the contents of any bottle, can, or other container as "beer," "ale," "malt beverage," "fermented malt beverage," "malt liquor," "wine," "champagne," "whiskey" or "whisky," "gin," "vodka," "tequila," "schnapps," "brandy," "cognac," "liqueur," "cordial," "alcohol," or "liquor" shall constitute prima facie evidence that the contents of the bottle, can, or other container was composed in whole or in part of ethyl alcohol. 
(g)  A parent or legal guardian of a person eighteen to twenty years of age or any natural person who has the permission of such parent or legal guardian may give or permit the possession and consumption of ethyl alcohol to or by a person under the age eighteen to twenty years of age under the conditions described in subsection (c)(1) of this section. This subsection shall not be construed to permit any establishment which is or is required to be licensed pursuant to article 46, 47, or 48 of title 12, C.R.S., or any members, employees, or occupants of any such establishment to give, provide, make available, or sell ethyl alcohol to a person under twenty-one years of age. 
(h)  The qualitative result of an alcohol test or tests shall be admissible at the trial of any person charged with a violation of subsection (b) of this section upon a showing that the device or devices used to conduct such test or tests have been approved as accurate in detecting alcohol by the executive director of the department of public health and environment. 
(i)  Official records of the department of public health and environment relating to the certification of breath test instruments, certification of operators and operator instructors of breath test instruments, certification of standard solutions, and certification of laboratories shall be official records of the state. Copies of such records, attested by the executive director of the department of public health and environment or his deputy and accompanied by a certificate bearing the official seal for said department, which state that the executive director of the department has custody of such records, shall be admissible in all courts of record and shall constitute prima facie evidence of the information contained in such records. The official seal of the department described in this subsection may consist of a rubber stamp producing a facsimile of the seal stamped upon the document. 
(j)  In any judicial proceeding in any court of this state concerning a charge under subsection (b) of this section, the court shall take judicial notice of methods of testing a person's blood, breath, saliva, or urine for the presence of alcohol and of the design and operation of devices certified by the department of public health and environment for testing a person's blood, breath, saliva, or urine for the presence of alcohol. This subsection shall not prevent the necessity of establishing during a trial that the testing devices were working properly and that such testing devices were properly operated. Nothing in this subsection shall preclude a defendant from offering evidence concerning the accuracy of testing devices. 
(k)  No law enforcement officer shall enter upon any private property to investigate any violation of this section without probable cause. 
(Ord. No. 1122.)  
Sec. 18-5. - Violation of bail bond conditions. 
(a)  A person who is released on bail bond of whatever kind, and either before, during, or after release is accused by complaint, information, indictment, or the filing of any other charges arising from the conduct for which he was arrested commits a violation of this ordinance if he knowingly fails to appear for trial or other court appearances in the case in which the bail bond was filed or if he knowingly violates the conditions of the bail bond. 
(b)  Bail Bond conditions may be set in general for all offenses by the municipal court judge and in addition may be set specific to the defendant and/or charge filed against said defendant at the judge's discretion. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as set forth in section 17-16A, Cortez City code as currently in effect and as maybe amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1158, 11-22-11)  
Sec. 18-6. - False reporting. 
A person commits the crime of false reporting if he or she knowingly: 
(a)  Assumes a false or fictitious identity or legal capacity, and in such identity he or she: 
(1)  Performs an act that if done by the person falsely impersonated might subject such person to an action, special proceeding, civil or criminal or to liability, charge, forfeiture or penalty. 
(2)  Uses false or fictitious personal identifying information to identify a specific individual such as but not limited to a name, date of birth, social security #, official government issued driver's license or ID card number. 
(3)  A violation of this section shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
( Ord. No. 1228 , 8-22-17)  
Sec. 18-7. - Repealed April 13, 1982.  
Secs. - 18-8, 18-9. Reserved.  
Sec. 18-10. - Repealed April 13, 1982.  
Sec. 18-11. - Disturbing the peace. 
(a)  A person commits the crime of disturbing the peace if he or she intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly: 
(1)  Makes a coarse and obviously offensive utterance, gesture, or display in a public place and the utterance, gesture, or display tends to incite an immediate breach of the peace; or 
(2)  Makes unreasonable noise in a public place or near a private residence that he has no right to occupy; or 
(3)  Fights with another in a public place except in an amateur or professional contest of athletic skill; or 
(4)  Not being a peace officer, discharges a firearm in a public place except when engaged in lawful target practice or hunting; or the ritual discharge of blank ammunition cartridges as an attendee at a funeral for a deceased person who was a Veteran of the Armed Forces of the United States; or 
(5)  Not being a peace officer, displays a deadly weapon, displays any article used or fashioned in a manner to cause a person to reasonably believe that the article is a deadly weapon, or represents verbally or otherwise that he or she is armed with a deadly weapon in a public place in a manner calculated to alarm. 
(6)  For purposes of these subsection(s) (a)(1), (a)(2), (a)(3), (a)(4) and (a)(5) a member of the Cortez Police Department is empowered to make a prima facie determination if such noise or conduct constitutes Disturbing the Peace. 
(b)  Schools, hospitals, and libraries. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person by himself or in the operation of any instrument, machine or vehicle to make any unnecessary noise within one hundred fifty feet of any hospital or any institution reserved for the sick or any school during school hours or any library during normal library hours. 
(2)  For purposes of this section (b)(1), a member of the police department is empowered to make a prima facie determination as to whether such noise constitutes a violation of disturbing the peace. 
(c)  Acts of another. It is unlawful for a person to permit another to commit an act of disturbing the peace in or upon any premises owned, possessed, or under management or control of the person when it is in that person's power to prevent another from committing such an act. 
(d)  It shall be an affirmative defense: 
(1)  To subsection (a)(3) of this section that the actor had significant provocation for his abusive or threatening conduct; 
(2)  To subsections (a)(4), (a)(5) of this section that the actor acted necessarily to prevent serious bodily injury to himself or another. 
(e)  A violation of section 18-11 disturbing the peace shall be punishable as set forth in section 17-16A Cortez City Code now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1968, § 11-4-6; Ord. No. 581, § 7; Ord. No. 757; Ord. No. 837; Ord. No. 1111 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1217 , 9-27-16) 
 As to disorderly conduct generally, see C.R.S. 1973, § 18-9-106.  
Sec. 18-12. - Indecent exposure—public indecency. 
(a)  A person commits indecent exposure if he/she knowingly exposes his/her genitals to the view of any person under circumstances in which such conduct is likely to cause affront or alarm to the other person. 
(b)  Any person who performs any of the following in a public place or where the conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by members of the public commits public indecency: 
(1)  An act of sexual intercourse; or 
(2)  A lewd fondling or caress of the body of another person; or 
(3)  Urinates or defecates. 
(c)  Public indecency is a strict liability crime. 
(d)  For purposes of this section, a member of the police department is empowered to make a prima facie determination as to whether such behavior constitutes an indecent exposure or public indecency. 
(e)  A violation of section 18-12 Cortez City Code shall be punishable as set forth in section 17-16A Cortez City Code now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
( Ord. No. 1217 , 9-27-16)  
Sec. 18-13. - False alarms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally and knowingly make, turn in or knowingly give a false alarm of fire or need of police or ambulance assistance or to knowingly aid or abet in the committing of such an act. 
(Ord. No. 418, § 1; Ord. No. 420, § 1; Ord. No. 581, § 8.) 
 For state law as to false alarms, see C.R.S. 1973, § 18-8-111.  
Sec. 18-14. - False reports to police. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally and knowingly make or file with the police department of the city any false statement or report concerning the commission or alleged commission of any offense occurring within the city. 
(Ord. No. 418, § 1; Ord. No. 581, § 9.) 
 For state law as to false reports to authorities, see C.R.S. 1973, § 18-8-111.  
Sec. 18-15. - Fences—Barbed wire, pointed posts, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to put upon, keep or maintain any barb, barbed wire, sharpened nails or any other pointed or sharpened thing of metallic substance upon any fence, cellar guard or window guard that fronts upon or that is erected or constructed upon any street, avenue, lane, alley, building or sidewalk so that such projects or extends beyond the surface of the wood or other material of which such fence, cellar guard or window guard may be constructed. 
(Code 1968, § 11-4-18.)

Sec. 18-30. - Officers—Impersonating, resisting, etc. 
(a)  No person shall knowingly or willfully: 
(1)  Falsely pretend to be a police officer, firefighter, or other officer of the city and perform an act in that falsely pretended capacity. 
(2)  (A) Exercise or attempt to exercise, without being duly authorized, any duty, power or function of any police officer, firefighter or any city officer. 
(B)  It shall be a defense that such person acted necessarily in an emergency in the interest of protecting public health, safety, or welfare, in the absence of the immediate presence of a police officer, firefighter, or city officer. 
(3)  Obstruct a police officer or firefighter, or any city officer by using or threatening to use violence, force, or physical interference, or obstacle, or knowingly obstruct, impair, or hinder the enforcement of the penal law or the preservation of the peace by a police officer acting under color of his official authority, or knowingly obstruct, impair, or hinder the prevention, control, or abatement of fire by a firefighter, acting under color of his official authority. An officer acts "under color of his official authority" when, in the regular course of assigned duties, he is called upon to make, and does make, a judgment in good faith based upon facts and circumstances that an authorized action should be taken by him in his official capacity. The term "officer" as used in this section means an officer in uniform or, if out of uniform, one who has identified himself by exhibiting his credentials as such officer. 
(4)  (A)  A person commits resisting arrest if he knowingly prevents or attempts to prevent a police officer acting under color of his official authority from effecting an arrest of the actor or another by: 
(i)  Using or threatening to use physical force or violence against the police officer or another. 
(ii)  Using any other means which creates a substantial risk of causing bodily injury to the police officer or another. 
(B)  It shall not be a defense that the arrest was unlawful if the police officer was acting under color of his official authority. 
(Code 1968, § 11-4-29; Ord. No. 578, § 1; amended by memo 3519; Ord. No. 1111 (part).) 
 For state law as to obstruction of justice generally, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 18-8-101 to 18-8-114. As to criminal impersonation, see C.R.S. 1973, § 18-5-113.  
Sec. 18-31. - Canine corps—Mistreatment, interference, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly torture, torment, beat, kick, strike, mutilate, injure, disable, tease, provoke or kill any dog used by the police department when such dog is being used in the performance of the functions or duties of the police department. 
Further, it shall be unlawful to knowingly torture, torment, beat, kick, strike, mutilate, injure, disable, or kill any dog owned by the police department when the dog is at the residence of its handler or the dog is in its designated place of kennel or place boarded. 
(Ord. No. 649, § 1.)  
Sec. 18-32. - Repealed May 23, 2006.  
Sec. 18-33. - Violation—Penalty. 
Any violation of this chapter shall be punishable as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 17, 9-25-12)  
Sec. 18-34. - Posters, handbills, etc.—Defacing, removing, etc.; deemed nuisance when posted without authority. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to either wilfully, maliciously, wantonly, negligently or in any other manner tear down, deface or cover up any posted advertisement or bill of any person when such is posted or put in harmony with the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
Any handbill, poster, placard or painted or printed matter which is stuck, posted or pasted upon any public or private house, store or other buildings, or upon any fence, power pole, telephone pole or other structure without the permission of the owner, agent or occupant of the house, shall be deemed a nuisance. 
(Code 1968, § 11-4-22.)  
Sec. 18-35. - Prisoners—Escaping. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, while a prisoner in the city jail, or in any other place where prisoners are confined, or otherwise in custody of and confined by the city, to escape, attempt to escape or to intentionally and knowingly assist others to escape or attempt to escape from such custody or confinement. 
(Code 1968, § 11-5-2; Ord. No. 581, § 17.) 
 For state law as to escape generally, see C.R.S. 1973, § 18-8-208.  
Sec. 18-36. - Same—Assisting escape; introduction of contraband. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally or knowingly assist or aid, or attempt to assist or aid any person in the custody of or confined under the authority of the city to escape from jail, place of confinement or custody. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally or knowingly make available to, present to or place within the reach of, or to cause to be made available to, presented to or placed within the reach of any person confined under authority of the city, vinous, spirituous or malt liquors, or any tool, implement or other thing calculated to aid in the escape of such person so confined or any other person so confined under authority of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 11-5-1; Ord. No. 581, § 18.) 
 For state law as to aiding prisoners to escape, see C.R.S. 1973, § 18-8-201. As to introducing contraband into penal institutions, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 18-8-203, 18-8-204.  
Sec. 18-37. - Private property—Injuring or destroying. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to either wilfully, maliciously, or wantonly injure or destroy real property, or improvements thereto, or movable or personal property, belonging to any person. 
(Code 1968, § 11-4-20.) 
 For state law as to trespass, tampering and criminal mischief, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 18-4-501 to 18-4-513.  
Sec. 18-38. - Repealed April 13, 1982.  
Sec. 18-39. - Graffiti. 
(a)  Graffiti prohibited; removal required. 
(1)  As used herein, the term "graffiti" or "graffiti and related vandalism" means any unauthorized inscription, symbol, design or configuration of letters, numbers or symbols, or any combination thereof written, drawn, scribed, etched, marked, painted, stained, stuck on or adhered to any surface (public or private), including, but not limited to, trees, signs, poles, fixtures, utility boxes, walls, windows, roofs, paths, walks, fences, streets, underpasses, overpasses, bridges, trestles, buildings, and any other surface or surfaces, regardless of the material of the component. 
(2)  It is unlawful for any person or group of persons to commit or attempt to commit any overt act resulting in the application of graffiti or engaging in or attempting to engage in any act of related vandalism. Such prohibited conduct shall include, but not be limited to, conspiring to commit or assist in the application of graffiti or engaging in or assisting in any act of related vandalism, including, but not limited to, acting as a "look out," regardless of whether the act of applying graffiti or engaging in related vandalism was actually committed or witnessed. 
(3)  Graffiti or graffiti-related vandalism which appears on property or structures (public or private) is deemed to be a public nuisance and shall be subject to abatement as herein proved. Should an owner or responsible party fail to remove or otherwise abate the graffiti as required in any notice of violation served upon him, the city may proceed to abate the graffiti or cause its removal and bill the owner or responsible party for the cost thereof. In the event of nonpayment, the city attorney shall be and is hereby authorized to take appropriate measures to create a lien against the subject property for purposes of recovering such costs, together with interest as provided by applicable law. If it is determined by the city that graffiti exists on property in violation of this section, the city manager or his designated agent may notify the owner of the subject property or responsible party in writing, through the issuance of a notice of violation providing a maximum of ten days within which the graffiti is to be abated or otherwise removed. Such notice may be served by certified mail, personal service or by posting the subject property and publishing a notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation within the city of Cortez. Such notice shall identify the property in violation, shall generally describe the location of the graffiti, and shall direct that such graffiti shall be removed or otherwise abated within ten days of the receipt of the notice. It is unlawful for any property owner to fail to remove or otherwise abate graffiti or related vandalism within the time frame set forth in the above notice once the same has been served. 
(4)  As part of any sentence imposed by the municipal court with respect to persons who either admit or are convicted of a violation of this section, the court may, as part of its sentencing, order that restitution be paid to the owner or party responsible for the removal or abatement of the graffiti pursuant to subsection (a)(3) of this section. If the person found to be in violation of this section is a minor under the age of eighteen years living with his or her parents or lawful guardian or custodian, the court may order restitution to be paid by the minor's parents or lawfully designated guardian or custodian. With respect to any minor under the age of eighteen years who admits or is convicted of the application of graffiti or any act of related vandalism on property owned by the city of Cortez, the city attorney shall be and is hereby authorized to seek restitution on behalf of the city against any parent, parents, lawful guardian or custodian with whom the minor resides pursuant to C.R.S., section 13-21-107, as amended. 
(b)  Possession of graffiti implements or paraphernalia by minors prohibited. It is unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen years to possess any graffiti implement or paraphernalia in a public place. 
(1)  For purposes of this section, the terms hereinafter set forth shall have the definitions as herein indicated: 
Aerosol paint container. Any canister, can, bottle, container or other receptacle which contains any substance commonly known as paint, stain, dye or any other pigmented substance which is or can be modified to contain pressure (or be pressurized) in order to impel or propel any such substance. 
Etcher. Any tool, device or other mechanism including, but not limited to, any tool, device, drill, bit or other mechanism commonly known as "glass etchers," "metal etchers," "cutting instruments" or any other instrument that can be applied by pressure or any other contact with any surface, including, but not limited to, glass, mirrors, windows, steel, aluminum, brass, tin, fiberglass, wood, plastic, concrete or any other surface which can cause any markings or scratches thereon. 
Graffiti implements or paraphernalia. Any substance or material such as, but not limited to, aerosol paint containers, markers, paint sticks, paint bombs, etchers or gum labels. The term shall also include, but shall not be limited to, tips or nozzles which can be applied to aerosol paint containers; any records of graffiti or related vandalism, including, but not limited to, pictures, photographs, drawings, scrap books, or other records depicting or illustrating any forms of graffiti or related vandalism. 
Gum label. Any substance consisting of a material such as, but not limited to, paper, fabric, cloth, plastic, vinyl or any other similar material, where the material also contains one or more surfaces containing a substance such as, but not limited to, adhesive or glue which cannot be removed from the surface in an intact condition with minimal effort. The term shall include decals, stickers, patches, stamps or labels. 
Markers. Any indelible or permanent ink marker or marking pen or any similar implement which contains any pigmented substances including, but not limited to, ink or any other substance which cannot be easily and completely removed with water after said substance has dried, where the width of the marking is one-sixteenth of one inch or greater. 
Paint bomb. Any latex, rubber, plastic or synthetic enclosure which contains any substance commonly known as paint, stain, ink or any other pigmented substance which is either designed to or is capable of rupture upon impact with any solid surface resulting in the application of the contents of said container to said surface. 
Paint stick. Any device which contains any substance, solid or liquid, including, but not limited to, any form of paint, stain, ink, chalk, wax, epoxy or any other similar substance which can be applied to any surface by such means as applying pressure to or contacting any surface in such a way as to leave any visible mark measuring at least one-sixteenth of one inch at any point. 
(2)  Possession of what would otherwise constitute graffiti implements or paraphernalia shall not be a violation of this section in the following circumstances: 
(A)  Possession of graffiti implements or paraphernalia by any minor enrolled in any educational class which requires otherwise legal possession of such implement or paraphernalia, provided the minor is carrying written verification of any such requirements, including color(s), size(s) and quantity, and written consent from his or her parent or lawfully designated guardian which is dated and signed; 
(B)  Possession of graffiti implements or paraphernalia by any minor whose employment requires possession of such implement or paraphernalia provided such minor is carrying written verification of any such job requirements including color(s), size(s) and quantity, job information and purpose, and written consent from the employer which is dated and signed. 
(Ord. No. 802.)  
Sec. 18-40. - Public property—Injuring or destroying. 
It is unlawful for any person to either wilfully, maliciously, wantonly, negligently or in any other manner injure or destroy real property or improvements thereto, or movable or personal property, belonging to the city. 
(Code 1968, § 11-4-19.) 
 For state law as to interference, trespass, etc., relative to public buildings, see C.R.S. 1973, § 18-9-110.  
Sec. 18-41. - Riots, affrays, etc. 
It is unlawful for any person within the city to intentionally and knowingly engage in or encourage any riot, rout, affray or fight. 
(Code 1968, § 11-4-8; Ord. No. 581, § 20.) 
 As to riots generally, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 18-9-101 to 18-9-105.  
Sec. 18-42. - Repealed April 13, 1982.  
Sec. 18-43. - Reserved.  
Sec. 18-44. - Repealed April 13, 1982.  
Sec. 18-45. - Reserved.  
Sec. 18-46. - Theft. 
(a)  A person commits theft when he knowingly obtains or exercises control over anything of value of another without authorization, or by threat or deception, and: 
(1)  Intends to deprive the other person permanently of the use or benefit of the thing of value; or 
(2)  Knowingly uses, conceals, or abandons the thing of value in such manner as to deprive the other person of its use or benefit; or 
(3)  Uses, conceals, or abandons the thing of value intending that such use, concealment or abandonment will deprive the other person permanently of its use and benefit; or 
(4)  Demands any consideration to which he is not legally entitled as a consideration of restoring a thing of value to the other person with a value of the thing involved is less than one thousand dollars. 
(b)  "Thing of value" as described in this section shall mean a thing with a value of less than one thousand dollars. 
(Ord. No. 707, § 2; Ord. No. 916 (part); amended by memo 3519; Ord. No. 1097 (part).) 
 For state law as to burglary, theft and robbery, see C.R.S. 1973, §§ 18-4-201 to 18-4-208.)  
Sec. 18-47. - Stones, snowballs, etc.—Throwing. 
It is unlawful for any person to knowingly or willingly throw any stone, snowball or any other missile upon or at any vehicle, building, tree or other public or private property, or upon or at any person in any public way or place, or enclosed or unenclosed ground. 
(Code 1968, § 11-4-17; Ord. No. 581, § 23.) 
 For state law as to throwing of missiles at vehicles, see C.R.S. 1973, § 18-9-117.  
Sec. 18-48. - Repealed April 13, 1982.  
Sec. 18-49. - Vendors—Obstructing sidewalk or other public place. 
It is unlawful for any person engaged in the sale of merchandise to obstruct any sidewalk or other public place unless granted written permission from the Cortez city council, or to disturb or impede others. 
(Code 1968, § 11-4-26; Ord. No. 581, § 25.)  
Sec. 18-50. - Unlawful to deposit refuse within city limits. 
It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to throw, deposit or place upon any sidewalk, alley, street or other public place, or upon private property without the consent of the owner, within the city, any empty bottles, cans, waste material, wastepaper, fruit, or vegetable skins or pulps and any and all forms of refuse, garbage, trash or waste material. 
(Ord. No. 560, § 1.)  
Sec. 18-51. - Theft of rental property. 
(a)  A person commits theft of rental property if he: 
(1)  Obtains the temporary use of personal property of another which is available only for hire, by means of threat or deception, or knowing that such use is without the consent of the person providing the personal property; or 
(2)  Having lawfully obtained possession for temporary use the personal property of another which is available only for hire, knowingly fails to reveal the whereabouts of or to return the property to the owner thereof or his representative, or to the person from whom he has received it within seventy-two hours after the time at which he agreed to return it. 
(b)  "Rental property" as described in this section shall mean rental property with a value of less than one thousand dollars. 
(Ord. No. 706, § 1; Ord. No. 916 (part); amended by memo 3519; Ord. No. 1097 (part).)  
Sec. 18-52. - Trespass. 
(a)  "Premises" as described herein means real property, buildings, and other improvements thereon. 
(b)  A person commits the crime of trespass if he unlawfully enters or remains in or upon the premises. 
(c)  Unlawful entry or remaining in or upon the premises shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Coming uninvited onto the private property of another; or 
(2)  Remaining thereon after being asked or ordered to leave by the owner, his agent or employee. 
(d)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as set forth in Cortez City Code Section 17-16A as now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 705, § 1; amended at city request, 3-07.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 18, 9-25-12)  
Sec. 18-52A. - Unlawful public trespass. 
(a)  Conduct denying lawful use of public building unlawful. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person to so conduct himself at or in any public building owned or operated or controlled by the city, the state or any of its political subdivisions, including the school district, as to wilfully deny to any public official, public employee or any invitee on such premises the lawful right of such official, employee or invitee to enter, use the facilities of or to leave any such public building. 
(2)  It is unlawful for any person at or in any such public building to wilfully impede any public official or employee in the lawful performance of duties or activities through the use of restraint, coercion or intimidation or by force and violence or threat thereof. 
(b)  Refusing or failing to leave public building unlawful when. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person to wilfully refuse or fail to leave any such public building upon being requested to do so by the chief administrative officer or designee charged with maintaining order in such public building if such person has committed, is committing, threatens to commit or incites to commit any act which did or would, if completed, disrupt, impair, interfere with or obstruct the lawful missions, processes, procedures or functions being carried on in such public building. 
(c)  Impeding or disrupting certain meetings in public buildings unlawful. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person at any meeting or session conducted by any judicial, legislative or administrative body or official at or in any public building to wilfully impede, disrupt or hinder the normal proceedings of such meeting or session by any act or intrusion into the chambers or other areas designated for the use of the body or official conducting such meeting or session or by any act designed to intimidate, coerce or hinder any member of such body or official engaged in the performance of duties of such meeting or mission. 
(d)  Interfering with use of public way or place unlawful. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person or persons to be upon any public way or any other place of public nature in such a manner as to wilfully interfere with the free and unobstructed use of such public way or place of public nature by any other person or persons. 
(e)  Definitions. 
(1)  This section shall be interpreted in such a manner as to be consistent with section 18-9-110, C.R.S., as amended, known as Public Buildings-Trespass, Interference Statute. The definitions provided in said statute shall be applied to this section. 
(f)  Penalty. 
(1)  A violation of this chapter shall be punishable as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(g)  Severability. 
(1)  Should any one or more sections of this section be judicially determined to be invalid or unenforceable, this section shall be interpreted, if possible, so that all other sections of said section remain valid and enforceable, it being the intent that the various provisions provided for herein are severable. 
(Ord. No. 792.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 19, 9-25-12)  
Sec. 18-53. - Passing bad checks. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to issue or pass a check as payment for any goods, services or other thing of value, or in exchange for cash when that person knew that, at the time of the issuance of the check, there were insufficient funds existing within the account being drawn upon to cover the check. For purposes of this section, the term "insufficient funds" means that a drawer has insufficient funds with the drawee to pay a check when the drawer has no checking account with the drawee or has funds in a checking account with a drawee in an amount less than the amount of the check plus the amount of all other checks outstanding at the time of issuance. A check dishonored for no account shall also be deemed to be dishonored for insufficient funds. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to issue or pass a check as payment for any goods, services or other things of value, or an exchange for cash, and to thereafter fail to tender sufficient funds to make the check good within fourteen days of notification from either the drawee upon which the check was drawn or from the person or firm to which the check was originally issued that the check has been twice refused for insufficient funds. It shall constitute a prima facie violation of this subsection that the firm or person to which the check was originally issued: 
(1)  Obtained photo identification from the drawer at the time of acceptance of the check; 
(2)  Obtained an address of the drawer of the check at the time of the acceptance of the check; 
(3)  Presented the check to the drawee for acceptance or refusal for the first time within thirty days of the date of issuance of the check; and 
(4)  Upon presenting the check to the drawee for collection and having twice received the check back for insufficient funds, the person or firm to whom the check was originally issued shall turn the insufficient fund check over to the Cortez police department for criminal prosecution. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to stop payment or cause payment to be stopped on any check issued or passed as payment for any goods, services or other thing of value, or in exchange for cash, when that person does so with the intent to defraud. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person to open a checking account, negotiable order or withdrawal account or share draft account using false identification or an assumed name, for the purpose of and with the intent of committing theft by check. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall apply where the value of the check exceeds one thousand dollars or where the offender is under accusation of formal criminal charges involving the issuance of two or more checks within any sixty-day period within the state with an aggregate value of one thousand dollars. 
(f)  A bank, savings and loan association, industrial bank or credit union shall not be civilly or criminally liable for releasing information relating to the drawer's account to any police authority or officer of the court provided the release of such information is for purposes of investigating or prosecuting a potential or alleged violation of this section. 
(g)  In imposing a penalty for violation of this section, the municipal court is specifically authorized and empowered to require restitution in full to the person or entity to whom any such check described in this section was issued as a portion of, or in addition to, any penalty deemed appropriate by the court. 
(Ord. No. 726; Ord. No. 900; amended by memo 3519; Ord. No. 1097 (part).)  
Sec. 18-54. - Conduct on public property. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to enter or remain in any public building or on any public property, or to conduct himself in or on the same in violation of any order, rule, or regulation concerning any matters described in this subsection. In addition to any authority granted by any other law, each resolution may adopt such rules, orders or regulations as are reasonably necessary for the administration, protection and maintenance of such buildings and property, specifically rules, orders and regulations upon the following matters: 
(1)  Preservation of property, vegetation, wildlife, signs, markers, statutes, buildings, grounds and other structures, and any object of scientific, historic, or scenic interest; 
(2)  Restrictions or limitations of the use of such public buildings or property as to time, manner or permitted activities; 
(3)  Prohibition of activities or conduct within public buildings or on public property, which may be reasonably expected to substantially interfere with the use and enjoyment of such places by others, or may constitute a general nuisance; 
(4)  Camping, picnicking, public meetings and assemblage, and other individual or group usage, including the time, place and manner in which such activities may be permitted; 
(5)  Use of all vehicles as the time, place and manner of use; 
(6)  Control and limitation of fires and the designation of fires where fires are permitted. 
(b)  No conviction may be obtained under this section unless notice of such limitations or prohibitions is prominently posted at all public entrances to such buildings or property, or unless such notice is actually first given the person by the appropriate city official, or by any law enforcement officer, having jurisdiction or authority to enforce this section. 
(Ord. No. 950; amended by memo 3519.)  
Sec. 18-55. - Unlawful sale, cultivation, manufacture, testing of retail marijuana or medical marijuana. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of the Cortez City Code when any person violates any of the rules of regulations adopted by the state of Colorado regarding the sale, cultivation, manufacture or testing of medical marijuana or retail marijuana or any city of Cortez rules and regulations adopted by ordinance or resolution for the regulation of retail marijuana or medical marijuana sales, cultivation, manufacturing or testing of medical marijuana or retail marijuana. 
(b)  It shall be illegal to cultivate marijuana, of any type retail, medical or for personal use outdoors. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall have a civil penalty and not be subject to a jail sentence, the fine for a violation of Cortez City Code section 18-55 shall be four hundred ninety-nine dollars. 
( Ord. No. 1194, 9-23-14 ; Ord. No. 1201, 8-25-15 ) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1194, adopted September 23, 2014, repealed the former § 18-55, and enacted a new § 18-55 as set out herein. The former § 18-55 pertained to unlawful possession or sale of marijuana and derived from Ord. No. 1166, adopted May 22, 2012.  
Sec. 18-56. - Marijuana, possession, consumption of marijuana on city property. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Marijuana or marihuana whenever used in the Cortez City Code means all parts of the plant of the genus cannabis whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of the plant, and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the plant, its seeds, or its resin, including marihuana concentrate. "Marijuana" or "marihuana" does not include industrial hemp, nor does it include fiber produced from the stalks, oil, or cake made from the seeds of the plant, sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination, or the weight of any other ingredient combined with marijuana to prepare topical or oral administrations, food, drink, or other product. 
(2)  City property shall include, but is not limited to, all real estate owned occupied or used by the city such as City Hall, all parks and other facilities, trails, river property, streets and sidewalks, etc. Whether located in the city limits or not. 
(3)  City means the city of Cortez. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, consume, use, display, transfer, distribute, sell, transport or grow any marijuana or marijuana products as defined in paragraph (a) above on city property as defined above. Except that the transportation of small amounts of marijuana (one ounce or less and up to six plants) of marijuana as defined in paragraph (a) above shall be allowed on city streets and sidewalks. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as set forth in chapter 17 section 17-16A, sentencing, municipal court, Cortez City Code now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1174, 2-12-13)  
Sec. 18-57. - Underage consumption/possession of marijuana. 
(a)  Any person age eighteen to twenty years of age who possesses, consumes, uses, displays, transfers, distributes, sells, or grows marijuana or marihuana as defined in Cortez City Code section 18-56(a)(1) definitions, in the city of Cortez commits illegal possession or consumption of marijuana by an underage person. 
Illegal possession or consumption of marijuana by an underage person is a strict liability offense. 
(b)  Illegal possession or consumption of marijuana by an underage person shall be punished as set forth in section 17-16A, sentencing, municipal court, Cortez City Code now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. The court, upon sentencing a defendant pursuant to this paragraph (b), may, in addition to any fine, suspend jail time on condition that the defendant submit to and complete a substance abuse or assessment, a substance abuse education program, or a substance abuse program at such defendant's own expense. 
(c)  Prima facie evidence of a violation of subsection (a) of this section shall consist of: 
(1)  Evidence that the defendant was age eighteen to twenty years of age and possessed, consumed, used, displayed, transferred, distributed, sold or grew marijuana as defined in Cortez City Code section 18-56(a)(1) anywhere in the city of Cortez; or 
(2)  Evidence that the defendant was age eighteen to twenty years of age and manifested any of the characteristics commonly associated with marijuana consumption, or impairment, or is under the influence of marijuana while present anywhere in the city of Cortez. 
(d)  The qualitative result of a marijuana test or tests shall be admissible at the trial of any person charged with a violation of subsection (a) of this section upon a showing that the device or devices used to conduct such test or tests have been approved as accurate in detecting marijuana by the executive director of the appropriate state department which regulates marijuana detection testing. 
(e)  In any judicial proceeding in the Cortez Municipal Court concerning a charge of underage possession/consumption, the court shall take judicial notice of methods of testing a person's blood, breath, saliva, or urine for the presence of marijuana and of the design and operation of devices certified by the department of public health and environment or other state agency in charge of marijuana detection testing standards for testing a person's blood, breath, saliva, or urine for the presence of marijuana. This subsection shall not prevent the necessity of establishing during a trial that the testing devices were working properly and that such testing devices were properly operated. Nothing in this subsection shall preclude a defendant from offering evidence concerning the accuracy of testing devices. 
(f)  No law enforcement officer shall enter upon any private property to investigate any violation of this section without probable cause. 
A violation of this section shall be punishable as set forth in chapter 17 section 17-16A, sentencing, municipal court, Cortez City Code now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1174, 2-12-13)  
Sec. 18-58. - Prohibition of clubs or other places for the consumption of marijuana. 
(a)  It shall be illegal to consume marijuana as defined in Cortez City Code section 18-56(a)(1) in any marijuana smoking club or other place as defined in subsection (b) below. 
(b)  Definitions. Marijuana smoking club means any place where people pay a membership or other fee to consume marijuana as defined in Cortez City Code section 18-56(a)(1). This includes but is not limited to commercial operations, private groups or any organization which allows for the consumption of marijuana on its premises. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punished as set forth in chapter 17 section 17-16A, sentencing, municipal court, Cortez City Code now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1174, 2-12-13) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1174, adopted February 12, 2013, set out provisions intended for use as § 18-57. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 18-58.  
Sec. 18-59. - Occupation of recreational vehicles or park trailers on private property. 
(a)  Definitions. Recreational vehicle (RV) or park trailer when used in this Cortez City Code section shall have the same meaning as defined in the city of Cortez Land Use Code section 2.02, definitions. 
(b)  No owner of real property or any other person shall occupy or permit to be occupied any recreational vehicle or park trailer on private property within the city of Cortez except in those RV and manufactured home parks approved by the city of Cortez. 
An RV or park trailer may be occupied on private property for a period of less than thirty days during any calendar year by out of town guests or family. 
(c)  It shall be rebuttable presumption that an RV or park trailer is occupied or in use, in violation of this code section, if the recreational vehicle or park trailer is connected to electrical or water supplies or sewer line located on the real property where the RV or park trailer is located, if auxiliary fuel tanks, other than those provided with the trailer, extended awnings, the set up of tables and chairs outside the RV or park trailer and the use of interior lights within the RV or park trailer or any other signs of occupation are observed. 
(d)  This section may be enforced by the Cortez City Police Department, Cortez Code Enforcement Officers, the planning and building department and any other city employees authorized by the city manager. 
(e)  A violation of this code section shall be punished by a fine of up to five hundred dollars. 
In addition to the penalty specified in subsection (e) above. The city of Cortez Municipal Court Judge may issue any orders necessary to ensure compliance with this ordinance including but not limited to suspended fines and jail sentences, cease and desist orders, and orders for the removal of recreational vehicles or park trailers not owned by the property owner from the real property, or removal from city right-of-ways, streets and alleys and other city property. 
(f)  Each day a violation or non-compliance exists shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 1179, 6-11-13) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1179, adopted June 11, 2013, set out provisions intended for use as § 18-56. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 18-59.  
Sec. 18-60. - Unauthorized dumping in trash receptacles/dumpsters 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, and it is a theft of services to throw, deposit, or place without the consent of the owner or authorized user of any dumpster or trash receptacle, any refuse, rubbish, ruin, solid waste, weed, wreckage, yard waste, combustible trash, ashes or any other waste material in any dumpster or trash receptacle located within the city of Cortez. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings as set forth in section 22B-1 Definitions: Ashes, brush, combustible trash, garbage, hazardous waste, litter, recyclable material, refuse, rubbish, ruins, solid waste, weed, wreckage, yard waste. 
(c)  Any person, firm, association, or corporation who violates this section shall be guilty of a municipal offense and shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A as now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
( Ord. No. 1187, 5-13-14 )  
CHAPTER 18A. - PARKING, STANDING, KEEPING AND STORING INOPERABLE VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 18A-1. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter: 
Antique vehicles. Any vehicle which is currently licensed as an antique by the state, or for which an application for registration as such is pending. This definition shall include cars which can be licensed with collector's license plates and/or street rod license plates. 
Inoperable vehicle. A vehicle in a condition of being junked, wrecked, wholly or partially dismantled, discarded, abandoned or unable to perform the functions for which it was originally constructed. 
Permanent fence. A fence of durable nature conforming to city ordinances and construction in such a manner so as to shield or conceal the area contained within the fence from public view. 
Person. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Property. Any real property within the City which is not a street or highway. 
Storage. The use of property for the purpose of keeping a vehicle thereon which is not in use by the owner thereof, or any other person. It shall be prima facie evidence that a vehicle is being stored if it has not been moved from its position on the property in the sixty days previous to the date of notice of noncompliance. 
Street or highway. The entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
Vehicle. A machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel on the road by using wheels, treads, runners or slides to transport persons or property or pull machinery and includes without limitation automobiles, airplanes, trucks, trailers, motorcycles, motorscooters, tractors, buggies and wagons. The term "vehicle" does not include antique vehicles as defined in this section. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1; Ord. No. 789, §§ 1, 2.)  
Sec. 18A-2. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  From and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter it is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to park or leave standing upon any public street, alley or thoroughfare within the city, an inoperable vehicle as the same is herein defined for a period of longer than twenty-four hours. 
(b)  From and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, it is unlawful for any person being the owner of, lessee of, renter or in custody of any inoperable vehicle to permit the same to remain upon private property within the city, for a period of more than thirty days after such owner, lessee, renter or custodian of the private property has been notified to remove the same. Such act is prohibited whether the inoperable vehicle is stored or parked upon private property belonging to the owner, lessee, renter or custodian of such inoperable vehicle or upon private premises belonging to another person, firm or corporation. 
(c)  From and after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter it is unlawful for the owner, lessee, renter or person in charge of any private property within the city, to suffer or permit the storing, keeping or standing of any inoperable vehicle upon such private property for a period of more than thirty days after the notice is given in the form and manner as set forth in this chapter, whether the inoperable vehicle is the property of such owner or not. 
(d)  It shall be prohibited to store any car on any private residential property even though said vehicle is operable. It shall be prima facie evidence that a car is being stored on private property if the vehicle does not have a current Colorado license plate. 
(e)  It shall be prohibited to store any car on any street within this city, even though said vehicle is operable. It shall be prima facie evidence that a vehicle is being stored on the street if the vehicle does not have a current Colorado license plate. 
Upon forty-eight hours' notification in writing that the vehicle is in violation of this section, the car will be towed and stored at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 2; Ord. No. 789 §§ 3—5; Ord. No. 833 (part).)  
Sec. 18A-3. - Exclusions and permits. 
(a)  This chapter shall not apply to a vehicle in an enclosed building; to vehicles being stored by a business enterprise, as long as the storage of the vehicle is on the same premises where the business is being conducted; or a vehicle being stored by any law enforcement agency in a storage place kept for that purpose. 
(b)  This chapter shall not apply to the storage of a vehicle or parts thereof on private property, provided such vehicle and parts of cars and the outdoor storage areas are maintained in such a manner that they do not constitute a health hazard, a safety hazard or a fire hazard and are effectively screened from ordinary public view by means of a permanent fence. Such storage area shall be kept free of weeds, trash and other objectionable items. 
(c)  Permits. If a notice of noncompliance has been given as set forth herein the vehicle owner may apply to the chief of police or his designee for a one time, nonrenewable permit to extend the period to achieve compliance for an additional sixty days if: 
(1)  There is an ongoing dispute over insurance coverage as to a wrecked or damaged vehicle which has not been totally destroyed by the wreck or accident; 
(2)  The owner is doing vehicle repairs which can reasonably be completed within the sixty-day period. 
Such permit shall clearly state that it is nonrenewable, set forth the penalties for noncompliance and the other remedies available to the city. If compliance is not achieved by the owner by the fiftieth day, the city shall provide written notice that if such compliance is not achieved by the date that ends the compliance period, the city will commence legal proceedings, including but not limited to, filing a misdemeanor complaint in the municipal court. 
There shall be no charge for the permit. The issuance of the permit herein shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 3; Ord. No. 789 §§ 6—8.)  
Sec. 18A-4. - Notice—Form and contents. 
(a)  The notice to be given to the owner of such vehicle and the owner of the private premises upon which the same is stored or kept, shall be in such form as shall be prescribed by the city manager, but such notice shall provide, at least, the name of the reputed owner, a description of the inoperable vehicle, the description of the premises upon which the same is stored or kept, and a demand that the same is removed no later than thirty days following the date of such notice. 
(b)  In the event the owner of the private property upon which vehicle is stored or kept is also the owner of the inoperable vehicle, only one notice shall be sent. 
(c)  All notices shall be sent by first class mail, and shall be mailed to the address of such person, if such address is known, or to the address of such person as reflected by the records of the county clerk and recorder of the county or the county assessor of the county. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 4; Ord. No. 833 (part).)  
Sec. 18A-5. - Posting of notice. 
In the event the letter is returned by the post office unclaimed or for any reason undeliverable, then a copy of the notice shall be posted in the city clerk's office on a bulletin board to be kept by the city clerk for that purpose and upon the inoperable vehicle in question. The notice is to be posted for a period of thirty consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 5; Ord. No. 789 § 9.)  
Sec. 18A-6. - Right of removal. 
(a)  In the event the owner of the motor vehicle or the owner, lessee, tenant or person in charge of the personal property upon which the same is stored does not remove the offending vehicle within thirty days after date of mailing of the notice or within thirty days from date of posting of the notice as provided in this chapter, the city manager or his representative shall have the right to go upon the private premises and to remove the offending vehicle and to impound the same for a period of thirty days from and after the date of such removal. 
(b)  Any police officer of the city shall have the right to remove or cause to be removed any inoperable vehicle left on a public street, alley or thoroughfare after the same has been left thereon for more than twenty-four hours. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 6; Ord. No. 789 § 10.)  
Sec. 18A-7. - Right to reclaim. 
For a period of thirty days following the impounding of the vehicle, the owner thereof may reclaim the vehicle by paying to the city all costs involved in the removal and storage of the motor vehicle; provided, that the vehicle so reclaimed may not thereafter be stored at any place within the city in violation of this chapter. In the event a summons and complaint has been issued by the municipal court of the city and the owner thereof or the owner of private property upon which the same was stored shall be convicted for violation of this chapter then prior to the reclamation of said vehicle by the owner, such fine imposed by the court shall be first paid. 
(Ord. No. 558, § 7.)  
Sec. 18A-8. - Disposition of unclaimed vehicle. 
After the passage of thirty days from date of impoundment, and if the vehicle is not reclaimed by the owner as provided in this chapter, the owner of the vehicle, if known, shall be notified by registered mail (return receipt requested) that the vehicle shall be disposed of by either public or private sale on a date certain. The internal administration and procedures of the entire private or public sale process shall conform with the applicable subsections of Colorado Revised Statutes § 42-4-1103. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 9.)  
Sec. 18A-9. - Violation—Penalty. 
In addition to the right of the city to remove any offending vehicle as provided in this chapter, any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall upon conviction thereof be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A, penalty as now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 8; amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 20, 9-25-12)  
Chapter 18B. - OFFENSES—JUVENILE 
 
Sec. 18B-1. - Juvenile offenders—Definitions. 
As used in this chapter unless a context otherwise requires; 
Child. A person who has reached the age of ten years and is under eighteen years of age at the time of the alleged offense. 
Parent. Either a natural parent of a child as may be established pursuant to article VI of title 19 of the Colorado Revised Statutes, 1973, as amended, or a parent by adoption. 
(Ord. No. 776, (part).)  
Sec. 18B-2. - Duty of parent—Appearance in court. 
(a)  Whenever a summons and complaint under this Code is filed against a child, the court shall send a parent or guardian, by first class mail, a notice that includes the alleged violation, date of violation, location at which the alleged violation occurred and the date, time and place of the scheduled court appearance and an order that the parent or guardian appear with the minor at each and every court appearance. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of a parent or guardian to appear with the child at each and every court appearance. It shall be unlawful for a parent to fail to appear at each and every required court appearance or fail to comply with the written promise to appear with the child, and a violation of the same may be punished by a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars and/or not more than ninety days in jail. It shall be an affirmative defense to this violation if the parent demonstrates to the court that at the time of the offense either (1) the parent(s) did not have lawful custody of the minor; (2) the minor was not residing with the parent(s); (3) the minor was emancipated or (4) if the parent(s) can demonstrate that the juvenile was uncontrollable. 
(Ord. No. 776, (part).)  
Sec. 18B-3. - Responsibility of parents for payment of fine. 
(a)  Whenever a minor under the age of eighteen years of age, residing or living with his/her parent(s), is convicted of an offense under this Code for which the court imposes a fine, restitution or court fees or costs, the parent of the minor child shall be jointly responsible of payment for such fine, restitution or court fees or costs. It shall be an affirmative defense to the obligation created by this section if the parents demonstrate to the court that at the time of the offense either (1) the parent(s) did not have lawful custody of the minor; (2) the minor was not residing with the parent(s); (3) the minor was emancipated or (4) if the parent(s) can demonstrate that the juvenile was uncontrollable. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section only, an "emancipated minor" means a minor over fifteen years of age and under eighteen years of age who has, with real or apparent assent of his/her parent(s), demonstrated his/her independence from his/her parent(s) in the matter of care, custody and earnings. The term may include, but shall not be limited to, any such minor who has the sole responsibility for his/her own support, who is married or who is in the military. Failure to pay any court-ordered fine, restitution, or court fees or costs shall be subject to the contempt powers of the city municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 776, (part).)  
Sec. 18B-4. - Appointment of counsel. 
If a child has been brought before the court for an offense of the Municipal Code that for an adult is punishable by a jail sentence; (a) the child or his/her parent(s) may request an attorney and if the child or parent(s) fail to have sufficient financial means, counsel shall be appointed by the court; or (b) the court may appoint counsel without such request if it deems representation by counsel is necessary to protect the interest of the child or other parties. 
(Ord. No. 776, (part).)  
Sec. 18B-5. - Hearing procedures. 
The general public shall not be excluded unless the court makes a specific finding that it is in the best interest of the child to exclude the general public, and in such event the court shall admit only such persons who have an interest in the case or the work of the court, including persons who the parent(s) wish to have present. Hearings may be continued from time to time as ordered by the court. 
(Ord. No. 776, (part): Ord. No. 1033.)  
Sec. 18B-6. - Issue of summons, complaint and custody. 
A member of the Cortez police department shall be empowered to issue a summons and complaint to a child for any violation of this Code. If, in the opinion of the officer, the issuance of the summons and complaint is not adequate to ensure that a child will answer charges under this Code, and the officer finds it necessary to take the child into custody, the child's custody shall conform to applicable state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 776, (part).)  
Sec. 18B-7. - Juvenile warrant. 
(a)  Any arrest warrant issued by the municipal court for a child shall bear a conspicuous notation that the arrestee is a child and the provisions of the applicable state statutes must be observed in the execution of the warrant. 
(b)  Whenever a child is arrested, the arresting officer shall notify the parent(s) without unnecessary delay. Such notification may be made to a person with whom the child is residing if the parent, guardian or legal custodian cannot be located. 
(Ord. No. 776, (part).)  
Sec. 18B-8. - Incarceration of child. 
(a)  No jail sentence shall be imposed upon persons under the age of eighteen years who have been convicted of a violation under this Code. 
(b)  Incarceration not to exceed forty-eight hours may be imposed on a child for failure to comply with a lawful order of the court, including an order to pay a fine. Any incarceration of a child shall be in compliance with section 19-2-204(4) C.R.S. 
(Ord. No. 776, (part), 1993.)  
Sec. 18B-9. - Juvenile sentencing. 
Upon the conviction of a violation of the Cortez City Code a juvenile as defined herein shall be subject to the penalties as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A and may also be ordered at sentencing to perform community service as a condition of any suspended sentence. Any costs imposed to perform community service shall be the responsibility of the juvenile and/or his parents and included in the fines and costs assessed by the court at sentencing. 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 21, 9-25-12) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1170, § 21, adopted September 25, 2012, repealed the former § 18B-9, and enacted a new § 18B-9 as set out herein. The former 18B-9 pertained to fine, court fees and costs and derived from Ord. No. 776, 1993 and amended by memo 3519.  
CHAPTER 18C. - RESERVED.[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1216 , adopted September 27, 2016, repealed Chapter 18C, §§ 18C-1—18C-3, which pertained to prohibition of nighttime juvenile loitering and derived from Ord. No. 784; amended by memo 3519 and Ord. No. 1170, adopted September 25, 2012. 
 
Sec. 18D-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
Yard/garage sale. A retail sale of personal property conducted by the occupant of a single-family residence or the owner/manager of a multi-family residence. There shall be no limitations on the number of individuals who can participate in the yard sales, as sellers. The term shall include all sales entitled "yard sale," "garage sale," "lawn sale," "attic sale," "patio sale," "rummage sale," or other similar sales of tangible personal property which are advertised by a sign or other means for the public to attend. Such sales are subject to the following limitations: 
(a)  Yard/garage sales shall be limited to the residential zone districts, including the R-1, R-2, NB and MH. 
(b)  Yard/garage sales shall be limited to the principal or accessory structure and the driveway of the dwelling. 
(c)  Each yard/garage sale shall be limited to no more than three consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 1005 (part).)  
Sec. 18D-2. - No permit required. 
No sales tax license will be required provided the following conditions are met: 
(a)  The person conducting the yard sale has not participated in more than two yard sales in any calendar year at that specific location subsequent to the passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(b)  The conduct of yard sales as a fundraiser for civil or charitable purposes shall not be limited by this Code as to location, so long as the location does not constitute a hazard to safety and is not in violation of any existing municipal code. 
(Ord. No. 1005 (part).)  
Sec. 18D-3. - Signs. 
All persons are permitted to direct signs advertising a yard sale in public rights-of-way, provided the signs meet the following requirements: 
(a)  Do not exceed eighteen inches by eighteen inches; 
(b)  Bear the name and address of the person holding the yard sale and date of sale; 
(c)  Are not placed on a traffic regulatory device or municipal utility structure; 
(d)  Do not obstruct traffic view or hinder municipal operations; and 
(e)  It shall be prima facie evidence that the party identified on the signs has placed the signs in the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 1005 (part).)  
Sec. 18D-4. - Unlawful acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any yard sale sign to be posted more than three days prior to the date of the yard sale. The sign shall be removed not later than the date after the last day of the yard sale. 
(Ord. No. 1005 (part).)  
Sec. 18D-5. - Violation penalty. 
A violation of this chapter shall be punishable as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A as now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1005 (part); amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 24, 9-25-12)  
CHAPTER 19. - PARKS AND RECREATION. 
 
Sec. 19-1. - Establishment and duties of parks and recreation department. 
There is hereby established the parks and recreation department of the city. The parks and recreation department shall have the management, control and supervision of all facilities, public parks, fields, tracts and areas of the city used for recreation purposes both within and without its corporate limits, as well as the center parkings in the streets and avenues and such other areas as may be designated from time to time by the council, and shall administer all recreation programs sponsored by the city. 
A parks and recreation director shall be appointed by the city manager and shall have the duty to administer the parks and recreation department as established. The parks and recreation director may appoint one or more authorized representatives to administer any part of the duties of this chapter. Both the director of parks and recreation and his authorized representatives shall be hereinafter referred to as "director" for the purposes of this chapter. The parks and recreation department shall hereinafter be referred to as "department." 
"Park" or "parks," as used in this chapter, means all athletic fields, parks, playgrounds, tracts, recreational facilities and areas of the city administered or regulated by the city and used for recreational purposes. These areas include the city pool, the golf course, all picnic areas, tennis courts, athletic fields used for softball, baseball, soccer or other sports, now owned or hereafter acquired. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part))  
Sec. 19-2. - Generally—Parks and recreation areas. 
(a)  Presence in parks. Parks will be open daily from 6:00 A.M. to 11:00 P.M. The director may extend the closing time to 12:00 midnight for such parks, playgrounds and athletic areas equipped with general athletic lighting. The director may also specify exceptions for specific parks from the above-scheduled open and closing times. If open and closing times for a specific park, athletic field, playground etc. are different than the times above specified, the applicable open and closed times for that particular park, athletic field or playground shall be prominently posted at that particular park, athletic field or playground location. 
Law enforcement personnel, emergency service personnel, authorized municipal employees, and security personnel employed for special functions are exempt from the provisions of this section. 
Loitering in the park between the hours of 11:00 P.M. and 6:00 A.M. for the purpose of consuming alcohol, purchasing or selling narcotics, the use of narcotics or disturbing the peace is prohibited. 
(b)  Riding vehicles on grounds of municipal parks, etc. No person shall at any time drive or ride any automobile, truck, motorcycle, motor scooter or other motor vehicle upon the grounds of any municipal park, playground or golf course, except in public streets running through such premises or within designated parking areas or sidewalks located upon such premises, without the express written permission of the director. 
(c)  Swimming, wading and boating in parks. Boating allowed at Denny Lake Park and Geer Natural Area, no person shall swim, wade or operate a boat upon any lake, lagoon or other water facilities located in any city park or other areas under the supervision of the department without the express written permission of the director. Non-motorized boats are permitted at Denny Lake Park and Geer Natural Area. 
(d)  Damaging, tampering with, etc., facilities. No person shall damage or wastefully or improperly use toilet, water and sewer facilities in any municipal park, or cause the lighting facilities or electrical appliances to be turned on or used without appropriate fees and/or reservation or the express written permission of the director. The city may charge fees for athletic lighting, to be determined on an annual basis. 
(e)  Golfing in parks and on city-owned property. No person shall use any portions of any city park or city-owned property for golfing purposes, or make use of any golf club or golf ball in any city park or on city-owned property, except at places designated for golfing by the director. 
(f)  Public meetings in parks. It is unlawful to hold any public meetings, addressed by one or more speakers and attended by twenty-five or more persons, within the parks of the city unless and until a permit therefore, pursuant to section 19-7 of this chapter, has been issued by the director. Such meetings shall be conducted in an orderly and law-abiding manner. 
(g)  Intoxicating beverages. No person shall have in their possession, nor will any person consume any form of alcoholic beverage within the parks of the city, except as provided in this chapter for the golf course and authorized special events. 
(h)  Loud noises, disturbances prohibited. No person or persons shall play any radio, tape players, band or musical instrument, television, phonograph, tape recorder or other device capable of reproducing sound at such a high volume in any municipal park or recreation area as to disturb the peace and quiet of another. There shall be no loud, or band music, or excessive noise beyond 9:00 P.M. or before 9:00 A.M., without the express written consent of the director. 
(i)  Animals in parks. Dogs and cats must be on a leash at all times except when participating in obedience classes or other activities authorized by the director. Horses shall use only bridle paths designated by posted notices. No other animals shall be allowed on the grounds of parks, playground or golf courses without the express written consent of the director. 
(j)  Overnight camping. No person or group of persons shall be allowed to camp overnight on any park grounds or parking areas without the express written consent of the director. 
(k)  Garbage and trash. No person shall dump, spill, deposit, place, throw or leave refuse, rubbish, filthy or odor-causing objects, substances or other trash upon any municipal park grounds except in identified trash receptacles. 
(l)  Sales advertising in parks and recreation areas. 
(1)  Sales, displays prohibited. It is unlawful for any person in a park or recreation area to expose or offer for sale any article, substance or thing, legal or illegal, or to station or place any stand, cart or vehicle for the transportation, sale of display of any such article, substance or thing, except any regularly licensed concessionaire acting by and under the written authority of the director or a concession agreement executed by the city: and any nonprofit or charitable organization acting under the written authority of the director. 
(2)  Advertising prohibited.
