It is unlawful for any person in a park or recreation area to announce, advertise or call the public's attention in any way to an article or service for sale or hire, except any regularly licensed concessionaire acting by and under the written authority of the director or a concession agreement executed by the city; and any nonprofit or charitable organization acting under the written authority of the director. 
(3)  Sale or offering of personal services is prohibited. It is unlawful for any person in a park or recreation facility to offer for sale or trade any personal service to be conducted on park or recreation facilities, except any regularly licensed concessionaire acting by and under the written authority of the director or a concession agreement executed by the city; and any nonprofit or charitable organization acting under the written authority of the director. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part); Ord. No. 869, § 1; Ord. No. 1112 (part).) 
(Ord. No. 1147, 11-23-10; Ord. No. 1199, 5-26-15 )  
Sec. 19-3. - Rules and regulations generally—Tennis courts. 
(a)  No person shall operate skateboards, roller skates, bicycles, motorized cycles or any other form of wheeled vehicle on tennis courts. Tennis courts shall be used exclusively for the purpose of playing tennis. Lights shall be turned off at 11:00 P.M. on all municipal tennis courts. 
(b)  Special reserved playing times for city-sponsored tennis tournaments, tennis lessons and school district tennis practice are provided at the express written consent of the director. Fees for this special reserved playing time shall be set annually, or before such special event, by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  Intoxicating beverages. No person shall have in their possession, nor shall any person consume, any form of alcoholic beverage at the municipal tennis courts. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part).)  
Sec. 19-3a. - Rules and regulations generally—Skateboard park. 
(a)  The exclusive use of the skateboard park shall be for the use of in-line skates, skateboards, scooters, bicycles and any other form of non-motorized, wheeled vehicle approved by the director. No person shall operate motorized cycles, any non approved form of wheeled vehicle or any other form of motorized wheeled vehicle in the skateboard park. Lights shall be turned off at 11:00 P.M. at the skateboard park. 
(b)  Intoxicating beverages. No person shall have in their possession, nor shall any person consume any form of alcoholic beverage at the skateboard park. 
(Ord. No. 924.) 
(Ord. No. 1147, 11-23-10)  
Sec. 19-4. - Rules and regulations generally—Swimming pool. 
(a)  No person shall swim in, or enter any fenced area around, any swimming pool owned or operated by the city at any time the pool is not staffed and open to the public without written permission of the director. 
(b)  Reserved times for pool rental and swim meets are established by the director and fees for these reserved times shall be set annually. 
(c)  Intoxicating beverages. No person shall have in their possession, nor shall any person consume, any form of alcoholic beverage within the municipal swimming pool complex. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part).) 
(Ord. No. 1147, 11-23-10)  
Sec. 19-5. - Rules and regulations generally—Athletic fields. 
(a)  Non-fenced athletic fields will be open for public use between the hours of 6:00 A.M. and 11:00 P.M. Fenced athletic fields must be reserved and a permit issued for the reservation. 
(b)  Athletic fields may be reserved for tournaments, games and practices. Tournaments, games and practices held on a continuing basis are given preference over new tournaments, games and practices. 
(c)  Fees for athletic field use shall be set annually by resolution of the council. 
(d)  Intoxicating beverages. No person shall have in their possession, nor shall any person consume, any form of alcoholic beverage within the athletic fields located within the city limits unless proper permits are obtained. 
(e)  Rules and regulations regarding the softball leagues and play shall be promulgated by the director. Individuals or teams who violate these regulations may be evicted from any city-owned softball facility or field and may be denied use of or access to city softball facilities or to other city athletic facilities. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part).) 
(Ord. No. 1147, 11-23-10)  
Sec. 19-6. - Rules and regulations generally—Cortez Municipal Golf Course. 
(a)  Golf season. The "golf season" is hereby to open on March 1st and close on November 15th, weather permitting, and: 
(1)  The golf course shall be open from 7:00 A.M. to sundown. The pro shop will be open from 7:00 A.M. to 7:00 P.M. (May to September) and primarily 8:30 A.M. to 5:00 P.M., weather dependent, during other open times; 
(2)  The interior of the golf course is closed from approximately November 15th to March 1st to all use, depending upon weather. However, the perimeter cart pathway may be used for walking and/or cross country skiing during the closed months of the golf course; 
(3)  Nine holes may be closed for maintenance purposes for a short period of time at the discretion of the golf course superintendent; 
(4)  The opening and closing of the golf course will be decided by the golf course professional and the golf course superintendent. The director will make the final decision if the golf course professional and the superintendent are in disagreement. 
(b)  Golf professional. The golf professional (pro) is the authority for the general management, operation and improvement of the golf pro shop during the term of their contract. The city shall employ a golf course superintendent, course personnel, and shall provide the operating budget for the maintenance and upkeep of the course. The pro is responsible for providing all the services at the golf course including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Golf lessons; 
(2)  Driving range; 
(3)  Golf club rental; 
(4)  Pull cart rental; 
(5)  Self-propelled cart rental; 
(6)  Food services; 
(7)  Liaison with men's and women's golf associations; 
(8)  Supervision of golf tournaments; 
(9)  Supervision of junior golf programs. 
(c)  Fees. Fees will be set yearly by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Golf advisory board . 
(1)  Board created, appointment, qualifications and terms of members. There is created a golf advisory board for the city consisting of five voting members, one member of which shall be a city council person, three members of which shall be residents of either Cortez or Montezuma County, and one member shall be a high school youth, and shall be appointed by the city council in the following manner and for the following terms: 
(A)  The members of the board shall be appointed by the council to serve terms as follows: One member at large from either Cortez or Montezuma County shall serve a three-year term; one member to be nominated by the men's golf association board who shall be a member of that association from either Cortez or Montezuma County and will serve for one year; and one member to be nominated by the women's golf association board who shall be a member of that association from either Cortez or Montezuma County and will serve for one year; and one member to be a high school youth and will serve for one year. As the term of each member expires, the vacancy thus created shall be filled by a majority vote of the council for a term equal to the position being vacated. If a vacancy occurs other than by expiration of term, the council, by a majority vote, shall appoint a new member to fill the unexpired term. 
(B)  The four remaining members of the advisory board shall be ex officio members without vote and shall consist of the mayor of the city, the director, who shall serve as secretary of the board, the golf pro, and the golf course superintendent. 
(2)  Absence from meetings. Should a member be absent for three consecutive regular meetings of such advisory board without cause, the office of such member shall be deemed to be vacant and the term of such member terminated, and the secretary of the advisory board shall immediately inform the city council of such termination. An absence due to illness or an unavoidable absence from the city, and notice thereof to the secretary of the advisory board on or before the day of any regular meeting by such advisory board, shall be deemed absence for cause. A regular meeting as provided for by law or rule of the advisory board or any regularly advertised public hearing shall be deemed a regular meeting. 
(3)  Election and term of chairperson; creation and filling of other offices. The advisory board shall elect its chairperson from among the appointed members and shall create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of the chairperson shall be one year with the eligibility for reelection. The position of chairperson shall be filled at the first regular meeting of each year. 
(4)  Regular meetings; calling of special meetings. The advisory board shall hold at least one regular meeting in each month during the months of March through October of each year, and such special meetings as are necessary in the opinion of the chairperson; provided, that a special meeting may be called by any three members of the advisory board or the city manager and/or the director upon due notice to the chairperson and the other members of the advisory board. 
(5)  Adoption of procedural rules; records. The advisory board shall adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep a record of its meetings, resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a public record. 
(6)  Majority vote required for recommendation, extension or amendment of plans. In voting upon the recommendation of any plan or any part thereof or any amendment, extension or addition by resolution of the advisory board, the same must be carried by the affirmative vote of a simple majority of the entire voting membership of the advisory board. 
(7)  Powers and duties generally. The advisory board shall perform the following duties: 
(A)  Make regular visits to the golf course, i.e., touring course in carts and playing the course; 
(B)  Bring comments, complaints and suggestions to the advisory board and act as a liaison to the city council; 
(C)  The chairperson should stay in regular communication with the director; 
(D)  Help to promote and advertise the golf course; 
(E)  Review all tournaments and tournament dates; 
(F)  Review and recommend to the council golf course rules and regulations for incorporation into applicable ordinances and resolutions; 
(G)  Advise and make recommendations concerning agreements with and hiring of a golf pro; 
(H)  Review and recommend to the council a master plan for the continued development and improvement of the golf course; 
(I)  Upon referral by the director the advisory board shall review cases of habitual offenders continually violating course rules and/or etiquette and help determine a course of action for the director to implement. 
(e)  Open play. Open play rules and regulations shall be as follows: 
(1)  Register in the pro shop before starting play. 
(2)  Replace divots and repair ball marks on the greens. 
(3)  Appropriate attire is required. 
(4)  Each player must have set of clubs. 
(5)  Groups of more than a foursome must have permission from the pro shop. 
(6)  Groups finishing on Number 9 have the right-of-way on Number 10. Other groups must check with the pro shop before starting Number 10. 
(7)  Tuesday morning is ladies' day. 
(8)  No range ball is allowed on the golf course. Violators may be evicted from the course. 
(9)  Tee times are available and are encouraged on any day of the week. 
(10)  Inappropriate conduct and/or golf etiquette will be handled on a case-by-case basis. 
(11)  Persons or groups in violation of the above rules and regulations may be evicted from the course by the pro and/or denied access to the golf course. 
(f)  League play. League play rules and regulations shall be as follows: 
(1)  League administrator must coordinate with the golf pro no later than 6 weeks prior to start. 
(2)  Excluding ladies' and men's association events there shall be a maximum of three league nights per week during May 15th to September 1st, and leagues will start no earlier than 5:30 P.M. on the front 9 (Monday—Thursday). 
(3)  If a league has 32 or more players, the golf pro or their designated staff member will close the front 9 holes and run a shotgun start. If this requirement is not met, then the golf pro or their designated staff member reserves the right to allow outside play on the front 9 and use a modified shotgun start. 
(4)  All rules and regulations at the golf course apply to any league. 
(g)  Tournament rules. Tournaments shall be governed by the following: 
(1)  All open play rules shall apply. 
(2)  Greens fees for tournaments will be set annually by resolution of the council. 
(3)  Tournament sponsors are required to sign an initial tournament use contract with the city and to complete a tournament request form and can be renewed or have first right of refusal. 
(4)  Tournaments shall be scheduled and regulated through the golf professional. 
(5)  The high school team is allowed to play free during the C.H.S.A.A. established high school golf season. 
(h)  Golf carts. Rental carts are available through the golf professional shop. Private carts (with exception of narrow wheel carts) are allowed at the course with a cap of eighty carts. Private golf carts must be built by a golf cart manufacturer and must be approved by the golf professional. Private carts will be charged a usage fee which is set annually by resolution of the council. Owners of private carts are completely responsible for all operating and maintenance expenses of the carts (including any towing charges). Private carts may be removed from the course if they are determined to be doing damage to the course (i.e., leaking gas, oil, etc.). No storage for private carts will be provided at the golf course through the city. Cart operators shall follow the rules and regulations set forth below: 
(1)  Stay thirty feet from the greens. 
(2)  Do not drive over tees. 
(3)  Drive around the outside of all golf trail signs. 
(4)  Do not drive rental carts at slow speed constantly, as it will drain battery dead after nine holes. 
(5)  Apply brakes evenly and smoothly so turf will not be torn. 
(6)  Stay out of bunkers and traps. Keep all carts out of the tall, bumpy and rough areas. Do not drive over ditches except at crossings. Reckless and careless use of carts is not permitted. 
(7)  Cart operators must possess a valid drivers' license. Children under sixteen years of age are not allowed to drive carts. 
(8)  No more than two riders are allowed on carts, except as approved by the golf pro. 
(9)  All private carts to be used on the golf course must be registered with the city prior to play and may only have two principal owners listed. If ownership of a private cart changes during any golf season, the cart must be re-registered and the registration fee paid. Each private cart owner will be given a list of rules and regulations pertaining to the usage of their private cart. 
(10)  One of the two registered owners must be in the private cart for each round of golf played. Occupancy is limited to that person and one other. 
(11)  Private cart owners must sign in at the pro shop prior to the playing of any hole at the golf course. 
(12)  Fees for private cart registration will be set annually by resolution of the council. All fees must be paid prior to use of the private cart on the golf course. 
(13)  Persons or groups in violation of the above rules and regulations may be evicted from the course. 
By the city or the city's duly authorized agent (golf pro) and/or denied access to the golf course. A refund of the private cart registration fee will not be given to cart owners evicted for cause. 
(i)  Intoxicating beverages. Only alcoholic beverages sold by and purchased from the Conquistador Golf Course, currently the Golf Pro, are allowed to be possessed and consumed on the Conquistador Golf Course. 
Consumption of alcohol in the golf course parking lot is prohibited and subject to Cortez City Code sections 18-1, Alcoholic beverages—drinking in public generally and 18-2, possession of open containers of liquor, wine and fermented beverages. 
(j)  Driving range. Driving range hours are posted in the pro shop. Driving range rules and regulations are as follows: 
(1)  Carts are not allowed on the driving range or driving range tee box except as approved by the golf pro or golf course superintendent. 
(2)  All range users shall stay within the boundaries as posted by the golf course superintendent. 
(3)  Golfers/spectators shall not loiter or be in attendance on the golf course driving range ball landing area, which is marked by out-of-bounds markers. 
(4)  Intentionally hitting balls to land outside the driving range is cause for eviction from the driving range. 
(5)  Range balls are the property of the golf professional. Using range balls in areas not authorized by the pro is strictly forbidden. 
(6)  The golf course superintendent may close the range for maintenance purposes. 
(7)  Violators of the above rules regarding the driving range may be evicted from the driving range or denied access to the driving range by the pro. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part); Ord. No. 723, § 1; Ord. No. 731, § 1; Ord. 762 § 1.) 
(Ord. No. 1154, 7-26-11; Ord. No. 1156, 10-25-11; Ord. No. 1178, 4-23-13; Ord. No. 1211 , 6-28-16; Ord. No. 1221 , 3-28-17)  
Sec. 19-7. - Park and facility use permit. 
(a)  A permit shall be obtained from the office of the director whenever any person or group desires to reserve any portion of the public parks or recreational facilities for any activity. The director of parks and recreation shall interpret this chapter and may act in any case not specifically covered by this chapter. Any request for a use prohibited in this chapter may be forwarded to the city manager who will take the matter before the city council for its consideration. 
(b)  Department-organized recreation activities shall be given first preference for use of facilities. 
(c)  An application for permission to reserve a park or portion thereof or parks and recreation facilities by persons or groups not officially a part of the department shall be initiated at least two weeks prior to the requested date, and shall have written approval of the director or his authorized representative; provided, however, that in extraordinary cases, the director or his authorized representative may waive or shorten the two-week time period as set forth above. 
(d)  All activities shall be under competent, adult supervision, and the organization using the facility shall assume full responsibility for any damage to the facility or the equipment. The department employee on duty shall exercise authority over the organization or its activities. Cleanup of the contracted area shall be the responsibility of the user. The user shall be charged on an hourly basis to pay for cleanup if it is necessary for the city to provide additional cleanup services. The fees or charges shall be established by the city council and administered by the director; provided, however, the city council may, in appropriate cases, waive the user fee or charge. 
(e)  All permits shall be revocable for cause by the director or upon finding of a violation of any rule, this Code or other city ordinance or state statute. If notice of cancellation of a request is not received at the office of the director at least forty-eight hours prior to the date of the event, the permit holder may be held responsible for all charges at the discretion of the director. 
(f)  No apparatus (scenery, etc.) or furniture and equipment shall be moved into a park facility unless special permission is granted in advance and so stated in the permit. Such apparatus, furniture or equipment (provided by the holder of the permit) shall be removed from the park area promptly after use and before 8:30 A.M. the following morning so that there shall not be any interference with normal park and recreation programs. Failure to comply may prohibit such groups from using facilities at a later date. 
(g)  Any person or group using facilities shall indemnify the city by signing a disclaimer for any and all damage to the facilities by any person or persons attending the event, and all liability and damages to any person for injuries, including death. Adequate insurance may be required for activities as determined by the director. If insurance is required it shall be provided by the person or groups using park facilities to cover such liability, listing the city as an "additional insured." Responsibility for loss, breakage or need for repair of any piece of furniture, equipment or portion of the facility or area shall rest solely with the person in charge, and/or the individual signing the agreement, who shall report same to the director. 
(h)  Building facilities and areas shall be vacated by 11:00 P.M. unless permission is otherwise granted specifically in the permit. It is the responsibility of the permit holder to ensure that this policy is administered. Programs shall be concluded in time to provide for cleanup and clearance of the facility as stated in the permit. 
(i)  The following specific rules shall be observed while using any facility. The permit holder shall be held responsible for any loss or damage growing out of such violation: 
(1)  The use of tobacco in any facility in any form shall be carefully controlled. No smoking shall be allowed unless proper and adequate containers are provided. 
(2)  Functions shall be confined to the specific part of the facility assigned to the permit holder. 
(j)  Prohibitions. 
(1)  The following activities shall be prohibited unless approved by the director: 
(A)  Continuous use of park and recreation facilities. 
(k)  The total number of people admitted for any usage shall not exceed the capacity of the facility involved, as determined by the director. 
(l)  All federal, state, county and city statues and ordinances shall be complied with by the permit holder. 
(m)  The use of special equipment shall be permitted only when operated by department employees or other persons specifically authorized in the permit. When used by other than department employees, and so stated in the permit, the special equipment shall be returned in the condition in which it was found (with the exception of normal wear) or the user shall be responsible for repair or replacement charges. 
(n)  No material of any kind shall be attached to any part of the facility or area without express written approval from the director. 
(o)  If control personnel, parking attendant, etc., are necessary, such personnel shall be supplied by the applicant. The director shall specify when control personnel are necessary. 
(p)  Concession rights shall be reserved to the city unless specifically stated otherwise in the permit. 
(q)  Sidewalks, roadways and parking facilities shall be those specifically surfaced areas within the park property constructed for that purpose. 
(r)  Continuous use of facilities by clubs or enterprises shall be permitted through signed agreements which shall be reissued as necessary at the direction of the director. No permit shall exceed a period of time of one year. Permits may be reissued each year with the approval of the director. 
(s)  When an application for use of the facilities has been approved by the director, notification shall contain the date, hours of use, type of activity and number of participants. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part); Ord. No. 723, § 2.) 
(Ord. No. 1147, 11-23-10)  
Sec. 19-8. - Cancellation. 
The director reserves the right to cancel the use of any parks, recreation or golf course facility if he deems that damage may occur to the facility during inclement weather. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part).)  
Sec. 19-9. - Refunds. 
The director shall approve the issuance of refunds by the finance department for the use of facilities (when charged) and recreation programs on the following basis: 
(a)  Athletic leagues. 
(1)  If the league is canceled by the department, a full refund shall be issued. 
(2)  If a participant, team or sponsor wants a refund before schedules are completed, the original fee charged less a five-dollar handling fee shall be refunded. 
(3)  After schedules are completed, seventy-five percent of the original fee charged shall be refunded. 
(4)  After leagues have started playing and before fifty percent of the league schedule has been completed, fifty percent of the original fee charged shall be refunded. 
(5)  No refund shall be issued once fifty percent of the league schedule has been completed. 
(b)  Recreation programs. 
(1)  If the program is canceled by the department a full refund shall be issued. 
(2)  If a refund is requested prior to the first class meeting, the original fee charged less a five-dollar handling fee shall be refunded. 
(3)  After the first class has met, no refunds shall be issued. 
(c)  Refunds. 
(1)  All refunds authorized by this section shall be issued during the regular business hours of the city, 8:00 A.M. through 5:00 P.M., Monday through Friday, with the exception of holidays. 
(Ord. No. 723, § 3.)  
Sec. 19-10. - Fees established. 
Fees for all city recreation facilities and programs shall be established annually by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part).)  
Sec. 19-11. - Penalty. 
Any person or persons guilty of violating any of the provisions contained in Sections 19-2, 19-3, 19-4, 19-5, 19-6 (e), (f), (g), (h), and (i) and 19-7 of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A as now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 692, § 2 (part); amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 25, 9-25-12)  
CHAPTER 19A. - CITY PARKS TO BE USED BY "FOR PROFIT" ENTERPRISES. 
 
Sec. 19A-1. - Establishment of procedures for the allowance of city parks to be used by "for profit" enterprises. 
(a)  All "for profit" activities which are allowed in any city park or facility shall be approved by the parks and recreation director. 
(b)  The city shall receive to a percentage of the gross revenues raised by any such activity based on city involvement at a minimum to cover city costs. This percentage of the gross may be negotiated between the person or entity that wishes to have the activity and the director of parks and recreation, or percentages may be set by council in their annual fee setting resolution. 
Section 19-2(a) of the codification determines the times that city parks shall be open. If an event is approved under this new chapter, section 19-2(a) will not be applicable but event times will be negotiated. 
(c)  Section 19-2(l), sales, advertising in parks and recreation areas, shall not be applicable to the events approved by the city in this chapter. 
(d)  Alcohol will only be permitted in an event with a "for profit" entity if it is co-sponsored by an approved non-profit eligible to host events which includes the sale of alcohol. 
(e)  A liquor license for any event serving alcohol must be obtained by the non profit entity sponsor pursuant to city licensing requirements. 
(Ord. No. 1147, 11-23-10) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1147, adopted November 23, 2010, repealed the former § 19A-1, and enacted a new § 19A-1 as set out herein. The former 19A-1 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1010.  
CHAPTER 20. - PERSONNEL. 
 
Secs. 20-1 to 20-5. - Reserved.  
Sec. 20-6. - Police pension fund—Adopted by reference. 
The statutes of the State of Colorado, Title 31, Article 30, Sections 301—324, Part 3, as amended, insofar as the same pertains and applies to the city, are hereby adopted by reference as fully and to the same extent as though the same were printed in full herein. The police pension fund of the city shall be operated in accordance with such statutes, as amended, except as otherwise provided by city charter or by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 504, §§ 1—2.)  
Sec. 20-7. - Same—Disability insurance. 
(a)  Any member of the police pension fund who receives funds from a disability insurance plan funded by the city shall as a condition to acceptance of such funds be deemed to have assigned such funds to the police pension fund of the city. 
(b)  The board of trustees of the police pension fund is hereby authorized and directed to consider the amount of any such funds received by the member as a portion of any award made from the police pension fund and to credit the fund with such payment in the same manner as if made directly from the police pension fund. 
(Ord. No. 504, §§ 3—4.)  
CHAPTER 21. - PLUMBING. 
 As to buildings generally, see Ch. 6 of this Code. As to gas generally, see Ch. 13. 
 
Sec. 21-1.1. - Plumbing Code—Copies on file. 
Three true and exact official copies of the above-described 2009 Edition of the International Plumbing Code (IPC) are on file in the municipal offices of the City of Cortez, Colorado, duly certified by the mayor and attested by the city clerk, and may be examined, duplicated, or copied by any interested person during the regular business hours of said offices, all such reproduction or copying to be at the expense of the person requesting the same. 
(Ord. No. 702, § 3; Ord. No. 703, § 3; Ord. No. 738, § 3; Ord. No. 798, § 3.) 
(Ord. No. 1137, § III (part)) 
 Prior ordinance history: Ord. Nos. 541, 584 and 637.  
Sec. 21-1.2. - Deleted. 
  Editor's note: § 21-1.2 was deleted at the city's request after adoption of the 1985 Uniform Plumbing Code by Ord. No. 637.  
Sec. 21-2. - Plumbing Code—Enforcement; inspections by building official. 
The building official shall enforce the Plumbing Code and any other plumbing regulations of the city, and make all inspections of plumbing installations; provided, that his duly authorized representative may act for him. 
(Code 1968, § 13-4-2.)  
Sec. 21-3. - Plumbers' licenses—Required; issuance; fee generally; qualifications; exception. 
No person shall carry on the business, trade or calling of plumbing, install or contract to do any plumbing within the city without first obtaining a license to do so. The building official, upon the payment of an annual license fee, as set forth by the city council by resolution, in advance, and upon being satisfied that the applicant has the qualifications herein specified, may issue to any applicant a plumber's license for the fiscal year or balance thereof. Every person applying for a license shall give satisfactory evidence to the building official that he is a regular practicing plumber, and has a license from the state board of health as required by law. Nothing in this section shall be construed so as to require a property owner to have a plumber's license to repair leaks on his own property. All plumbing work within the city must be performed under the direct supervision of a master plumber. 
(Code 1968, § 13-4-3.) 
 For state law as to plumbers generally, see C.R.S. 1973, § 12-58-101 et seq.  
Sec. 21-4. - Same—Bond required; proration of fee. 
No license shall be issued under this chapter until the applicant has executed and furnished a bond to the city with good and sufficient sureties to be approved by the building official, in the amount of one thousand dollars conditioned upon compliance with the regulations and instructions of city officials in charge of the sewers and water system and their authorized agents, and with all the requirements of the ordinances of the city and the state Plumbing Code, in relation to sewers, waterworks and plumbing. 
The city council by resolution may, from time to time, change the amount of the bond referenced above. 
No reduction of license fee shall be made because a license may be granted for only the balance of the fiscal year. 
(Code 1968, § 13-4-4; Ord. No. 909 (part).)  
Sec. 21-5. - Same—Transfer; cancellation. 
Plumbing licenses are not transferable either directly or indirectly. 
The building official shall, for unskillfulness, carelessness or willful violation of the state Plumbing Code or any instructions of the water and sewer superintendents or their authorized agents, cancel any such license after giving the licensee a hearing with due notice of the charges. 
(Code 1968, § 13-4-5.)  
Sec. 21-6. - Plumbing permits. 
A permit must be obtained for each and every installation of plumbing in the city. 
A plumbing permit fee will be established by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 1968, § 13-4-7.)  
Sec. 21-7. - Inspection required. 
All plumbing and sanitary sewer lines must be inspected by the building official or his authorized representative. 
(Code 1968, § 13-4-8.)  
Sec. 21-8. - Installation of grease traps. 
Grease traps shall be installed in accordance with the latest regulations approved by the state department of public health. 
(Code 1968, § 13-4-6.)  
Sec. 21-9. - Penalties for violation. 
In addition to all other penalties herein provided, any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter or suffering or permitting the same to be violated shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and a violation upon conviction shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A as now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. Each day that the violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. A separate and additional complaint may be filed by the building inspector for such continuing violations. 
(Ord. No. 909 (part); amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 26, 9-25-12)  
CHAPTER 21A. - CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL GENERAL POLICY 
 
Sec. 21A-1. - Responsibility. 
(a)  This program applies to all metered water accounts provided by the City of Cortez. The cross-connection administrator, or his designee, shall be responsible for the protection of the public water distribution system from contamination or pollution due to the backflow or back-siphonage of contaminants or pollutants through the water service connection. 
(b)  If a backflow prevention device is required for the in-plant, industrial piping or owner's premises for the protection of the potable water system, the cross-connection administrator shall give written notice to the owner to install an approved backflow prevention device or devices at his or her own expense within ninety days of the receipt of the notice, or the customer's water service will be discontinued until the proper device or devices are installed. In case of a direct hazard, immediate termination of service will occur and will only be restored when approved assemblies have been installed to protect the potable water supply. 
(Ord. No. 1048, § 1 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1226 , § 1.00, 8-8-17)  
Sec. 21A-2. - Right of entry. 
(a)  A representative of the City of Cortez will carry proper credentials of his or her office. By previously-arranged appointment and upon presentation of proper credentials, the representative shall have the right of entry to inspect any and all buildings and premises for cross connections relative to possible hazards. This right of entry shall be a condition of water service in order to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the customers throughout the city's distribution system. Where building security is required, the backflow assembly should be located in an area not subject to security. Questions regarding proper credentials should be directed to the department of public works. 
(b)  The department of public works may request an administrative search warrant for the purpose of inspecting buildings and premises for cross-connections relative to possible hazards. Applications shall be made to the Cortez Municipal Court which, upon proper showing, may grant a search warrant to the department of public works for the purpose of inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1048, § 1 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1226 , § 1.01, 8-8-17)  
Sec. 21A-3. - Violations. 
(a)  Failure of the customer to cooperate in the installation, maintenance, testing, or inspection of backflow prevention assemblies required by these standards shall be grounds for the discontinuance of water service to the premises, or the requirement of installation of an air-gap separation from the public water system. 
(b)  Service of water to any premises may be discontinued by the public works director if unprotected cross-connections exist on the premises. When any defect is found in an installed backflow prevention assembly, or if a backflow prevention assembly has been removed or bypassed, the service may be discontinued. Service shall not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected. 
(c)  Discontinuance of service may be summary, immediate, and without written notice whenever, in the judgment of the public works director, such action is necessary to protect the purity of the public potable water supply or the safety of the water system. 
(Ord. No. 1048, § 1 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1226 , § 1.2, 8-8-17)  
Sec. 21A-4. - General requirements. 
(a)  All building plans must be submitted to the City of Cortez Cross-Connection Administrator for approval prior to the issuance of water service. Building plans must show: 
(1)  Water service type, size, and location; 
(2)  Meter size and location; 
(3)  Backflow prevention device size, type, and location; and 
(4)  Fire sprinkling system(s) service line, size, and type of backflow prevention device. 
(b)  Backflow prevention assembles are to be installed in an accessible location to facilitate maintenance, testing, and repair. Drawings must show various installations. 
(c)  All backflow prevention assembles shall be installed downstream of the water meter prior to any uses. 
(d)  Before installing a backflow prevention assembly, pipelines should be thoroughly flushed to remove foreign material. 
(e)  In no case will it be permissible to have a bypass on a backflow assembly, unless also protected by the same level backflow assembly. 
(f)  Backflow prevention valves are not to be used as the inlet or outlet valve of the water meter. Test cocks are not to be used as supply connections (not applied to residential dual-check meter installations). 
(g)  In order to insure that backflow prevention assembles continue to operate satisfactorily, it will be necessary that they be tested at the time of installation and on an annual schedule thereafter. Such tests will be conducted in accordance with ASSE and/or USC Cross-Connection Control 10th Edition and Field Test Procedures as directed by the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE). 
(h)  The City of Cortez will require inspection of all containment installations. 
(i)  All cost for design, installation, maintenance, repair, and testing are to be borne by the customer. 
(j)  No grandfather clause exists. All laws and regulations apply regardless of the age of the facility. 
(k)  All fire sprinkling systems shall have a minimum protection of an approved double-check valve for containment of the system. 
(1)  All glycol (ethylene or propylene), or antifreeze systems shall have an approved reduced pressure zone assembly for containment. 
(2)  Dry fire systems shall have an approved double-check valve installed upstream of the air pressure valve. 
(3)  Single family residence with a fire sprinkler system and domestic water combined shall have a double check valve when no chemicals are used. 
(l)  All fire sprinkler systems shall conform to the currently-adopted International Fire Code. 
(m)  Commercial fire hydrant meters shall have the reduce pressure zone assembly tested prior to use and a copy of the test report turned in to the cross-connection administrator. 
(n)  All commercial water haulers shall have a reduce pressure zone assembly installed and tested prior to receiving water from the City of Cortez. 
(1)  Exception: Trucks configured with top fill air gaps. 
(Ord. No. 1048, § 1 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1226 , § 1.3, 8-8-17)  
Sec. 21A-5. - Reference manuals. 
(a)  Reference manuals adopted for guidelines on cross-connection control include: 
(1)  Cross-Connection Control Manual, Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE), latest edition. 
(2)  Definitions of terms used in this regulation are those contained in the Cross-Connection Control Manual, CDPHE, latest edition. 
(3)  American Water Works Association Recommended Practice for Backflow Prevention and Cross-Connection Control Manual M14, Fourth Edition 2015. 
(4)  Manual of Cross-Connection Control, 10th Edition, USC. 
(Ord. No. 1048, § 1 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1226 , § 1.4, 8-8-17)  
Sec. 21A-6. - Copies on file. 
(a)  Three true and exact official copies of the Cross-Connection Control Manual, CDPHE, latest edition, shall be on file: one in the office of the Cortez City Clerk; one in the Cortez Public Library; and one in the office of the Director of Public Works of the City of Cortez, duly certified by the Mayor and attested by the City Clerk, and may be examined, duplicated, or copied by any interested person during the regular business hours of said office, all such reproduction or copying to be at the expense of the person requesting the same. 
(Ord. No. 1048, § 1 (part).) 
( Ord. No. 1226 , § 1.5, 8-8-17)  
CHAPTER 22. - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS. 
 For charter provisions as to public improvements, see Char., art. VIII, §§ 5, 9, art. IX, §§ 5, 7, art. XIII. 
 For state law as to authority of city to make public improvements, see C.R.S. 1973, § 31-35-303. As to sidewalk improvements, see C.R.S. 1973, § 31-35-305. 
 As to sewers generally, see Ch. 23 of this Code. As to streets and sidewalks generally, see Ch. 24. As to the location of curb lines, see §§ 24-3 to 24-6. As to curb cuts, see §§ 24-7, 24-8. Article I. - In General. 
 
Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Paving. Includes repaving, macadamizing and remacadamizing. 
Real estate. All lands whether platted or unplatted, regardless of lot or land lines. Lots, plots, blocks and other subdivisions may be designated in accordance with any recorded plat thereof and unplatted lands by any definite description. 
Street. Avenues, boulevards, alleys and other highways. 
(Code 1968, §§ 8-5-1, 8-5-4.)  
Sec. 22-2. - Council to award contracts and assess costs; director of public works to make recommendations as to contracts and supervise work. 
(a)  The city council shall have the power to contract for or have made local improvements and to assess the cost thereof, wholly or in part, upon the property especially benefitted. 
(b)  All contracts for public improvements shall be awarded by the council upon recommendation of the director of public works, except as provided by this chapter, and the improvements shall be constructed by and under the direction of the director of public works in accordance with the specifications prescribed or approved by the council. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-2.)  
Sec. 22-3. - Improvements to be authorized by ordinance. 
Whenever the council by resolution orders any of the local improvements mentioned under this chapter, such improvement shall be authorized by ordinance. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-3.)  
Sec. 22-4. - Adoption of existing improvements. 
If at the time of the passage of an ordinance authorizing any improvements for any district, any piece of real estate or any railway company to be assessed in the district has the whole or any part of the proposed improvements, conforming to the general plan, the same may be adopted in whole or in part, or may be changed to conform to the general plan, if deemed practical, and the owner of such real estate shall, when the assessment is made, be credited with the amount which is saved by reason of adapting or adopting such existing improvements. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-1.)  
Sec. 22-5. - Assessment of costs generally—Against benefitted land generally. 
Whenever any improvement authorized to be made by the city pursuant to this chapter is so ordered, the city council shall determine that all or any part of the total cost thereof, including, but not limited to, the cost of improving the intersections of streets and alleys, but excepting the share to be assessed against any street or other railway company, shall be assessed against the tracts or parcels of land specifically benefitted thereby and included within the district or within the assessment unit, if the district is divided into such units, with the following exceptions: Any tract or parcel owned by the United States of America or any agency, instrumentality or corporation thereof and any street or other public right-of-way. Such special assessments shall be in proportion to the special benefits derived to such property and on a front foot, area, zone or other equitable basis, as may be determined by the city council, sufficient to cover the portion of the total cost of the improvement to be defrayed by special assessments. Regardless of the basis so determined, in cases of wedge, V or irregularly shaped lots or tracts, the amount apportioned thereto shall be in proportion to the special benefits thereby derived. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-3.)  
Sec. 22-6. - Same—Allocation for street and alley intersections. 
The cost of improvements in street intersections may be segregated and such cost, except the share assessable to street or other railway companies, may be assessed upon all frontage of the street improved and on intersecting streets within a distance of one-half block in each direction from such intersections, in proportion to the frontage of each lot or tract on the street improved or on an intersecting street, or on both within such distance. The cost of the improvement of an alley intersection may be assessed upon the real estate in the same block extending to the nearest street intersection and half the length of the block along its sides; provided, that where the sides of blocks are of unequal length, the council may determine the limit of assessment. The cost of improving street and alley intersections may be treated as one of the costs of any improvement without separately segregating such intersection cost. In such case, the total cost of any improvement shall be assessed as provided by this section upon the basis determined without any separate assessment for intersection costs. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-5.)  
Sec. 22-7. - Same—Allocation for sidewalks. 
The whole cost of construction and reconstruction of sidewalks, including intersections and necessary grading and removal of obstructions, shall be assessed upon the lots or lands in front of which such improvements are made, as follows: The grading, removal of obstructions, intersections and all other general expenses, including cost of collection and interest, pro rata per front foot; new walks, pro rata per front foot where constructed; and reconstructed walks upon each lot or piece of land where reconstructed according to the cost of reconstruction. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-7.)  
Sec. 22-8. - Same—Against public corporation land. 
When the state, any agency, instrumentality or corporation thereof, or any city, county, school district or any other public or quasi-public corporation, except the United States of America or any agency, instrumentality or corporation thereof, owns any land or hold the title to any land not used as a street or other public right-of-way, which if owned by a private person would be liable to assessment for benefits to pay for any public improvement mentioned in this chapter, an assessment shall be made against such land as though such land were the property of a private person, and the state, its agency, instrumentality or corporation, or the city, county, school district or other public or quasi-public corporation shall pay the amount of that assessment. If such assessment is not paid within thirty days after the final publication of the assessing ordinance, suit may be brought in the district court to enforce the collection of such assessment and the judgment rendered against such city, county, school district or other public or quasi-public corporation shall be enforced as other judgments against such entities, but no such land owned thereby shall be sold under any such judgment. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-8.)  
Sec. 22-9. - Grading or paving of area belonging to street or railway company. 
Whenever any grading or paving district is created under this chapter, the council shall include in the area to be paved or graded the entire width of the street from curb to curb, or in the absence of curbs to street lines determined by the city council including the portion of such street occupied by, or required by franchise obligation to be paved, chargeable or assessable to any street or other railway company whose tracks run through or across any street in such district. The council shall charge to, assess and collect the proper proportion of the cost of such improvement from such street or railway company in the same manner as is provided in this chapter for other property specially benefitted thereon, and shall issue bonds for the same, which bonds shall be issued and made payable in like manner as bonds issued for the improvement to be assessed against the real estate especially benefitted. A street or railway company shall be held to occupy and shall be liable for the grading and paving of that part of the street lying between the rails of each track and two feet outside of each rail, and every railway company, whether street railway, shall be assessed for the cost of the paving and grading of any part of any street or alley occupied by or required by franchise obligation to be paid by them. The assessment levied for the cost of such improvement chargeable to a railway company shall be a first and prior lien against the entire franchise and property of the company within and without such district, but within the limits of the city, excepting any lien thereon to secure the payment of general taxes. All the terms, conditions and provisions in this chapter relative to the collection of the amounts chargeable against tracts or parcels of land assessed shall be applicable in the enforcement and collection of such assessment against such railway company, and the property of such railway shall be sold by the city as in cases of default in payment of general taxes levied thereon; but railway trackage shall not be considered or computed as assessable frontage, in determining the sufficiency of petitions or remonstrance as provided by this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-4.)  
Sec. 22-10. - Construction of walks by owner. 
In districts for the construction and reconstruction of sidewalks alone, or in combination with other improvements, the work may include the necessary grading from the curb line to the lot line, and the owner of any lot or tract to be assessed shall have the right to construct or reconstruct his own walks in conformity with the plans and specifications for the district, within thirty days from the publication of the ordinance authorizing such improvement. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-6.)  
Sec. 22-11. - Notices generally—Effect of failure to receive. 
Whenever any notice is mailed as required in this article, the fact that the person to whom it was addressed does not receive it shall not in any manner invalidate or affect the proceedings provided for under this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-9.)  
Sec. 22-12. - Same—Use of figures, general descriptions, etc. 
In all proceedings and notices authorized by this chapter, figures may be used instead of words and it shall not be necessary in an improvement district to designate each piece of real estate in the district separately. General description and quantities may be used, except in the assessment rolls, and except in assessments, any cost stated may be stated as being a probable amount per front foot, per square foot or per lot, of a given size and proportionate amounts for other lots, or when a different method of assessment is provided, then as being subject to such method. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-10.)  
Sec. 22-13. - Legal actions—Generally. 
The finding of the council by ordinance that any improvement provided for in this chapter was duly ordered after notice duly given, or that a petition or remonstrance was or was not filed, or was or was not duly subscribed by the required number of owners, shall be conclusive in every court or other tribunal. Within fifteen days immediately succeeding the publication of such ordinance upon its final passage, any person who has filed a written remonstrance, as provided by this chapter, shall have the right to commence an action or suit in any court of competent jurisdiction to correct or set aside the determination of the council. Any person concerned who objects to the regularity, validity and correctness of proceedings and instruments taken, adopted or made at or subsequent to such hearing and prior to the final passage of such ordinance shall also have the right to commence such an action or suit to cure or set aside such purported irregularity, invalidity or incorrectness. Nothing in this section shall be construed as not requiring any person to make any objection by written remonstrance at such hearing in order not to waive such objection, if the purported irregularity, invalidity or incorrectness of any matter first occurred prior to the first publication of the notice of the hearing. After the expiration of such fifteen days all actions or suits not so commenced attacking the regularity, validity and correctness of that ordinance and of all proceedings, determinations and instruments taken, adopted or made prior to such ordinance's final passage, shall be perpetually barred. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-2.)  
Sec. 22-14. - Same—Statute of limitations. 
Except as otherwise provided in sections 22-13, 22-23 and 22-52 of this Code, all actions legal or equitable for relief against any proceedings had under this chapter whether based upon irregularities or jurisdictional defects, shall be commenced within thirty days after the wrongful act complained of, or else be thereafter perpetually barred. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-11; Ord. No. 497, § 1.)  
Sec. 22-15. - Connection with utilities may be compelled by city manager; assessment of costs of connections. 
Whenever any paving district or local improvement providing for paving is ordered under the provisions of this chapter, the city manager, if he deems it advisable, may order the owners of the abutting real estate to connect their several premises with the water and gas mains or with any other utility in the street in front of their several premises and upon default of the owners for twenty days after such order to make such connections the city may contract for and make such connections or do the work by day labor in the manner and in accordance with the specifications prescribed for such work. The whole cost of each connection shall be assessed against the property with which the connections are made in accordance with the provisions of this chapter for the acquisition of improvements, creating local improvement districts and defraying the cost thereof, for such paving or local improvement district. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-12.)  
Sec. 22-16. - Power and duty of city officers to enforce chapter. 
The officers of the city are authorized and directed to take all action necessary or appropriate to effectuate the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 8-7-13.)  
Sec. 22-17. - Applicability of chapter to prior improvement districts. 
The provisions of this chapter insofar as applicable shall apply to all local improvement districts heretofore created and to the collection of any assessment or installment of assessments therein not delinquent and certified to the county tax collector for collection. 
(Code l968, § 8-10-17.)  
Article II. - Initiation. 
 
Sec. 22-18. - By resolution of council. 
(a)  Required. Proceedings to improve streets, alleys and public highways and parts thereof by paving, grading, curbing, guttering and surfacing with suitable material, the construction and reconstruction of sidewalks upon and otherwise improving, of the whole or any part or parts of any street, alley or streets and alleys, which need not be connected or contiguous, in the city, or any combination of such improvements, including necessary grading, crosswalks, curbs, drains, readjusting manholes, catchbasin and such other incidentals, including the incidental storm sewers in case of paving, as the council may prescribe, shall be initiated upon recommendation of the director of public works by the adoption of a resolution by the city council. 
(b)  Contents. The resolution by the city council initiating proceedings on proposed improvements, except as otherwise provided by this chapter shall state the nature and location of the improvement to be made, without mentioning minor details and incidentals, describe the local improvement district to be assessed, by boundaries or other brief description, and instruct the director of public works, or an engineer specially retained by the city in connection with such district, who, in such event, may perform all or any portion of the duties prescribed by this chapter to be performed by the director of public works as directed by the council, to prepare and present to the council: 
(1)  Preliminary plans and specifications for such improvement. 
(2)  An estimate of the probable total cost thereof, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the cost of constructing or otherwise acquiring such improvement, engineering and clerical service and supplies, cost of inspection, cost of collecting assessments, advertising, printing, interest on bonds until interest on assessments is available to defray such, fiscal services, legal services for preparing proceedings and advising in regard thereto and other incidental costs. 
(3)  A map of the local improvement district to be assessed. 
(c)  Preliminary plans. The preliminary plans shall show a typical section of the comtemplated improvement, the type of material and the approximate thickness and width. Such resolution may provide for one or more types of construction. 
(d)  Combination of improvements. More than one improvement may be combined in one local improvement district when the city council determines such improvements may be combined together in an efficient and economical district. If in the combination of improvements they shall be separate and distinct by reason of substantial difference in their character or location, or otherwise, each such improvement shall be considered as a unit or district for the purpose of petition, remonstrance and assessment, such unit or district being sometimes designated as an assessment unit. In case of such combination the city council shall designate the improvement and area constituting each such assessment unit, and in the absence of an arbitrary and unreasonable abuse of discretion, its determination that there is or is not such a combination and its determination of the improvement and area constituting each such unit shall be final and conclusive. The costs of constructing and otherwise acquiring each such improvement shall be segregated for the levy of assessments and an equitable share of the incidental costs shall be allocated to each such assessment unit. 
(e)  Cost estimates not limitation on council. Any estimate of cost required or authorized in this article shall not constitute a limitation upon such cost nor a limitation upon the rights and powers of the city council or of any officers, agents or employees of the city, except as otherwise specifically stated in this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-4.)  
Sec. 22-19. - By petition. 
(a)  Generally. A public work or improvement, the costs of which, in whole or in part, are to be assessed by the city, may be initiated on petition of property owners. 
(b)  Standing to petition: conditions. The owners of land to be assessed for not less than fifty-one percent of the entire cost of any public work or improvement, including all incidental expenses, constituting at least a majority in frontage, in area or in whatever other property constituting the basis for the computation of assessments of the real estates so to be assessed, may by written petition initiate the acquisition of any improvement which the council is authorized to initiate, subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  The council may incorporate such improvement in any assessment unit and in any improvement district pursuant to subsection (d) of section 22-18 and all other provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  The council need not proceed with the acquisition of any such improvement or any part thereof after holding a hearing thereon, if the council determines that it is not in the public interest that the proposed project, or a part thereof, be constructed. 
(3)  Any particular kind of improvement, material therefor or part thereof need not be acquired or located, as provided in the petition, if the council determines that such is not in the public interest. 
(4)  The council need not take any proceedings or action upon receiving any such petition if the council determines by resolution that the acquisition of the designated improvement probably is not feasible for the reason stated in such resolution. If the resolution requires a cash deposit or a pledge of property in at least an amount or value therein designated and found by the council to be probably sufficient to defray the expenses and cost incurred by the city taken preliminary to, and in the attempted acquisition of, the improvement designated in the petition, and if such deposit or pledge is not made with the director of finance within twenty days after one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city of a notice of the resolution's adoption and of its contents in summary form. An additional deposit or pledge may from time to time be similarly so required as a condition precedent to the continuation of action by the city. Whenever such deposit or pledge is made and the council determines that such acquisition is not feasible within a reasonable period of time, the council may require that all or any portion of the costs incurred in connection with investigation of such proposal by the city shall be defrayed from such deposit or proceeds of such pledged property, in lieu of such defrayment of costs by petitioners or other interested persons, within twenty days after the determination by resolution of such amount and upon publication of a notice thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-5; Ord. No. 602, § 1.)  
Sec. 22-20. - Proceedings of council after initiation by petition. 
Upon the filing of a petition as permitted by section 22-19, the council shall proceed in the same manner as is provided for by this article where proceedings are initiated by the city council, except as otherwise provided. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-6.)  
Article III. - Plans. 
 
Sec. 22-21. - Resolution adopting preliminary plans, specifications and map. 
(a)  Generally. The council shall by resolution adopt the preliminary plans and specifications and the map of the director of public works for the proposed improvement when the council is satisfied with such proposals. 
(b)  Additional contents. The council shall by that resolution or a resolution subsequently adopted prescribe: 
(1)  The extent of the local improvement district to be assessed and of each assessment unit, if the district is so divided, by boundaries or other brief description. 
(2)  The kind of improvement proposed, without mentioning minor details. 
(3)  The number of installments and the time in which the cost of the improvement will be payable. 
(4)  The probable cost as shown by the total estimate of the director of public works, which estimate shall not constitute a limitation upon the cost of the project nor for any other purpose. 
(5)  The amount or proportion of the total cost to be paid by other than special assessments, if any. 
(6)  The method of levying assessments. 
(7)  The approximate amount or share of the portion of the total estimate to be assessed against property specially benefitted by the acquisition of the proposed improvement. 
(c)  Order to construct; setting of hearing date. The council in that resolution shall order that the project be made when the same has been authorized by ordinance, and shall fix a day upon which a hearing in respect to such project shall be had within thirty days after the adoption of the resolution prescribing the extent of the local improvement district. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-7.)  
Sec. 22-22. - Notice to owners, etc. 
After the adoption of the resolution required by section 22-21 the city clerk shall give notice of such proposal by publication as required for other notices to the owners of real estate in the local improvement district and to all persons interested, generally, and without naming such owner or persons, of: 
(a)  The kind of improvements proposed, without mentioning minor details or incidentals. 
(b)  The number of installments and time in which the cost of improvements will be payable. 
(c)  The maximum rate of interest on unpaid installments. 
(d)  The extent of the district to be assessed, by boundaries or other brief description. 
(e)  The time when the council will consider the ordering of the proposed improvements and hear all complaints, remonstrances and objections that may be made in writing concerning the same by the owner of any real estate to be assessed or any person interested. 
(f)  The fact that all proceedings in the premises are on file and can be seen and examined at the office of the city clerk during business hours, at any time, by any person so interested. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-8.)  
Sec. 22-23. - Public hearing. 
(a)  Right of owners to present views, etc. On the date fixed for the hearing on the proposed improvements any and all property owners interested in such improvement may, by written petition, remonstrance or otherwise, present their views in respect to the proposed improvements to the council. 
(b)  Adjournment. The council may adjourn the hearing from time to time. 
(c)  Consideration of arguments. After the hearing has been concluded, after all written complaints, remonstrances and objections have been read and duly considered and after all persons desiring to be heard in person have been heard, the council shall consider the arguments, if any, and any other relevant material put forth. 
(d)  Determination against proposal. If the council determines that it is not in the public interest that the proposed project, or a part thereof, be made, the council shall make an order by resolution to that effect and any proceedings for the project, or any part thereof determined against by such order, shall stop and shall not be begun again until the adoption of a new resolution. 
(e)  Waiver of claims not presented. Any objection to the regularity, validity and correctness of the proceedings and instruments taken, adopted or made prior to the date of the hearing on the proposed improvements shall be deemed waived unless presented by written remonstrance at the time and in the manner specified by this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-9.)  
Sec. 22-24. - Construction after protest. 
If within the time specified in such notice a written protest or remonstrance against the making of all the improvements proposed by initiation of the city council is filed with the city clerk and signed by the owners of property constituting a majority in frontage, in area or in whatever other property constituting the basis for the computation of assessments, as the case may be, of the real estate to be assessed in the district or in the assessment unit, if the district is divided into assessment units, the proposed improvements shall not be made, unless the city pays one-half or more of the total cost of the improvements with funds derived from other than the levy of special assessments. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-9.)  
Sec. 22-25. - Modification, rescission, etc., generally. 
All proceedings may be modified or rescinded wholly or in part by resolution adopted by the council at any time prior to the passage of the ordinance adopted pursuant to sections 22-27 and 22-28 and authorizing the improvements to be made. No substantial change in the district, details, preliminary plans or specifications or estimates shall be made after the first publication or mailing of notice to property owners, whichever occurs first, except for the deletion of a portion of a project and property from the proposed program and district or assessment unit. The director of public works, however, shall have the right to make minor changes in time, plans and materials entering into the work at any time before its completion. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-9.)  
Sec. 22-26. - Revision of preliminary plans. 
(a)  Duty of director of public works. After the hearing on the proposed improvement plans after the city council has disposed of all remonstrances, so filed, and after the council has determined to proceed with the local improvement district, as modified, if modified, the council, if there be modification, by resolution shall direct the director of public works to prepare and present to the council: 
(1)  A revised and detailed estimate of the total cost, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the cost of constructing and otherwise acquiring each proposed improvement and of each of the incidental costs, which revised estimate shall not constitute a limitation for any purpose except as provided in this section. 
(2)  Full and detailed plans and specifications for each proposed improvement designed to permit and encourage competition among the bidders, if the work is to be acquired or improved by contract. 
(3)  A revised map showing the location of each improvement and the real property to be assessed therefor. 
(b)  Combination or division of construction units. The resolution modifying the proposed plan for improvements may combine or divide the proposed improvement or improvements into suitable construction units for the purpose of letting separate and independent contracts, regardless of the extent of any improvement constituting an assessment unit and regardless of whether a portion of the cost of any improvement is to be defrayed other than by the levy of special assessments. Nothing, however, contained in this section shall be construed as not requiring the segregation of costs for assessment purposes. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-10.)  
Sec. 22-27. - Ordinance adopting final plans, etc.—Generally. 
When an accurate estimate of cost, full and detailed plans and specifications and map are prepared and presented and are satisfactory to the council, it shall adopt an ordinance prescribing: 
(a)  The extent of the local improvement district to be assessed and of each assessment unit, if any, by boundaries or other brief description. 
(b)  The kind and location of each improvement proposed, without mentioning minor details. 
(c)  The amount or proportion of the total cost to be defrayed by special assessments, the method of levying assessments, the number of installments and the times in which the costs assessed will be payable. 
(d)  The character and extent of any construction units. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-10.)  
Sec. 22-28. - Same—Revision and amendment; letting of contract exceeding revised estimates. 
(a)  The director of public works may further revise such cost, plans and specifications and map from time to time for all or any part of any project and the ordinance may be appropriately amended prior to letting any construction contract therefor and prior to any work being done other than by independent contract let by the city. The ordinance, if amended, shall order the work to be done as provided for by this chapter. 
(b)  No contract shall be let for any improvement nor an improvement ordered acquired under the direction of the director or otherwise for any amount exceeding the revised estimated cost of the project excluding incidental costs. 
(Code 1968, § 8-5-10.)  
Article IV. - Construction Contracts. 
 
Sec. 22-29. - Letting of contract generally. 
(a)  Competitive bidding—Lowest responsible bidder required where contract exceeds five thousand dollars. In accordance with section 5, article IX of the city Charter, any improvement of any nature made in any district where the entire cost, value or amount of such work including labor and materials shall exceed five thousand dollars, except such work done by employees of the city with supplies and materials purchased by it or supplied under agreement with the United States of America, the state or any federal or state agency, instrumentality or corporation, shall be done only under independent contract to be entered into by the city with the lowest responsible bidder submitting the lowest and best bid upon proper terms after due public notice has been given asking for competitive bids. 
(b)  Same—Notice of desire for. The notice asking for competitive bids shall state that bids will be received at a time and place designated therein and shall be published at least twice a week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, the first publication to be not less than fifteen nor more than thirty days prior to the time specified in the notice for opening bids. 
(c)  Same—Right of city to reject bids and waive irregularities. The city shall have the right to reject any and all bids and to waive any irregularity in any bid. 
(d)  Contract may be on lump sum or unit basis. Any contract may be let on a lump sum or unit basis. 
(e)  Bond required. No contract shall be entered into for such work unless the contractor shall give an undertaking with a sufficient surety approved by the city council and in an amount fixed by the council for the faithful performance of the contract, substantially as required by state law, except as otherwise provided by this chapter. 
(f)  Reletting and recovery upon default of contracts. Upon default in the performance of any contract, the proper official may advertise and relet the remainder of the work without further ordinance and deduct the cost from the original contract price and recover any excess cost by suit on the original bond, or otherwise. 
(g)  Contract to require payment of materials, etc. All contracts shall provide among other things that the person entering into the contract with the city will pay for all materials furnished and services rendered for the performance of the contract, and that any person furnishing the materials or rendering the services may maintain an action to recover for the same against the obligor in the undertaking as though the person was named therein; provided, that the action is brought within one year after the time of the cause of action accrued. Final settlement shall be effected substantially as required by state law. 
(h)  Construction of improvement by city. The city shall have the power to make any improvement, or portion thereof, in any district, directly by the officers, agents and employees of the city, with supplies and materials purchased or otherwise acquired therefor. 
(Code 1968, § 8-6-1.) 
 For state law as to bonds for faithful performance by contractors, see C.R.S. 1973, § 38-26-106.  
Sec. 22-30. - Purchase of supplies and material by city. 
Pursuant to section 2, article IX of the city Charter, all supplies and materials purchased by the city for any district, but not by a contractor, costing five hundred dollars or more shall be purchased only after due advertisement as provided in the preceding section. The city shall accept the lowest bid if the kind, quality and material are equal, but the city shall have the right to reject any and all bids, to waive any irregularity in any bid and to select a single item from any bid. The provision as to bidding shall not apply to the purchase of patented and manufactured products offered for sale in a noncompetitive market or solely by a manufacturer's authorized dealer. 
(Code 1968, § 8-6-1.)  
Sec. 22-31. - Interest of officers and employees of city in contracts. 
Pursuant to section 4, article IX of the city Charter, no councilman, other elected official or appointed officer, agent or employee of the city, except in such official capacity, shall either directly or indirectly be a party to, or be in any manner interested in, any contract or agreement with the city for any matter, cause or thing whatsoever where any liability, indebtedness or obligation shall in any way be created against the city for any district, except by competitive bidding. If any contract or agreement is made in violation of the provisions of this section it shall be voidable, and no action shall be maintained thereon by any party thereto against the city. To the extent that the city makes any payment thereunder, such contract or agreement shall be valid, and any such payment may be included in any cost defrayed by the levy of special assessments, unless theretofore the city elects to void the contract or agreement in its entirety and to recover any such payment from the party to whom made. 
(Code 1968, § 8-6-1.)  
Sec. 22-32. - Federal or state assistance generally. 
The city may enter into and carry out any contract or establish or comply with the rules and regulations concerning labor and materials and other related matters in connection with any project or portion thereof as the city may deem desirable or as may be requested by the United States of America, the state or any federal or state agency, instrumentality or corporation that may assist in the financing of any project or any part thereof. Any improvement, of which any portion of the cost may be defrayed by the city by the levy of special assessments, may be acquired with the cooperation and assistance of, under a contract let by or with labor, supplies and materials furnished by, the United States of America, the state or any federal or state agency, instrumentality or corporation. Advantage may be taken of any offer from any source to complete any improvement on a division of expense or responsibility. The department of public works under the direction of its director on behalf of and in the name of the city is authorized to make any such improvement in such a manner, when so authorized by an ordinance adopted pursuant to sections 22-26 to 22-28. 
(Code 1968, § 8-6-1.)  
Sec. 22-33. - Applicability of division to assigned or transferred contracts. 
The provisions of sections 22-29 to 22-32 shall not apply to any case in which the city has taken over by transfer or assignment any contract authorized to be assigned to it under the provisions of this chapter nor to any contract in connection with the construction or improvement of any project which the city may have had transferred to it by any person. 
(Code 1968, § 8-6-1.)  
Sec. 22-34. - Paving guarantees.
