In all cases of paving, any specifications and contracts may provide that bidders shall guarantee that the paving shall remain in good order and repair for a period of five years from and after the date of its acceptance by the council, or for such lesser period as may be determined by the council, and make all necessary repairs during such period without further compensation; provided, that in case of macadamizing, after two years the guarantee, if any, shall extend only to the maintaining of a perfect grade, surface and foundation and not to any diminution of the thickness of the original pavement by wear and tear; in case of concrete curb, gutter or sidewalk, the specifications and contracts may provide for a guarantee not in excess of two years; and the council may provide for a guarantee for a reasonable time, not to exceed two years of all other work. 
(Code 1968, § 8-6-2.)  
Sec. 22-35. - Reservation by city of power to impose conditions. 
The council, except as specifically limited by this chapter, may, in the letting of contracts, impose such conditions upon bidders with regard to bonds and securities, guarantees of good and faithful performance and completion of the work and keeping the same in repair and any further matter or thing in connection therewith as may be considered by the council advantageous to the city and to all interested. 
(Code 1968, § 8-6-3.)  
Article V. - Bonds Generally. 
 
Sec. 22-36. - Use permitted; manner of sale, etc. 
(a)  All local improvements may be paid for by public improvement bonds of the city. 
(b)  Any bonds issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may be sold in such manner as may be approved by the city council for the payment of the contractor for defraying the reasonable costs for labor, supplies and materials incurred by the city or supplied under agreement with the United States of America, the state or any federal or state agency, instrumentality or corporation and for all proper incidental expenses. Such bonds may be also delivered to the contractor in payment for the amounts due such contractor. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-1.)  
Sec. 22-37. - Interest—Generally. 
(a)  Repealed. 
(b)  Delivery to contractors. If delivered to the contractor, the bonds shall be accepted at par plus interest due thereon to the date of their delivery in payment of the amounts due under the contract and the contractor shall be required to accept delivery of the remainder of the authorized issue of bonds and to pay the principal amount of such bonds and accrued interest to the date of delivery, so that money will be available to the council to be expended in the payment of the incidental expenses for the payment of which the bonds were in part authorized. Delivery of such bonds to contractors shall always be on such terms that the consideration for the bonds, represented by amounts due contractors and money, shall be such as to result in a net interest cost on the bonds of not more than eight percent per annum computed to maturity according to standard tables of bond values. 
(c)  Rates relative to assessment interest rates. No bond interest rate shall at any time exceed the interest rate, the lower or lowest rate, if more than one, borne by the assessments, but any bond interest rate may be the same as or less than any assessment interest rate, subject to the limitation of this section, as the council may determine. 
(d)  Acceptance of bonds as condition in bidding. In advertising for construction bids as provided in section 22-29 the council may stipulate that the contractor must accept bonds in payment of the contract price as provided in this section. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-1; Ord. No. 547, § 1.)  
Sec. 22-38. - Same—Coupons. 
(a)  Attachment; signature required. Except for such bonds which are registerable for payment of interest, interest coupons shall be payable to the bearer and they shall be attached to the bonds and shall bear the original or facsimile signature of the officers signing the bonds. 
(b)  Validity of signature. The bond and coupons, bearing the signatures of the officers in office at the time of the signing thereof, shall be the valid and binding obligations of the city, notwithstanding that before the delivery and payment, any or all of the persons whose signatures appear on such shall have ceased to fill their respective offices. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-6.)  
Sec. 22-39. - Issuance and payment generally. 
(a)  Form; date; to be issued in name of city; to be payable to bearer at certain time; amounts. All local improvement bonds shall be of such form and of such date as may be prescribed by the council, shall be issued in the name of the city and bear the name of the district to be improved and shall be payable to bearer at a designated time in a sufficient period of years to cover the period of construction and payments provided for, but subject to call as provided by this article, in convenient denominations of not more than one thousand dollars each. All such bonds shall be issued by the director of finance upon estimates of the director of public works and order of the city manager, approved by the council. 
(b)  Records. The director of finance shall preserve a record of such bonds in a suitable book kept for the purpose. 
(c)  Signing and attesting. The bonds shall be subscribed by the city manager, attested by the city clerk with the seal of the city affixed thereto and countersigned by the director of finance. 
(d)  To be payable out of assessments only. The bonds, both principal and interest, shall be payable only out of monies collected on account of the assessments for the improvements in any district, except as provided by this article. Such assessments shall be applied to the payment of the bonds issued for the same district only, until all of such bonds have been paid. 
(e)  Pledge of special surplus and deficiency fund as security. The payment of such bonds shall be additionally secured by a pledge of and made from the special surplus and deficiency fund, and whenever four-fifths of the bonds of any public improvement district have been paid and cancelled, and for any reason the remaining assessments are not paid in time to take up the final bonds of the district and there is not sufficient money in such special surplus and deficiency fund, the city shall pay such bonds when due and reimburse itself by collecting the unpaid assessments due such district, all as authorized by section 4, article XIII of the city Charter. 
(f)  Additional security. The payment of any bonds, both as to principal and interest, may also be additionally secured as otherwise provided in and authorized by article XIII of the city Charter. 
(g)  Payment of incidentals with bonds. A sufficient number of such bonds or the proceeds therefrom may be used to pay for engineering and clerical service and supplies, inspection, collecting assessments, advertising, printing, accrued interest on outstanding bonds, fiscal services, legal services and other incidentals. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-2.)  
Sec. 22-40. - Liability of city; to be paid out of assessments only. 
Bonds issued pursuant to this article shall not be a debt of the city and the city shall not be liable thereon, nor shall it thereby pledge its full faith and credit for their payment, nor shall the bonds be payable out of any funds other than the special assessments and other monies pledged to the payment thereof. Each bond issued under this chapter shall recite in substance that such bond and the interest thereon are payable solely from the special assessments and other monies pledged to the payment thereof. The payment of bonds shall not be secured by an encumbrance, mortgage or other pledge of property of the city, except for such special assessments and other monies pledged for the payment of bonds. No property of the city, subject to such exceptions, shall be liable to be forfeited or taken in payment of the bonds. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-3.)  
Sec. 22-41. - Effect of irregularity in issuance, delivery or sale; status in hands of bona fide purchaser or holder for value. 
Bonds issued under this chapter shall not be invalid for any irregularity or defect in the proceedings for their issuance, sale or delivery and shall be incontestable in the hands of bona fide purchasers or holders for value. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-4.)  
Sec. 22-42. - Terms; conditions generally. 
Except as otherwise provided, any special assessment bonds authorized to be issued shall bear such date, shall mature in such denomination at such time or term, or serially at such time, not exceeding the estimated life of the improvements acquired with the bond proceeds and in any event not more than twenty years from the date of issuance, shall bear interest payable annually, or at such lesser interval or as may be prescribed by ordinance, at such rate not greater than eight percent per annum, shall be payable in such medium of payment at such place within or without the state, and at the option of the council may be in one or more series, may be made subject to prior redemption in advance of maturity at such time with or without the payment of such premium not exceeding five percent of the principal amount of each bond so redeemed, except as provided by this division, may provide for the payment of interest thereon from the proceeds thereof for a period not to exceed three years from the date thereof, may be issued with privileges for registration for payment as to principal or interest, or both, and generally shall be issued in such manner, in such form, with such recitals, terms, covenants and conditions and with such other details as may be provided by the council in the ordinance authorizing the bonds, except as otherwise provided. Except for payment provisions specifically provided in this chapter, such bonds and any interest coupons attached thereto shall be fully negotiable within the meaning of and for all the purposes of the negotiable instruments law. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-5.)  
Sec. 22-43. - Use of proceeds; validity not dependent on acquisition proceedings, etc. 
All monies received from the issuance of any bonds authorized by this article shall be used solely for the purpose for which issued, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the payment of preliminary expenses incurred in connection with such purpose, the payment of interest on such bonds for a period not to exceed three years from the date thereof and all other incidental expenses; provided, that any unexpended balance of such bond proceeds remaining after the completion of the acquisition or improvement of the project or service for which such bonds were issued shall be paid immediately into the fund created for the payment of the principal of such bonds and shall be used therefor. The validity of such bonds shall not be dependent on nor affected by the validity or regularity of any proceedings relating to the acquisition or improvement of the project or service for which the bonds are issued. The purchaser of the bonds shall in no manner be responsible for the application of the proceeds of the bonds by the city or any of its officers, agents and employees. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-7.)  
Sec. 22-44. - Calling in by director of finance. 
Whenever considered advisable by the director of finance he may, and whenever funds may be in his hands to the credit of any local improvement district exceeding the amount of interest on the unpaid principal accruing on the next principal payment date and, if maturing serially, the principal accruing on the next principal payment date, he shall by publication at least once not less than fifteen days prior to the redemption date, in some newspaper of general circulation in the city, call in a suitable number of bonds of such district for payment of the principal amount thereof and accrued interest to the redemption date. After the redemption date so designated interest on the bonds so called shall cease. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as preventing the city from providing that such bonds shall be redeemed only on interest payment dates. The notice shall specify the bonds so called by number and all such bonds shall be paid in the order designated in the authorizing ordinance. The holder of any bonds may at any time furnish his post office address to the director of finance and in such case a copy of such advertisement shall be mailed by the director of finance to the holder of the bonds called, at such address, within three days of the date of such publication. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-8.)  
Sec. 22-45. - Surplus and deficiency fund generally. 
(a)  Excess to be paid into fund. When all outstanding bonds have been paid in a public improvement district and any money remains to the credit of such district, it shall be transferred to the special surplus and deficiency fund. 
(b)  Deficiencies to be paid out of fund. Whenever there is a deficiency in any improvement district to meet the payment of outstanding bonds, money to cover such deficiency shall be paid out of such fund, pursuant to section 4, article XIII of the city Charter. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-9.)  
Sec. 22-46. - Rights of holders generally. 
(a)  Enumerated. Subject to any contractual limitations binding upon the holders of any issue or series of bonds or trustee therefor including but not limited to the restriction of the exercise of any remedy to a specified proportion, percentage or number of such holders, any holder of bonds or trustee therefor shall have the right and power, for the equal benefit and protection of all holders of bonds similarly situated: 
(1)  By mandamus or other suit, action or proceeding at law or in equity to enforce his rights against the city and its council and any of its officers, agents and employees and to require and compel the city or its council or any such offices, agents or employees to perform and carry out its and their duties, obligations or other commitments under this article and its and their covenants and agreements with the bondholders. 
(2)  By action or suit in equity to require the city and its council to account as if they were the trustees of an express trust. 
(3)  By action or suit in equity to have appointed a receiver, which receiver may take possession of any accounts and may collect, receive and apply all revenues or other monies pledged for the payment of the bonds in the same manner as the city itself might do. 
(4)  By action or suit in equity to enjoin any acts or things which may be unlawful or in violation of the rights of the bondholders. 
(5)  To bring suit upon the bonds. 
(b)  Remedies not exclusive; failure to prosecute remedy not to relieve city, etc. No right or remedy conferred by this article upon any holder of bonds or any trustee therefor is intended to be exclusive of any other right or remedy, but each such right or remedy is cumulative in addition to every other right or remedy and may be exercised without exhausting and without regard to any other remedy conferred by the city Charter or by any other law. The failure of any bondholder to proceed as provided by this section shall not relieve the city, its council or any of its officers, agents and employees of any liability for failure to perform or carry out any duty, obligation or other commitment. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-10.)  
Sec. 22-47. - Preliminary expenses. 
The city may provide for the payment of all necessary preliminary expenses actually incurred in the making of surveys, estimates of costs and revenues, the employment of engineers, architects, fiscal agents, attorneys at law, clerical help, other agents or employees, the making of notices, taking of options and all other expenses necessary or desirab1e to be made and paid prior to the authorization for or the issuance of such bonds; provided, that no such expenditures shall be made or paid unless an appropriation has been budgeted and made therefor in the same manner as is required by law, or unless other monies are available to defray such expenses. Any funds so expended by the city for preliminary expenses incurred in connection with the same purpose as that for which bonds are issued may be fully reimbursed and repaid to the city out of the proceeds derived from the issuance of such bonds, in which case such expenses shall be included as an incidental cost for assessment purposes. The amount so advanced by the city to pay such preliminary expenses may, by an ordinance authorizing the issuance of such bonds, be made a first charge against such bond proceeds until the same has been repaid, and, in such event, such amount shall be paid therewith before any other disbursements are made therefrom. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-11.)  
Sec. 22-48. - Refunding. 
(a)  Permitted. Any bonds issued under this article may be refunded pursuant to an ordinance to be adopted by the council in the manner provided for the issuance of other bonds. 
(b)  Security. Refunding bonds so issued may be secured in such manner and may be made payable from such sources as was provided in the ordinance authorizing their issuance; provided, that the security for the payment of the refunding bonds shall not be greater than the security for the payment of the bonds refunded, nor shall there be pledged for the payment of the refunding bonds revenues which are not pledged for the payment of the bonds refunded. 
(c)  Sale or exchange. Refunding bonds so issued may be sold at public or private sale or may be exchanged dollar for dollar for the bonds to be refunded. 
(d)  Escrow for proceeds of sales. If sold, the proceeds of sale may be escrowed for the payment of the bonds to be refunded in such manner as may be provided in the ordinance authorizing the refunding bonds. 
(e)  When bonds are refundable. No bonds may be refunded under this article unless they either mature or are callable for redemption under their terms within twelve months from the date of issuance of the refunding bonds, or unless the holders thereof voluntarily surrender them for exchange or payment. 
(Code 1968, § 8-8-12.)  
Article VI. - Levy and Collection of Assessments Generally. 
 
Sec. 22-49. - Preparation of statement of costs and assessment rolls. 
(a)  Statement of costs. Upon the completion of any local improvement in any district, or in case of assessment units of sewers, upon completion from time to time of a project in any assessment unit or any part of sewers affording complete drainage for any part of the district, upon the acceptance thereof by the city council or whenever the total cost of such improvement, or any of such part of sewers can be definitely ascertained and upon the council's determination to assess all or a part of the cost thereof, the director of public works shall prepare a statement showing the total cost of the improvement, or of any part thereof, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the cost of constructing or otherwise acquiring such improvement, engineering and clerical service and supplies, cost of inspection, cost of collecting assessments, advertising, printing, interest on bonds until interest on assessments is available to defray such, fiscal services, legal services for preparing proceedings and advising in regard thereto and other incidental costs. 
(b)  Assessment roll. The director of public works also shall prepare an assessment roll which shall contain among other things: 
(1)  The names of the last known owners of the property to be assessed, or if not known that the name is unknown. 
(2)  A description of each tract or parcel of land to be assessed, and in the case of street or other railway company a general description of the franchise and property thereof assessed. 
(3)  The amount of the assessment thereon. 
The council shall order the director to certify, and he shall certify, the assessment roll to the city council by filing the same in the office of the city clerk when the roll is to prepared. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-1.)  
Sec. 22-50. - Hearing upon assessment roll. 
(a)  Council to fix time and place. When the assessment roll is certified and filed, the city council shall fix a time and place when objections or remonstrances thereto by the owners of such real estate to be assessed, street or other railway companies and all interested persons will be heard. 
(b)  Notice. The city clerk shall, after the fixing of the time and place for such hearing, give notice of such hearing by publication once a week for two consecutive weeks by two weekly insertions, the first publication to be not more than thirty nor less than fifteen days prior to the hearing, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, and by mailing notice, postage prepaid, as first class mail, at least fifteen days prior to such hearing, to the last known address of each last known owner of land within the district whose property will be assessed for the cost of the improvements, such addresses and owners being those appearing on the real property assessment rolls for general, ad valorem, taxes of the county where such property is located. The notice shall state: 
(1)  That such assessment roll is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(2)  The date of filing such assessment roll. 
(3)  The time and place, when and where the city council will hear and consider objections and remonstrances to the assessment roll and to the proposed assessments by the parties thereby aggrieved. 
(c)  Filing of objections by owners, etc. The owner of any property which is assessed in such assessment roll, such street or other railway company or other interested persons, whether named in such roll, may, within twelve days from the first publication of such notice, file with the city clerk any specific objections in writing. Any objection to the regularity, validity and correctness of the proceedings of such assessment roll, of each assessment contained therein and of the amount levied on each tract and parcel of land shall be deemed waived unless presented in writing at the time and in the manner specified by this chapter. 
(d)  Hearing of objections; consideration of objections, etc., by council; decision of council. At the time and place designated for hearing such objections, the city council shall hear and determine all written objections or remonstrances which have been filed by any party interested to the regularity of the proceedings in making such assessment, the correctness of such assessment or of the amount levied on any particular tract or parcel of land to be assessed. The council shall have the power to consider any other matter concerning the validity of any assessment and the power to adjourn such hearing from time to time. After the hearing has been concluded, after all written complaints, remonstrances and objections have been read and duly considered and after all persons desiring to be heard in person have been heard the council shall consider the arguments, if any, and any other relevant material put forth. Thereafter, the council by resolution shall have power, in its discretion, to revise, correct, confirm or set aside any assessment and to order that such assessment be made de novo. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-2.)  
Sec. 22-51. - Ordinance levying assessment. 
(a)  Required. The council by ordinance shall, by reference to the assessment roll, if modified and as confirmed by such resolution, levy the assessments in such roll. 
(b)  To be final determination. Such decision, resolution and ordinance shall be a final determination of the regularity, validity and correctness of the proceedings of such assessment roll, of each assessment contained therein and of the amount levied on each tract and parcel of land. That determination by the council shall be conclusive upon the owners of the property assessed. 
(c)  Statement of provisions of section 22-52. The ordinance also shall state substantially the provisions in section 22-52. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-2.)  
Sec. 22-52. - Statute of limitations on actions to correct or set aside assessment. 
Within the fifteen days immediately succeeding the publication after its final passage of any ordinance levying any special assessments, any person who has filed a written objection or remonstrance shall have the right to commence an action or suit in any court of competent jurisdiction to correct or set aside such determination. Thereafter all actions or suits attacking the regularity, validity and correctness of the proceedings of such assessment roll, of each assessment contained therein and of the amount levied on each tract and parcel of land shall be perpetually barred. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-2.)  
Sec. 22-53. - Liens. 
(a)  Effective date. All assessments made pursuant to this chapter shall be a lien from the date of its publication after final passage in the several amounts assessed against each tract or parcel of land and the property of any street or railway company assessed from the date of the publication after final passage of the assessing ordinance. 
(b)  Persons, etc., exempted. A lien shall not, however, attach to any tract or parcel of land so assessed which is owned by the state or any agency, instrumentality or corporation thereof, any county, municipality, school district, special or quasi-municipal district, other political subdivision or private corporation operating a public utility. 
(c)  Attachment in subdivisions. As to any subdivision of any real estate assessed pursuant to this chapter, the assessments shall in each case be a lien upon all the subdivisions in proportion to their respective shares, except for real estate owned by such a public corporation or privately owned public utility. 
(d)  Priority. The lien for each such assessment shall be prior and superior to all other liens, claims, encumbrances and titles, whether prior in time or not, and shall constitute such a lien until paid except as follows: 
(1)  Any assessment lien shall be subordinate and junior to any lien for general, ad valorem, taxes and shall be subject to extinguishment by the sale of any property on account of the nonpayment of general taxes. 
(2)  Any assessment lien on any tract or parcel of land shall be prior and superior to any assessment lien thereon subsequently levied. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-3.)  
Sec. 22-54. - Effect of delays, errors, etc. 
No delays, mistakes, errors, defects or irregularities in any act or proceeding authorized by this chapter shall prejudice or invalidate any final assessment, but the same shall be remedied by subsequent or amended acts or proceedings as the case may require, and when so remedied the same shall take effect as of the date of the original act or proceedings. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-3.)  
Sec. 22-55. - Reassessments on finding assessment invalid. 
If in any court of competent jurisdiction, any final assessment made pursuant to this chapter is set aside for irregularity in proceedings, the council may, upon notice as required in the making of an original assessment, make a new assessment in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-3.)  
Sec. 22-56. - Completion and extension of assessment roll from assessment ordinance. 
The director of finance shall from the assessing ordinance complete and extend the assessment roll by showing, in suitable columns after each piece of real estate and railway company assessed and after the total amount of the assessment for each piece of real estate and railway company, the amounts of each installment of principal and interest, if pursuant to this article the same is payable in installments, and the date when such installments will become due, with suitable columns for use in case of payment of the whole amount or of any installment or penalty. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-4.)  
Sec. 22-57. - Payments—When due; installment payments generally. 
All assessments made pursuant to this article shall be due and payable without demand within thirty days after its publication upon its final passage. 
All such assessments may at the election of the owner be paid in installments with interest. 
Failure to pay the whole assessment within such period of thirty days shall be conclusively considered and held an election on the part of all persons interested, whether under disability or otherwise, to pay in installments. All persons electing to pay in installments shall be conclusively considered and held as consenting to such improvements, and such election shall be conclusively considered and held as a waiver of any and all rights to question the power or jurisdiction of the city to construct or otherwise acquire the improvements, the quality of the work, the regularity or sufficiency of the proceedings of the validity or correctness of the assessment. 
The owner of any piece of real estate may at any time pay the whole unpaid principal with the interest accrued to the next interest payment date, together with penalties if any, and either without or with the payment of any prepayment premium not exceeding five per centum of the unpaid principal so prepaid, as the council may provide according to sections 22-50 and 22-51 of this Code. Subject to the foregoing provisions all installments both of principal and interest, shall be payable at such times as may be determined in and by section 22-50. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-5; Ord. No. 497, § 3.)  
Sec. 22-58. - Same—Effect of failure to pay. 
Failure to pay any installment, whether principal or interest, when due shall, ipso facto, cause the whole amount of the unpaid principal to become due and payable immediately, and the whole amount of the unpaid principal and accrued interest shall thereafter draw interest at the rate of one percent per month or fraction of a month until the day of sale, not exceeding, however, at any time a total interest amount due of thirty percent of the principal amount of the assessment, i.e., the time of the issuance of a delinquency certificate, plus two percent additional on unpaid principal and accrued interest as penalties, plus costs of collection. At any time prior to the day of sale, the owner may pay the amount of delinquent installments with accrued interest at one percent per month, or fraction of a month, and all penalties and costs of collection accrued and shall thereupon be restored to the right to pay in installments in the same manner as if default had not been made. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-6.)  
Sec. 22-59. - Same—Payment by installment. 
(a)  Number and frequency. In case of such election to pay in installments, the assessment of the principal shall be payable in not less than two or more than fifteen substantially equal annual installments, or not less than four nor more than thirty substantially equal semi-annual installments. 
(b)  Payment of interest. The interest in all such cases on the unpaid principal shall be payable annually or semi-annually at a rate not exceeding eight percent per annum, but not less than the highest interest rate borne by the bonds of the local improvement district. The number of installments, assessments, period of payment and rate of interest may be determined by the council. 
(c)  Power of council to set first payment. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as limiting the discretion of the city council in determining the time the first installment of principal or interest, or both, shall become due. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-7.)  
Sec. 22-60. - Same—Payment within thirty days without penalty or interest; notice of payment dates and places. 
(a)  Payments may be made to the director of finance at any time within thirty days after the final publication of the assessing ordinance without penalty or the payment of interest. 
(b)  The director of finance shall give notice by publication in at least one newspaper of general circulation in the city, at least once a week for two consecutive weeks by two weekly insertions, the first publication to be at least twenty days before the end of such thirty-day period, of the place of payment and the time for it to close. Before any installment payment date such a notice shall also be so published. The failure of the director to publish such notice or to do any other act or thing required by this section shall not affect such assessment or any installment thereof, nor extend the time for payment thereof, but shall subject the director to liability to the property owner for any damage he may sustain by reason of such failure. Such other notice may be given as deemed desirable by the city council, city manager or director of finance. 
(Code 1968, § 8-9-8 )  
Article VII. - Collection of Delinquent Assessments. 
 
Sec. 22-61. - Notation of delinquency and interest thereon by director of finance. 
As soon as any assessment or installment thereof of any local improvement district becomes delinquent, the director of finance shall mark the same as delinquent on the assessment roll and, in addition to the amount of unpaid principal shown on such assessment roll and accrued interest thereon to the date of delinquency, shall note on the roll the accrual of interest at the penalty rate provided by this chapter plus the two percent penalty and costs of collection. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-1.)  
Sec. 22-62. - Delinquency certificates—Preparation and issuance; effect; contents; records. 
Within ten days after a delinquency has been noted by the director of finance as provided in section 22-61, the director of finance shall prepare and issue to the city a delinquency certificate to the property included in each such delinquent assessment, which certificate shall have the force and effect of a sale of such property to the city for the amount thereof. 
Such certificate shall be dated as of the time such assessment or installment became delinquent and shall be for the amount of the unpaid principal and the accrued interest to the date of delinquency, plus any accrued interest after such date on such principal, and accrued interest at the penalty rate, as well as the penalty charged thereon, and collection costs. Such certificate shall contain besides the description of the property sold, the name of the person assessed, if known, or if unknown, that fact, the amount of the unpaid principal of the assessment and the accrued interest to the date of delinquency, plus the rate of penalty interest and the penalty thereon, the number of the assessment, the name of the improvement district in which assessed and the date when such certificate will go to deed. 
Such certificate shall be made in duplicate, bound together in books in numerical order and filed in the office of the director of finance. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-1.)  
Sec. 22-63. - Same—Local improvement district delinquency certificate register. 
(a)  Entry of delinquency certificates. Within twenty days after preparing and issuing any delinquency certificate for any tract or parcel of land the director of finance shall enter the same in a book to be kept by the director known as "Local Improvement District Delinquency Certificate Register." 
(b)  Contents. Such register shall contain, in proper columns, the number of the assessment, the name of the district in which assessed, the name of the person to whom assessed, if known, the description of the property sold, corresponding with the description in the certificate and the assessment roll, the amount of assessment and interest and the rate of penalty interest and penalty. The director must regularly number each entry in such register on the margin of such book and put a corresponding number on cach original and duplicate delinquency certificate. Such register must contain blank spaces following each entry of a delinquency certificate therein, in which may be entered the name of an assignee thereof, the date of such assignment and the amount paid the assignee, the name of a redemptioner thereof, the date of such redemption and the amount paid by such redemptioner. 
(c)  To be part of records of director of finance. Such book or register shall be retained by the director of finance and become a part of the records of his office. 
(d)  Period in which purchase of certificate may occur. From and after entry in such register and until two years from its date, any such certificate, unless redeemed, may be purchased from the director in the manner provided by this chapter. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-2.)  
Sec. 22-64. - Same—Purchase and assignment generally. 
Whenever any person tenders to the director of finance in cash the amount of any delinquency certificate, i.e., the unpaid principal and accrued interest to the date of delinquency, and interest thereon at the rate of one percent per month from date of such certificate to the end of the month in which such purchase is made, not exceeding, however, at any time a total interest amount due of thirty percent of the principal amount of the assessment, together with penalties and costs of collection, the director shall assign such delinquency certificate to the purchaser by making and executing for and on behalf of the city the blank assignment on both the original and duplicate thereof and shall deliver the original certificate so assigned to the purchaser. Thereafter the director shall immediately make the proper entries showing such assignment in the local improvement district delinquency register. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-3.)  
Sec. 22-65. - Same—Form of assignment. 
The assignment of delinquency certificates as provided by section 22-64 must be substantially in the following form and endorsed on the certificate: 
ASSIGNMENT BY 
DIRECTOR OF 
FINANCE 
	
State of Colorado 	) ss. 
City of Cortez 	) 
	
For and in consideration of the sum of $ ____________ paid to said City, the receipt whereof is hereby acknowledged, I do hereby assign to ____________ whose post office address is ____________ all the right, title and interest of the said City in and to the within and foregoing delinquency certificate. 
In witness whereof, I have hereunto set my hand at Cortez, Colorado, this ____________ day of_ ____________ , 19 ____________ . 
 
	____________ 
	Director of Finance 
	City of Cortez, Colorado 
 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-4.)  
Sec. 22-66. - Same—Assignment by purchaser. 
(a)  A delinquency certificate purchased pursuant to the provisions of this article may be assigned by the purchaser; provided, that such assignment must be attached to the original delinquency certificate and a duplicate of such assignment must be delivered to the director of finance who must attach the same to the duplicate delinquency certificate in his office. 
(b)  The assignment of any delinquency certificate by the purchaser thereof or any assignee of such purchaser must be executed in duplicate and acknowledged as provided by law in the conveyance of real property. Such assignment must be substantially in the following form: 
	
For value received, I hereby assign to ____________ whose post office address is ;daterule;, all my right, title and interest in and to delinquency certificate No. ____________ , issued by the Director of Finance of Cortez, Colorado, on account of delinquent local improvement district assessments for the year 19 ____________ , on the property described in said certificate. 
In witness whereof, I have hereunto set my hand this ____________ day of ____________ , 19 ____________ . 
	
	_____
(acknowledgment) 
 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-4.)  
Sec. 22-67. - Redemption of property generally. 
(a)  Payment required. At any time within two years from the date of any delinquency certificate, the owner of the property described therein, or anyone on his behalf, may redeem such property by paying to the director of finance the amount stated in such certificate, i.e., the unpaid principal and accrued interest to the date of delinquency, together with interest thereon or thereafter at the rate of one percent per month or fraction thereof from date thereof to the last day of the month in which such redemption is made, not exceeding, however, at any time a total interest amount due of thirty percent of the principal amount of the assessment, plus the two percent penalty and any costs of collection. 
(b)  Issuance of redemption certificate. Thereupon the director of finance shall issue to the redemptioner a certificate of redemption which shall state the name of the redemptioner, the date of redemption, the number of the certificate so redeemed, the description of the property contained therein and the name of the district for which such certificate was issued. 
(c)  Notations to be made by director of finance. In case such certificate has not been assigned, the director shall note upon the original and duplicate delinquency certificate and, if assigned, upon the duplicate certificate the fact that the same has been redeemed and the date of redemption. The director shall also note the redemption upon the local improvement delinquency certificate register. 
(d)  Disposition of monies received. The money received from the redemption of any property described in a certificate which has been assigned shall be deposited by the director of finance to the credit of the person named in the last assignment of such certificate. 
(e)  Notice to assignees; reimbursement of assignees. The director shall thereupon give notice to such person, at the address shown by the record, of such deposit. Such person shall thereafter be paid the same by the director upon surrender of such certificate to the director who shall mark the same "paid" and hold it as a voucher. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-5.)  
Sec. 22-68. - Issuance of deed on unredeemed property. 
If the property described in any delinquency certificate is not redeemed within two years from the date thereof, the director of finance, after having given the notice required by this article, shall issue a deed thereto to the city or, if the same has been assigned, to the person holding the original delinquency certificate under assignment upon request therefor and upon the delivery to the director of such original certificate and filing proof of having given the notice as required by the director before making a deed to the city. Such deed shall recite substantially the matter contained in the certificate and that no person redeemed the property within the time allowed by law for its redemption. It shall be signed and acknowledged by the director of finance in the manner required by law to entitle the same to be recorded under the laws of this state. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-6.)  
Sec. 22-69. - Notice before expiration of redemption period—Required; contents. 
(a)  The director of finance shall, at least one month and not more than three months before the expiration of the time of redemption of any property, serve or cause to be served, a written, printed or partly written and partly printed notice on the person in the actual possession or occupancy of such land or lots, and shall also, within the same time, serve upon or mail postage prepaid by first class, to the person in whose name the same stands upon the real property assessment rolls for general, ad valorem, taxes of the county where such property is located, at the address stated therein, a copy of such notice. 
(b)  Such notice shall state when the delinquency certificate was made, in whose name the property was assessed, the description of the land or lots, the name of the local improvement district for which assessed and the amount of the unpaid principal and accrued interest to the date of delinquency, plus the rate of interest thereafter, the maximum amount of unpaid interest, the two percent penalty and any costs of collection. Such notice shall also state when the time of redemption will expire. 
(c)  The director of finance shall at the same time send a similar notice by mail to each mortgagee or other holder of a recorded lien against such land in each case where such mortgagee or lien holder has previously filed in the office of the director of finance a written request for such notice and paid the fee therefor. Such request shall include the name and address of the mortgagee, the name of the reputed owner of the land, a description of the land and the date of the expiration of the mortgage or lien. No notice need be sent after the date of expiration, unless a further request therefor is duly filed. If the mortgagee or lien holder furnishes a duplicate request form for that purpose the director shall certify thereon to the filing of the request and deliver the same to the party filing it. 
(d)  If there is no person in the actual possession or occupancy of such land or lot and if the person in whose name it stands, upon diligent inquiry, cannot be found in the state, the director shall, within the same time, post or have posted, in a conspicuous place upon such land or lots and in a substantial manner, a copy of such notice. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-7.)  
Sec. 22-70. - Same—Affidavits of compliance required. 
The director of finance shall, before issuing any deed to the city, make and file his affidavit showing full compliance with the requirements of the preceding section as to giving notice of the expiration of the period of redemption. 
Before issuing a deed to the holder of any delinquency certificate, the director shall require that affidavits be filed showing a complete compliance with the provisions of the previous section as to giving such notice. Such proof shall be filed in the office of the director of finance and remain a permanent record in such office. Any person making a false affidavit as to any fact required by this section shall be guilty of perjury. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-8.)  
Sec. 22-71. - Recitation of delinquency certificate matters in deed; evidentiary status of acknowledged or proved deed. 
The matters recited in the delinquency certificate must be recited in the deed and such deed duly acknowledged or proved and shall be prima facie evidence that: 
(a)  The improvement district was created, the assessment made and the work and improvement done in the manner provided by law. 
(b)  All notices were given, all hearings were had, orders were made and ordinances were passed and adopted as required by law and that all proceedings up to the execution and delivery of such deed were done in the manner required by law. 
(c)  The assessments were not paid, that the delinquency entries were properly made and delinquency certificate properly issued, as prescribed by law, and by the proper officer. 
(d)  The property was not redeemed, the notice required to be given before deed was taken was properly given as required by law and the person who executed the deed was the proper officer. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-9.)  
Sec. 22-72. - Fees to be received by director of finance. 
(a)  The director of finance shall receive the following fees which, when paid, shall be credited to the general fund of the city: 
(1)  For issuing any delinquency certificate, twenty-five cents, to be included in the amount of the certificate. 
(2)  For making any deed, one dollar, to be paid by the person to whom made. 
(3)  For giving notice to a mortgagee or lien holder, fifty cents, to be paid by such person. 
(4)  For giving notice of expiration of period of redemption, one dollar. 
(b)  In all cases where the property is deeded to the city the fees shall be charged to the amount for which the deed is taken and upon the sale of the property, or the sale of the delinquency certificate, shall be paid. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-10.)  
Sec. 22-73. - Quiet title actions. 
Whenever the necessary costs and attorney's fees have been advanced by the holders of the bonds of the district or any prospective purchaser or other person, it shall be the duty of the council to cause the city attorney to commence suit to quiet title to the property described in such deed in the name of the city and to secure the possession of the property; provide property described in any number of tax deeds made to the city and against any number of owners of property may be included in the same suit. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-11.)  
Sec. 22-74. - Sale of property acquired by city under article—Generally. 
(a)  Authority of city. At any time after acquiring title and possession of any property as provided by this division, the city may sell such property to any purchaser upon receiving therefor a sum not less than the amount for which the property was sold to the city. 
(b)  Purchaser to take subject to taxes and assessments. The purchaser shall take such property subject to any unpaid general taxes and assessments. 
(c)  Execution and issuance of deed. When such purchase is made and the money paid therefor, the city shall issue a deed to the purchaser signed by the mayor, attested by the city clerk and countersigned by the director of finance. Such deed shall be executed and acknowledged in the manner required by law to entitle the same to be recorded under the laws of this state. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-12.)  
Sec. 22-75. - Same—Procedures. 
(a)  Time for appraisal and sale; notice required. Within thirty days after the maturity of the last installment of any issue of bonds of a local improvement district, if any such bonds or interest coupons remain unpaid, any property remaining unsold, to which the city has taken title by reason of assessments of such improvement district, shall be appraised and immediately after such appraisement such property shall be offered for sale by giving notice of the time and place of sale by publication of such notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, at least once a week for three consecutive weeks by at least three weekly insertions therein, the date of sale to be not less than twenty-five days from the date of the first publication of such notice. 
(b)  Offer for sale; minimum price required for sale. At the time and place designated in the notice the director of finance shall offer such property for sale to the highest bidder, but no sale shall be made for less than the appraised value. 
(c)  Readvertisement on receipt of inadequate bids. If no bid is received for a sum equal to or greater than the appraised value, the sale may be postponed for not to exceed thirty days. Such property shall be readvertised and, at the time to which such sale was postponed, shall again be offered for sale and sold to the highest bidder. 
(d)  Issuance of deed. Upon the sale of any property and the payment therefor a deed shall be executed to the purchaser in the same manner as provided for the execution of deeds in section 22-74. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-13.)  
Sec. 22-76. - Same—Disposition of money received generally. 
All money received by the director of finance on account of the payment of assessments or installments thereof, the assignment or redemption of delinquency certificates, for rents, issues and profits, from the sale of any property, title to which is held by the city for the benefit of any local improvement district, less any expenses of securing possession of such property or for the care, operation and sale of the same shall be deposited to the credit of the interest and bond fund of the local improvement district in the same proportion as the assessment or installments for which the property was taken. Any money left in a local improvement district bond fund or any money derived from the rental or sale of any real property acquired by the city through sale for delinquent assessments or installments shall, after all warrants, bonds and coupons of such district have been paid in full, be credited to the special surplus and deficiency fund of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-14.)  
Sec. 22-77. - Same—Payment of liens. 
The city may use any available funds for the satisfaction of any lien prior in right to any special assessment lien created by the city. In the resale of any property to which the city has acquired title, the city shall use its best efforts to sell the property for an amount at least equal to the funds so used plus the amount necessary to satisfy the special assessment lien created by the city, principal, interest penalties and collection costs. The monies received from such a resale in payment for the property shall be used first to satisfy such special assessment lien and thereafter to restore to the fund from which any such prior lien was satisfied. Pursuant to section 5, article XIII of the City Charter, and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the city is authorized to acquire and dispose of property on which there are delinquent taxes, special assessments or both. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-15.)  
Sec. 22-78. - Same—Prohibited while court suit pending. 
No certificate of delinquency as provided for by this article shall be assigned nor any property to which the city has a deed sold, on account of any assessment or installment thereof, during the pendency of any proceedings in court affecting the validity of such assessment. 
(Code 1968, § 8-10-16.)  
Article VIII. - Construction and Design Standards. 
 
Sec. 22-79. - Adoption by reference. 
There is adopted by reference, pursuant to article III, section 11 of the Charter of the city, a certain construction design standards ordinance prepared by the Cortez planning and zoning commission. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 1.)  
Sec. 22-80. - Summary. 
Said ordinance provides in part for definitions, abbreviations, symbols, plans and specifications, plan revisions, as-built plans, general construction criteria, permits, excavation, backfilling and restoration, underground warning tape, protection of existing improvements, inspection and testing, and design materials, and methods for streets, water systems and sewer systems. 
(Ord. 546, § 2.)  
Sec. 22-81. - Copies on file. 
Three true, official, complete and full copies of this ordinance are on file in the office of the city clerk of the city, and may be examined, copied or reproduced by any interested person during regular business hours of the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 3.)  
Sec. 22-82. - Penalty. 
It shall be unlawful to erect, construct, reconstruct, alter or repair any item listed in the construction design standards ordinance in violation of any provision of this ordinance or any amendment thereof, or who interferes in any manner with any person in the performance of a right or duty granted or imposed upon him by the provisions of this ordinance, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished as set forth in Cortez City Code section 17-16A as now in effect or as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 546, § 4; amended by memo 3519.) 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 27, 9-25-12)  
Article IX. - Alternate Method of Constructing Public Improvements. 
 
Sec. 22-82.1. - Alternate method. 
Notwithstanding any provision of this Code to the contrary, the council may establish public improvement districts, construct improvements, issue special assessment bonds, and levy and collect special assessments in accordance with this article. The provisions of this article shall apply without regard to the provisions of articles I through VIII of this chapter 22; provided, however, that this article shall be an alternate method of accomplishing its objects, and shall not be deemed to impair or affect any other power or authority of the city, including without limitation articles I through VIII of this chapter 22. 
(Ord. No. 604, § 1.)  
Sec. 22-82.2. - Reimbursement agreements. 
The creation of a reimbursement agreement for the construction, installation, and acquisition of a public work or improvement therein, the costs of which, in whole or part, may be recovered by the initial developer of said improvement via a reimbursement agreement shall be as specified in the city of Cortez Land Use Code, chapter 6, section 27. 
(Ord. No. 1116.)  
Sec. 22-83. - Application of state law. 
The provisions of title 31, article 25, part 5, Colorado Revised Statutes, and all future amendments thereto, pertaining to special improvement districts in municipalities, and the provisions of title 11, article 57, part 1, Colorado Revised Statutes, and all future amendments thereto, pertaining to the issuance of public securities, shall apply to public improvement districts within the city and to the issuance of special assessment bonds, and the city shall be vested with all the rights, powers, and authority conferred thereby; provided, however, that the provisions of said Title 31, Article 25, Part 5, Colorado Revised Statutes, and all future amendments thereto, shall be modified and supplemented by the provisions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 604, § 1.)  
Sec. 22-84. - Initiation of public improvement district upon recommendation of director of public works. 
The creation of a public improvement district, and the construction, installation, and acquisition of a public work or improvement therein, the costs of which, in whole or in part, are to be assessed against property owners by the city, may be initiated by the council on recommendation of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 604, § 1.)  
Sec. 22-85. - Initiation of public improvement district by property owner petition. 
(a)  The creation of a public improvement district, and the construction, installation, and acquisition of a public work or improvement therein, the costs of which, in whole or in part, are to be assessed against property owners by the city, may be initiated by the council on petition of the property owners to be assessed for not less than a majority of the entire costs estimated to be assessed. A petition shall not be held invalid solely because actual costs to be assessed differ from estimated costs in the petition so that the petition was signed by less than the property owners to be assessed for a majority of the actual costs. If the property is owned by a corporate, governmental, or other such entity, the person or persons with the authority to contractually bind such entity shall be considered the property owner for the purpose of signing a petition. 
(b)  If a proposed public improvement district initiated by property owner petition includes two or more noncontiguous parcels, the petition must be subscribed by the property owners in each such parcel in accordance with subsection (a) hereof. 
(c)  A property owner petition for a proposed public improvement district should contain the signature of the property owner, the percentage of the cost to be borne by the property owner, the requested method of assessment, a description of the improvement petitioned for, a description of the property to be included within the district, and any other matters which may be necessary or appropriate; provided, however, that the council may accept a petition not in conformance with this subsection (c) where it is determined that the petition complies with subsections (a) and (b) hereof. 
(d)  Upon receipt of a property owner petition, the council may elect to proceed, at its sole discretion, either under this Article or under Article II of this Chapter 22, regardless of any provision in the petition to the contrary. 
(e)  The council need not proceed with the creation of a public improvement district initiated by property owner petition or the acquisition of any improvement or any part thereof after holding a hearing thereon, if the council determines that it is not in the public interest that the proposed improvement or part thereof, be constructed. Any particular kind of improvement, material therefor, or part thereof need not be acquired or located, as provided in the petition, if the council determines that such is not in the public interest. The council need not take any proceedings or action upon receiving any such petition if the council determines by resolution that the acquisition of the designated improvement probably is not feasible for the reason stated in such resolution. 
(f)  Upon receipt of a property owner petition, the council may, in its sole discretion, require the petitioners to make a cash deposit or pledge other security to defray the costs incurred by the city in connection with the improvement set forth in the petition. Failure to provide such security shall be grounds for rejection of the petition. Additional security may from time to time be similarly required as a condition precedent to continuation of action by the city. The cash so deposited or security so pledged may be nonrefundable at the council's option. 
(Ord. No. 604, § 1.)  
Sec. 22-86. - Limitation of actions. 
Any person filing with the council prior to or at the time of the hearing on the creation of the district, a written complaint, protest, or objection, shall have the right, within thirty days after final passage of the ordinance creating the district, to commence an action or suit based on such complaint, protest, or objection, in any court of competent jurisdiction, to correct or set aside any determination of the council, or to question or challenge the authority or proceedings taken by the council relating to the creation of the district, the issuance of bonds, the method of assessment, the estimated amount of any particular assessment, or the construction of improvements. Thereafter, all actions, suits, or proceedings challenging or questioning the validity of the creation of the district, the issuance of bonds, the method of assessment, the estimated amount of any particular assessment, or the construction of improvements, shall be perpetually barred. 
(Ord. No. 604, § 1.)  
CHAPTER 22A. - RECREATIONAL VEHICLES. 
 
Sec. 22A-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  Motor vehicle. Any self-propelled vehicle which is designated primarily for travel on the public highways and which is generally and commonly used to transport persons and property over the public highways. 
(b)  Racing of motor. Sudden acceleration or deceleration of recreational vehicle. 
(c)  Recreational vehicle. A self-propelled wheeled or tracked vehicle primarily designed to be operated for recreational purposes on land, or on land and water, other than roads or highways. This definition shall include, but is not limited to, motorcycles, motor bikes, motor scooters, motor bicycles, trail bikes, minibikes, tote-goats, dune buggies, go-carts, snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles. 
(d)  Stunting. Operating a vehicle in a manner causing it to weave or suddenly change course or the loss of body contact with the seat by a driver or passenger and which is not for the purpose of safe operation of such vehicle. 
(e)  Touring. Any repetitious driving in the same area which causes a disturbance or is done with the intent of calling attention to an operator or recreational vehicle. 
(f)  Written permission. A letter on official stationery of the jurisdiction involved, which sets out the authorization to use specific property for the operation of certain recreational vehicles within the city or a written letter of authorization signed by the owner of private property for the operation of such vehicles on said private property. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 1.)  
Sec. 22A-2. - Operation of motorcycles and other recreational vehicular devices. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a recreational vehicle in any of the following places without first obtaining written permission or authorization hereinafter required: 
(a)  On any property owned by the city, other than public streets and parks, except where such operation is specially permitted by written order of the city manager or his designated representative; 
(b)  Upon or within any city park property or other publicly held or controlled park or recreational property within the city except where such operation is specifically permitted by written order of the director of parks and recreation or his designated representative; 
(c)  On any Montezuma Valley Irrigation Ditch, right-of-way or easements unless such operation is specifically permitted by written order of the Montezuma Valley Irrigation Company manager or his designated representative; 
(d)  On any private property within the city except by the property owner only unless specific written permission has been given by the owner or designated representative of the owner of such property to the individual operating said vehicle. In this case, said property must be conspicuously posted at least every two hundred fifty feet designating said property as recreational vehicle area; 
(e)  Nothing in this section is intended to prevent the lawful operation of any motor vehicle or recreational vehicle on any public street, highway or alley in accordance with other applicable ordinances of the city or statutes of the state. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 2.)  
Sec. 22A-3. - Written permission—Specifically. 
When written permission is given for a recreational vehicle area as outlined in subsections (a) to (e) of section 22A-2, said written permission shall set forth the effective date of the use, hours of the use, the name of the property owner or his agent, and any specific conditions attached to the written permission. A copy of the order is to be delivered to the Cortez police department prior to the effective date of the authorization, together with a telephone number where the property owner or his agent may be reached on a twenty-four-hour basis. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 3.)  
Sec. 22A-4. - Parent responsibility. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the parent or legal guardian of any person under the age of eighteen to permit such minor to act in violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The parent or guardian shall be deemed equally liable for any violations of any person under the age of eighteen under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 4.)  
Sec. 22A-5. - Creating disturbance prohibited. 
No motorcycle or recreational vehicle shall be operated in any manner so as to cause a disturbance in any area of the city. Touring, stunting or the racing of motors is prohibited in any hospital or nursing home area and in residential areas. 
(Ord. No. 538, § 5.)  
CHAPTER 22B. - REFUSE COLLECTION.  
Article I. - In General. 
 
Sec. 22B-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings hereinafter set forth. 
Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, or other combustible material. 
Bag means a closed container of moisture-resistant plastic, paper or other pliable material which is waterproof and capable of holding solid wastes during normal handling conditions and which is of sufficient strength to contain the contents put into it without breaking or rupturing. 
Biodegradable means the natural breakdown of materials within one year or less when placed in a biologically active compost project by the action of living organisms which may be bacteria, fungi and actinomycetes. 
Biologically active means an environment of a managed compost project containing the elements of heat, moisture and oxygen. 
Brush means a voluntary growth of bushes or similar matter growing out of place in the location where such material is growing, and shall include all cuttings from trees and bushes, as well as high vegetable growth which may conceal filthy deposits. 
Combustible trash means paper, cardboard, leaves, straw, grass clippings, sawdust, shavings, small tree and shrub clippings and all similar flammable or combustible material which has been discarded. 
Commercial user means any person, firm, or corporation performing any business, occupation or profession. It shall also include buildings or structures used for residential occupancy for three or more families or groups of individuals living independently of each other in separate apartments. 
Garbage means decomposed animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food of any kind or character. 
Hazardous waste means any chemical, compound, substance or mixture that state or federal law designates as hazardous because it is ignitable, corrosive, reactive or toxic, including, but not limited to, solvents, degreasers, paint thinners, cleaning fluids, pesticides, adhesives, strong acids and alkalis and waste paints and inks. 
Hazardous waste shall also be interpreted to include those chemicals, compounds, substances or mixtures defined as such under the subtitle D regulations issued by the U. S. Environmental Protection Agency in 1988 and amendments thereto if effective, and those defined as such under the environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (ERCLA). 
Litter means scattered refuse or rubbish. 
Recyclable material includes, but is not limited to, metals, glass, plastic, and paper products, which are intended for reuse, remanufacture or reconstitution. Recyclable material may include used motor oil collected and transported in accordance with applicable state health and safety regulations. 
Refuse means, but shall not be limited to, all decomposed and nondecomposed solid wastes, except sewage and body waste, such as garbage, rejected or waste food, offal, swill, carrion, ashes, dirt, slop, waste cement, waste paper, trash, rubbish, waste or unwholesome material of any kind, street cleanings, litter, dead animals, and industrial wastes except those substances defined as hazardous waste. 
Residential user means a dwelling or structure used for residential purposes and containing not more than two families or groups of individuals living independently of each other in separate apartments. 
Rubbish means, but shall not be limited to, all nondecomposed solid wastes, excluding ashes, such as vehicle bodies, and solid wastes, combustible and noncombustible wastes such as paper, cardboard, cans, wood, yard clippings, leaves, dirt, grass, bedding material, weeds, litter, crockery, glassware, glass and similar materials. 
Ruins means the remains of something collapsed, dilapidated or destroyed. 
Sanitation supervisor means any person appointed by the public works director or city manager to perform the duties imposed upon such person by the city code. 
Solid waste means solid or semisolid discarded material including, but not necessarily limited to, ashes, combustible trash, garbage, refuse and rubbish. 
Weed means an unsightly, useless, troublesome or injurious herbaceous plant when such plant is out of place at the location at which it is growing, and includes all rank vegetable growth which emits unpleasant or noxious odors, as well as high and rank vegetable growth that may conceal filthy deposit. 
Wreckage means the broken, disrupted and disordered parts or material from a disabled, collapsed, destroyed or dilapidated structure, vehicle, or other object. 
Yard waste means grass clippings, lawn rakings, leaves, garden vegetation, brush and other woods, free of other debris or refuse. 
(Ord. No. 742 (part).)  
Article II. - Collection.  
Division 1. - Generally. 
 
Sec. 22B-2. - Responsibility of city. 
The city shall make refuse collection and disposal service available to all residents of the city. 
Nothing within this article shall preclude such services from being offered to city residents by private businesses involved in the hauling of trash or refuse; provided, however, such private businesses shall comply with the provisions of Section 22B-3, 22B-6, and 22B-9 and such other rules and regulations that the city council may adopt from time to time upon recommendation of the public works director or city manager. Any user charges authorized by the city council pursuant to resolutions enacted under the authority of Section 22B-8 shall not compel industrial or commercial establishments or multifamily residences of eight or more units to use or pay user charges for waste services provided by the city in preference to those services provided by private businesses involved in the hauling of trash or refuse. 
The city may make collection of specified recyclable goods available to all residences of the city. At such time as this ser-vice is made available by the city, it shall be unlawful for anyone to remove from any container labeled as a "recycling" container, any material of any value, except that city employees may collect that material on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 742 (part).)  
Sec. 22B-3. - Regulations. 
(a)  All refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected and disposed of by the city or by private trash haulers. 
(b)  No person shall collect, convey over any of the streets or alleys of the city, or dispose of any refuse accumulation within the city except as provided in this article. 
(c)  The public works director or city manager shall have the authority to make regulations with respect to collection and disposal of refuse by the city, which regulations may pertain to the days of collection, type and location of pickup, and conveyance and disposal of refuse. The public works director or city manager shall have the authority to modify and revoke such regulations, from time to time, subject to review and approval of the city council. When the public works director determines that it is appropriate to do so, he may require the placement of recyclable materials in containers of a specific design and placed at appropriate locations for collection. The public works director shall have the authority to make regulations with respect to the purchase of containers, type of recyclable materials to be collected, frequency of collection or other items related to the collection of recyclable materials. 
(d)  Nothing within this article shall prohibit the actual producers of refuse or the owners of premises upon which refuse has accumulated from personally collecting, conveying and disposing of such refuse; provided, however, such producers or owners shall comply with the provisions of this article and with any other governing laws, ordinances or regulations, and provided further that such actual producers or owners shall not be exempt from the payment of refuse collection fees unless otherwise specifically provided herein. 
(e)  Nothing within this section or this article shall prohibit refuse collection outside the city from being transported over city streets to designated landfills for refuse disposal; provided, however, such collectors and transporters shall comply with the provisions of this chapter regarding the transportation of refuse as well as applicable state and federal law, including requirements relating to the "transportation of hazardous wastes." 
(Ord. No. 742 (part).)  
Sec. 22B-4. - Junk and appliances. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or leave outside any building or dwelling in the city any dilapidated furniture, appliance, machinery, equipment, building material, vehicle or portions thereof, or other items which are either wrecked, junked, dismantled or in inoperative condition, and which are not completely enclosed within a building or dwelling. All such substances shall be prohibited and abated in conformance with Chapter 12 of this Code. This section shall not apply to authorized junk dealers or establishment engaged in the repair, rebuilding, reconditioning or salvage of equipment. 
(Ord. No. 742 (part).)  
Sec. 22B-5. - Hazardous goods. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside any building in a place accessible to children any appliance having an airtight snap lock or similar device without first removing the lock or door from such appliance or container. This section shall not apply to any appliance or container which has been placed adjacent to a building and is crated, strapped or locked to such an extent that it is impossible for a child to obtain access to any airtight compartment thereof. Any such appliance or container shall be kept from public view. 
(Ord. No. 742 (part).)  
Sec. 22B-6. - Hazardous wastes. 
No person shall place hazardous waste in refuse containers for collection or bury or otherwise dispose of hazardous waste in or on private or public property within the city. Residents may contact the County Health Department for recommendations on disposal of hazardous waste. Highly flammable or explosive materials shall be stored and disposed of in accordance with Cortez Fire Protection District regulations at the expense of the owner or possessor of such materials. In no event shall toxic or flammable liquid or any waste liquid containing crude petroleum or its products be disposed of by discharge into or upon any gutter, street, alley, highway, storm drain, canal, ditch flood control channel, or detention pond, lake or other watercourse or upon the ground. 
(Ord. No. 742 (part).)  
Sec. 22B-7. - Refuse disposed by actual producers. 
(a)  The actual producers of refuse or the owners of premises upon which refuse is accumulated who desire to personally collect and dispose of such refuse shall do so in compliance with regulations of the city. 
(b)  The public works director shall promulgate rules and regulations subject to the approval of the city council concerning individual collection and disposal. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to exempt actual producers of refuse or the owners of premises upon which refuse is accumulated from the fees for refuse collection which are provided for in this article unless otherwise specifically exempted from payment of such fees. 
(Ord. No. 742 (part).)  
Sec. 22B-8. - Responsibility of owner of premises. 
The owner of the premises, as well as the occupant thereof, shall be responsible for compliance with the terms of this article and liable for any violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 742 (part).)  
Sec. 22B-9. - Fees. 
(a)  The fees to be charged and collected by the city for refuse collection, the frequency of pickup service to be offered by the city, and the fees to be charged by the city for special services concerning the collection and transportation of refuse shall be determined by the city council. The schedule of fees and frequency of pickups shall be determined and enacted by resolution adopted by the city council, which resolution shall also specify an effective date for the fees and charges specified in the resolution. Such resolution may also specify a minimum residential user charge which charge may be imposed and collected whether the residential property owner actually uses city sanitation services or not. Such charges are hereby determined to be necessary in order to allow the city to provide basic sanitation and trash collection service to the residents of the city, which service promotes the public health, safety and welfare. Said fees shall be subject to any limitation imposed by C.R.S. 30-15-401(7), as amended. 
(b)  The fees determined by council action in the form of a resolution are hereby assessed against the properties within the city receiving and benefitting from basic refuse collection service. If such fees are not paid within thirty days after normal city billing such services, the amount so assessed shall become a lien upon the property receiving or benefitting from such service or upon the property which is subject to a user charge as determined by resolution of the council. Collection of such assessment shall be in the manner provided by law. 
(c)  Any interruption of sanitation service due to the request of the customer lasting less than twenty-one days shall be deemed to be a continuation of service for the entire month for billing purposes and shall not be subject to a credit against the customer's billing.
